summary: Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend's late substitution in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously questioned Townsend's place in the England squad, but admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored against Italy. Townsend responded to Merson's initial criticism with a tweet after his goal. Merson's latest tweet suggests the bad feeling between the pair has not completely dissipated.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to sign FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto. The Japan international will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge this summer. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane claims that Chelsea's interest in Muto is not connected to the £200million sponsorship deal they signed with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013 and has 11 international caps for Japan, only graduated from Keio University with an economics degree two weeks ago. The player has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and has scored once for Japan. A £4million deal for Muto has been mooted, but he admits he hasn't decided whether to join Chelsea despite being pleased with their bid.

The passage states that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers. The researchers suggest that antibiotics, which are used to make farm animals put on weight, may also be fattening our children. The study, published in the medical journal Pediatrics, compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year olds with records on antibiotic prescription. By two years old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese. Children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. Boys seemed particularly prone to weight gain after being given antibiotics and were also slightly taller than boys who hadn't been given the drugs. The study did not prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but it suggested that if they do, it may be because they kill off bugs in the gut that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body. Killing certain gut bugs may also increase appetite. The lead author, Dr Antti Saari, warned that antibiotic exposure before six months of age, or repeatedly during infancy, was associated with increased body mass in healthy children. He suggested that such effects may play a role in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic and highlighted the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy. The passage also mentions that the worldwide obesity epidemic is more pronounced for boys and that an increase in the use of antibiotics could be an additional contributing factor to the development of excess weight problems. Previous research has found that babies given antibiotics are at higher risk of eczema and digestive problems. The over-prescription of antibiotics is a concern, as it may lead to the pills losing their power and making common infections harder to treat. The Government has warned that a new superbug could infect up to 200,000 Britons and kill 80,000 in a single outbreak.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover while taking up position in his sentry box during the Changing of the Guard. The incident was caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell. The guard lost his footing and slid sideways, knocking his bearskin and dropping his rifle. He quickly got up, but was visibly embarrassed as he realized how many tourists had witnessed the fall. The slip is thought to have been caused by metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a popular event at Buckingham Palace, with thousands of tourists gathering daily in the summer and every other day in the winter. The guard is part of the Queen's Guard, which is not purely ceremonial but also operational. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

"Roots," an epic miniseries about an African-American slave and his descendants, is being remade for 2016. The original miniseries had over 100 million viewers in 1977. A&E, Lifetime, and History networks will simulcast the remake. LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version. The new miniseries will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and will consult scholars for authenticity. The producers aim to bring the story to fans of the original and a new generation. The remake will be released in a time of significant racial issues in the United States. Burton stated that there is a new audience who do not know the story of "Roots" and its importance.

The passage describes allegations made by a former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, that he was sexually harassed and assaulted by palace aides at Clarence House in 1978. On his first day at work, he was groped and threatened after being asked about his sexual orientation. The incident occurred when he entered a bedroom to look for a pen and was approached by several male staff members. Lawler left his job the same day due to the ordeal. He reported the incident to palace officials last year after inquiries began into historical child sex abuse cases. His complaints were ignored for months before the police were notified. A retired royal aide, who was interviewed by police, denied involvement because he was working for the Queen at Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with any police investigation. The police have declined to comment further as investigations continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s television sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their life in Happy Valley, Oregon, and their decision to start a family. They cleverly adapted the original song's lyrics to reflect their own story, including their efforts to conceive and the moment Melissa discovered she was pregnant. At the end of the video, they share a sonogram of their unborn child. The Meeks made the video so loved ones living far away could know about the baby, and it took five takes to film. After finding out the gender of the child, another video is a possibility. The video's success was unexpected, but the couple has enjoyed the attention. Previously, Melissa had made a video capturing Jesse's reaction when he found out about the pregnancy through a tag on their dog. Another couple from Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, also made a pregnancy announcement video using the same theme song last year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble was used in several key scenes, including when Scarlett meets Rhett Butler and when she is attacked in the shanty town. The dress has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray over the years. The dress was part of a private collection amassed by James Tumblin, who began collecting onscreen costumes and props from the film in the 1960s. Tumblin bought the dress for $20 when he learned it was about to be thrown away. Other notable items sold at the auction include a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The auction featured more than 150 items from the Academy Award-winning film. Gone With The Wind celebrated its 75th anniversary last year and was based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 best-selling book. Hattie McDaniel, who played Mammy, became the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role in the film.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child's mother was holding him and another child when he slipped and fell 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents while in the pit. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, was pointed at a house's front door. The camera has not been working for over two years since all fixed devices were turned off in the West Midlands in March 2013. Around 300 speed and traffic cameras using old technology were decommissioned and replaced with mobile camera units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the issue and will send an engineer to the site. The council confirmed that the camera in Wellington Road will not be included in a new pilot using digital technology. There are no plans to make the camera operational again.

Usain Bolt will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. He will be part of the Jamaican team and is fit and healthy. Bolt is excited to participate and believes Jamaica has a strong relay tradition. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon. Bolt aims to make his country proud while wearing the national colors.

Neymar and Dani Alves supported Barcelona's basketball team by attending an El Clasico match against Real Madrid. Barcelona won the basketball game 85-80. Despite the victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division due to points difference. Neymar helped Brazil defeat Chile 1-0 at the Emirates Stadium. Before the international break, Barcelona won their El Clasico football match against Real Madrid and are four points clear at the top of La Liga. Neymar and his Barcelona teammates will return to La Liga action on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble of trophies. Neymar's sister Rafaella also attended the basketball game.

From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued in the Mediterranean Sea by the Italian coast guard. On Monday, 20 boats were in distress. Save the Children fears 400 migrants could be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized about 80 miles off the Libyan coast. The Italian coast guard cannot confirm this incident and has not found evidence of a capsized boat with 550 people. There has been an increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with more than 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool. Sanchez had a number of clubs interested in him after Barcelona let him leave. Wenger was aware of Liverpool's interest in Sanchez, which he believed was linked to their negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Sanchez has made an instant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger believes Sanchez's qualities, efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit make him one of the best. Wenger played down speculation linking Arsenal with a move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling. Despite losing Suarez and having Daniel Sturridge injured, Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has done well in developing his team.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The event will take place at the Lee Valley VeloPark and Wiggins hopes to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. The current record of 52.491km is held by Australian Rohan Dennis. Wiggins, who turns 35 on April 28, is a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner. He will be looking to motivate people to challenge themselves and will be attempting to set a mark that will last for some time. Tickets for the event will go on sale from April 19, priced at £49, £39 and £29. Wiggins will be hoping for a capacity crowd of 6,000 to spur him on.

Serena Williams struggled to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday, eventually winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3. Williams was not satisfied with her performance, calling it an 'eye opener' for the claycourt season. The US team lost 3-2 to Italy, with Williams and Alison Riske losing the doubles rubber 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. This result means the US has been relegated to World Group II. Williams, the world No 1, has won 19 singles grand slams but has been less successful at the French Open, winning it twice. The US captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, said the team needs to work harder to get back into the World Group next year.

River Plate are interested in signing Radamel Falcao, a former player who spent eight years with them before moving to Porto in 2009. The Argentine club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed a desire to have Falcao return, stating that the club's doors are open for him. However, a transfer is complicated. Falcao has struggled during his loan spell at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season. It is uncertain whether United will keep him or if he will return to Monaco, his parent club. Falcao has shown good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games to equal the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. Falcao joined River Plate at 15, made his first team debut four years later, and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances during his four seasons with the club.

Ella Henderson, a 2012 X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles against a vibrant city background. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency. The campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson is excited to work with the brand, which she uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, which manages Henderson, believes the collaboration is a good fit due to the artist's international appeal and the brand's popularity.

A billboard featuring officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler on March 14, has been erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. Torres is on leave while the incident is investigated. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, reads 'Thank you for your support, Kenosha.' Siler's family and friends are upset by the billboard, calling it 'disrespectful.' The police association claims the billboard was meant to thank the community for its support and that no offense was intended. Siler was shot after 'arming himself with a weapon' during a confrontation with Torres. The shooting occurred just 10 days after Torres shot another man, Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives. Knight survived and was charged with a crime. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces in the fighting on Monday in the southeastern town of Negur. The militants reportedly crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Iranian officials have asked Pakistani authorities to catch the surviving assailants. A militant group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. The group is an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim organization that has targeted Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Jaish al Adal has claimed responsibility for previous attacks on Iranian territory, including one in 2013 that killed 14 border guards. Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to rein in the terrorists. The Pakistani government condemned the attack, saying it was investigating and would apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan.

The Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO). This response was given in response to a question from Antonio Inoki, a flamboyant former wrestler and current lawmaker, during a meeting of Japan's parliament, the Diet. Inoki, who has a colorful background including stints in wrestling, politics, and TV, asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. The Defense Minister explained that while the ASDF does investigate unidentified flying objects that could violate Japan's airspace, they have never found evidence of UFOs from outer space. Inoki himself claims to have seen a UFO, but he does not know if aliens exist. This isn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed the implications of extraterrestrial visitors, as in 2007, a former Defense Minister pondered the legal ramifications of defending against an invasion from outer space under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was standing on a toilet in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport because he was worried the seat was not clean. The toilet broke, causing him to be injured with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. He was found bleeding and was taken to a hospital where he received stitches. Initially, he told his friends he was squatting on the toilet but later told police he was sitting when it broke. The police believe the incident was an accident and reminded people that toilets are for sitting on, not standing on.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom. The camera was traced back to Rebbie. He is accused of sexually abusing the girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others in the bathroom. The police found 41 videos on his computer, some of which showed close-up images of children's genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and purchasing the camera specifically to record the 15-year-old girl. He faces several charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail. The relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family is unknown.

The passage describes a series of photographs by Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama, where fathers are pictured leaping into the air next to their daughters. The daughters are pictured looking directly into the camera with a smile, while their fathers perform energetic poses. The series is part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman," and the fathers are dressed in sharp suits, embodying the term "salaryman." The images are meant to show the fathers' fun side, as they are usually expected to act serious. The daughters wear casual clothing, and the families are photographed in front of various Japanese landmarks. The photographs have gained interest online for their unique and curious nature. The fathers' expressions range from excited to slightly pained due to their energetic leaps, and some of the daughters can't help but giggle at their fathers' antics.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has sparked discussions in English cricket, but the focus has shifted to the start of the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially dropped from the England team in 2014, is now part of the Surrey team and is aiming to make a return to the England squad. Pietersen appeared reflective during a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval, but he was also seen joking with teammates and photographers. The batsman is working hard with Surrey to regain his place in the England Test team, with hopes of helping England regain the Ashes this summer. Surrey will begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19, and Pietersen will play in a match against Oxford MCCU on Sunday.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria was initially fired due to a poor run of results, but was then reinstated the following day by the club's owner, Angelo Massone, who decided to give the coaching staff another chance. However, after Ceahlaul lost 2-0 to FC Botosani on Saturday, Ze Maria was fired again. He had replaced Florin Marin in January and was Ceahlaul's third coach this season. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international with 25 caps, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic. Ceahlaul is currently 16th in the standings, six points away from safety.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco team-mate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets his move to Manchester United. Falcao was not happy in France but Dirar thinks he would have been better off staying at Monaco. Falcao moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to hit the heights he achieved before suffering a serious knee injury. United will have to pay £46million to make Falcao's transfer permanent but are unlikely to do so after he scored only four goals all season.

New Zealand police are seeking the public's help to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday. The man wore a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt. He stole the dairy's till and about $1,500 in cash. The incident occurred at Union St dairy, and the owner's daughter was present during the robbery. The man threw the cash register to the ground and fled with the till drawer. The police report no weapons were used, and the suspect remains at large. Anyone with information is encouraged to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or to message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested on Monday. She is accused of having sex with a 15-year-old student in her car on two consecutive nights in January. This arrest comes a month after her first arrest on March 19, when she admitted to kissing another 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts. Granado was released on bail after the first arrest and was placed on administrative leave by school officials. The second arrest occurred after another student came forward with similar allegations. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district has assured families that they took immediate action, and Granado is currently on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being on school property.

A video of a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times. The dog belonged to the local bike shop's owner and was attacked when it approached the water's edge. The crocodile held onto the dog for hours, and the incident was witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston, who was on holiday with his wife. The crocodile is part of a local sanctuary population that lives in the nearby mangroves and sometimes appears in the marina and even on the resort's golf course. The video has sparked reactions on social media, with some expressing horror and dislike for crocodiles. Crocodiles in Mexico can grow up to 6 meters long and are living closer to humans due to urbanization.

Steve Bruce is confident that Hull City can stay in the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton. Hull have six games left to secure their Premier League status, facing tough fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce believes that staying positive and winning a few matches will be enough to keep them up. Hull have had a strong three years in the league, but Bruce acknowledges that this season has been the most challenging due to the expectation created by their previous success. Injuries to key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass have hindered Hull's performance. Southampton moved up to fifth in the table after the win, but manager Ronald Koeman had to address an incident where Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty, despite James Ward-Prowse being the designated penalty taker. Koeman will discuss the importance of team rules with his squad.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching after he asked pupils to change their exam answers after the exam session had finished. This invalidated the school's SATs results for 11-year-olds in English, maths, and science. The local education authority launched an investigation after being tipped off about the suspected breach of exam rules. The Department for Education annulled all SATs results for the entire school as a result. Guffick admitted the allegations and accepted that his conduct was unacceptable. He claimed he asked pupils to make their answers more legible, not to change them. The National College for Teaching and Leadership panel banned Guffick from teaching for at least two years, and Education Secretary Nicky Morgan agreed with the decision. Guffick showed remorse and regret for his actions.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri. They got married last year in Mauritius. Lindegaard has struggled for playing time at United and is third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his lack of playing time, he is happy in his personal life, as shown by his Instagram post with his wife. They have a son together and have been dating since 2012. Lindegaard has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons at United. He was linked with a move to FC Midtjylland in January but the transfer did not happen.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite estimates of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, for $260,000, came from a Sotheby's employee. Reggie Jackson, a Yankee Hall of Famer, bought the letters after the stadium closed in 2008. He hoped a new generation would enjoy them. The letters, which are 10 feet tall and wide, were installed in 1976. In addition, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were photographed inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha. Neither player will be disciplined for the incidents. Rodgers wants the players to learn from the experience and has urged them to understand the responsibilities that come with being elite athletes. The manager is focused on preparing his team for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with captain Steven Gerrard available after serving a three-match suspension. Rodgers is not revealing whether he will recall Gerrard for the match, stating that his priority is getting Liverpool into their first FA Cup final under his management. He believes that the team is ready to progress and has cited the importance of learning from past losses as part of the journey to success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and posted a picture on Twitter of him relaxing with his dog at home. He was in good form during Germany's 2-0 win over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool at the weekend. He has scored three goals and provided four assists since January and claims he fits perfectly into English football due to the high number of games. Ozil was rumored to have been seen in a Berlin nightclub after missing the Newcastle game, but these claims were dismissed by manager Arsene Wenger.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique. The club is 'very happy' with his performance, despite speculation about his future. Luis Enrique signed a two-year deal last summer and is close to winning the La Liga title. Bartomeu says there is time to discuss a contract extension in the future. He is impressed with how Enrique has prepared the team for their upcoming matches. Barcelona are in contention to win three trophies this season. Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi scored in Barcelona's 2-0 win over Valencia on Saturday.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool. The deal is worth around £100,000 a week and will run until 2020. Henderson had 14 months remaining on his previous contract. He is the third player under Brendan Rodgers to sign a new deal, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson has been one of the most improved players under Rodgers and has contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season. He is considered a candidate to replace Steven Gerrard as Liverpool captain when Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Raheem Sterling's contract talks are expected to resume at the end of the season. Liverpool's Chief Executive Ian Ayre expects Sterling to stay at Anfield for 'a long time'. Up to 10 players are expected to leave Liverpool this summer.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. He signed a three-year deal when he moved from Atletico last July but has struggled to make the left back position his own. Luis played for Brazil in their friendly wins against France and Chile during the international break. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is urging his team to stay focused and win every game to secure the Premier League title.

Nathan Hughes had his ban over-turned on appeal after he was initially suspended for three matches for accidentally knocking out George North. Hughes was deemed 'reckless' for failing to prevent his knee colliding with North's head as he scored a try for Northampton. The Wasps No 8 was shown a red card for the offence, but that dismissal has now been officially rescinded. The appeal lodged by Wasps was upheld, and the ban was thrown out. The incident was the third time North had been knocked out in two months, and he has since been advised to take a month off to recover from concussion symptoms. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss against Toulon while awaiting his appeal hearing. He is now free to return to action immediately, but is not in the match-day squad for Wasps' Aviva Premiership trip to London Welsh. The appeal panel concluded that no act of foul play took place as the incident occurred accidentally.

The passage describes a fiery sunset observed in Washington and other parts of the Pacific Northwest, including Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The deep reddish color of the sunset was caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires were started by farmers burning grass in their fields, but grew out of control due to strong winds. The smoke from these fires was carried across the Pacific Ocean by atmospheric winds and reached the Pacific Northwest. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors from the sunlight, allowing red and orange colors to appear more intense during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue. The fires in Siberia destroyed dozens of villages, and rescue crews were able to put out the flames.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in St. Louis, Missouri, just over a month after she bought it. The car was found after a man recognized it and tipped off the police. When Schoenig got her car back, she found that the thieves had spray painted the rims red, added red detailing to the sides, and changed the steering wheel to include orange accents. Instead of being upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to thank the thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. She is now getting the car professionally cleaned due to the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who found her car, Mick Sexton. The smoothie will be called the Sexton on Wheels and will feature banana, pineapple, peach, and coconut cream.

Manchester City players will lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, have incentivised contracts to help the club stay within financial fairplay requirements. City are currently in fourth place in the Premier League and will be just four points ahead of Liverpool if they win their next game. The top three teams in the league qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round to join them. The City squad have around £12million resting on reaching their European target. City have lost seven times since starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea and have suffered early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admits the season has disintegrated and they must improve. The club faces a battle to sign top players like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who also interests Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City's Under 18s 1-0 in a match played at Altrincham's Moss Lane. The match was free to attend and featured a high number of English and Mancunian players. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick for United. The match was played in a 3-5-2 formation, similar to the one used by the senior team. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City have lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. The match showcased the skills and commitment of young English players, highlighting the potential for future opportunities in the first team.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game'. Hart, who earned his 50th cap against Italy, said he is still learning from Buffon, who is 37 years old and has 147 caps. Hart expressed his desire to continue learning and playing for England, inspired by Buffon's career.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver burritos in 67 cities. Customers will pay a 9% service charge, and delivery fees start at $5, varying with distance and demand. The restaurant previously declined offers from other delivery services but has now chosen Postmates, which uses independent contractors. Chipotle's popularity is evident as two presidential candidates, Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio, have been seen in their restaurants. Other fast food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an opinion piece in The Boston Globe urging the Department of Justice to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. They argue that the death penalty would prolong their suffering through years of appeals and would be a constant painful reminder for their two remaining children. They advocate for Tsarnaev to spend the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waive all rights to appeal. The Richards stress that they are speaking for themselves and not for others when they make this plea. They believe that taking the death penalty off the table would allow them to turn the page and move towards a better future.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747-8 that has been transformed into a luxury home for a billionaire. The cost of this project is estimated at £400 million and took three years to complete. The plane, which would normally carry 600 passengers, has been redesigned to accommodate a single owner and dozens of guests. It features multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a state room, and an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds for sleeping. The plane also includes a conference room, an office or guest bedroom, and a lounge with a television. The interior design is luxurious and hotel-like, with no resemblance to a typical commercial airplane cabin. The layout of the plane is detailed in a plan published by Greenpoint Technologies.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral, Florida, carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station. The rocket's first stage attempted to land on a floating barge but landed too hard and tipped over. SpaceX aims to reuse rockets to reduce the cost of space travel. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station and return with over 3,000 pounds of cargo. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the space station. The launch was the second attempt after Monday's launch was scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The wedding will take place on Thursday, April 23, and the couple will be chosen from a contest announced by NBC's Today show. The winning couple will receive a free wedding reception, a hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley, who was married to Elvis, emphasized that the chapel and wedding are not a joke and are first-class. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis artifacts outside of his home in Memphis, Tennessee. Couples must submit a video or photos along with an explanation detailing why they deserve the prize. The winner will be announced next Monday.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League. Liverpool and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet have played 47 games this season, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. The team won 2-0 against Newcastle United on Monday night, with Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scoring. Henderson says the team needs to keep winning to put pressure on City, who are four points ahead. Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal and admits he thought Newcastle should have had a penalty when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A on Saturday. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack. Roma's goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves in the second half to preserve the win. The victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches and they remain in fifth place. Security was tight for Napoli's visit due to a fan's death before last season's Italian Cup final. Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho.

The match between Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town ended in a 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The game was uninspiring, and the media team at Doncaster Rovers had a difficult time compiling match highlights. The video they posted on the club's YouTube channel was only 27 seconds long, featuring 14 seconds of actual match action, which included the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle. This brief video is a must-see for all football fans.

The passage describes a man named Roland Giroux who has a unique relationship with his blood parrot cichlid. Unlike cats and dogs, which can be touched, marine pets like the blood parrot cichlid are not typically touched by their owners. However, Giroux has developed a bond with his fish, which he captures on camera. He places his hand in the tank and gently cups the fish, then strokes it with his finger. The fish initially moves away but returns to be massaged and seems to enjoy the sensation. The fish swims off and returns multiple times to be stroked. Giroux notes that the fish used to share its tank with two other fish but had to be separated due to bullying. He then began feeding the fish by hand and noticed it becoming more sociable. The fish now enjoys being stroked and becomes frustrated if Giroux doesn't play with it daily. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and the redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986. Giroux plays with and massages his fish for at least 15 minutes each day.

Ben Stokes has a reputation for being a fiery character in the England cricket team. He broke his wrist punching a locker after being dismissed last year, and this serves as a reminder to him to channel his aggression properly. Stokes has had a year of ups and downs but has fought his way back into the team. He is not afraid to stand up to opponents, as shown during the Ashes series. England coach Peter Moores had a chat with Stokes after a clash with Marlon Samuels in the second Test, and the advice seemed to work as Stokes responded positively. England must manage Stokes carefully to ensure they do not quash his natural exuberance and desire to take on opponents. His aggression should be controlled but not stifled, as it can lead to runs and wickets. England wants Stokes to play as much as possible to help him hit his full potential. There is a consideration to play the second spinner Adil Rashid, but England wants both Stokes and Chris Jordan to play and grow in the international game. This summer, there will rarely be a need for two spinners, so England is excited about the prospect of these two exciting cricketers improving.

The Wales vs Belgium Euro 2016 qualifier on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are at the top of Group B with 11 points each, but Belgium lead on goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has increased expectations for the team. The Football Association of Wales (FAW) has stated that the match has sold out due to high demand. The Wales squad prefers the Cardiff City Stadium over the larger Millennium Stadium for this match. UEFA rules prevent the venue from being changed within 120 days of the scheduled date.

England's Under-17 squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria includes players from several Premier League clubs. The defending champions have a 100% record in qualifying and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. The squad features players like Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi from Arsenal, and Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold from Liverpool. They will play Italy on May 7, Holland on May 10, and Ireland on May 13. Goalkeepers are Paul Woolston and Will Huffer, defenders include Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, and Jay Dasilva, midfielders are Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland, and Chris Willock, and forwards are Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi, and Ike Ugbo. This is the first call-up for Arsenal's Stephy Mavididi.

Manchester City is interested in signing Evangelos Patoulidis, a 14-year-old playmaker from Anderlecht. Arsenal and Barcelona have also shown interest in the young talent. Patoulidis turned down an offer from Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies. Manchester City has been in talks with Anderlecht's chairman, Roger Vanden Stock, to negotiate a compensation package for the player. City's manager, Manuel Pellegrini, is looking to secure the young talent to build for the future.

A 33-year-old transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found dead in a flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. She died from injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and must return to a London police station for further questioning. The London Ambulance Service was called to the scene on March 28th at around 9:30 pm. The police are urging anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Miss Santillan worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami and had expressed her love for London on social media. The investigation is being led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, who is seeking information to understand why this happened and to solve the case.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, saved money for a gravestone for her baby, Daniel James. £207 was set aside for the £500 gravestone, but the money went missing. She suspected her housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, and his girlfriend Carol. A lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show revealed Jamie had stolen the money. Jamie confessed to taking the money and blamed his girlfriend Carol in a Facebook message. Dawn was devastated and felt betrayed, as the money was meant to show her love for her lost child.

The Islamist terror group ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, a minority group, on Wednesday. Most of those released were women and children, with the rest being ill or elderly. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders. The Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil, the capital of Iraq's Kurdistan region. The exact reason for the release is unclear. ISIS had previously captured and displaced Yazidis, killing hundreds and forcing them to flee their homes in northern Iraq last summer. The Yazidis are a minority group of Kurdish descent with a unique religious identity. They have faced persecution, including being referred to as devil worshipers. The release comes after ISIS' conquest of the town of Sinjar, which led to a humanitarian crisis and international intervention through airstrikes. The Yazidi population in northern Iraq is estimated to be around 500,000.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, has had an impressive season, breaking into the first team and England's side. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animation, using still photographs to create an animated effect, showcases some of his best goals and celebrations. The video, produced by Copa90, is titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and is released ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday. He is up against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead Liverpool forward despite a trophyless season and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who collected a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, said Rodgers' future should not be determined by one game. He acknowledged the difficulty with the players that came in last summer and that they have not yet bedded in. Carragher thinks Rodgers and the team will aim to win a trophy and return to the top four next season. He emphasized the importance of making the right signings to improve the squad. Carragher received a Beacon Award in London for his work with his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in eight schools in deprived areas of Merseyside.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport. The toy, a brightly colored Nerf gun that fires sponge darts, was deemed a security risk. Security officers took exception to the toy when it was picked up on the X-ray machines. They demanded James hand it over and also performed a pat down and inspection of the child. James's father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security checks as 'ludicrous' and 'over-zealous'. The family was forced to leave the toy behind to avoid missing their flight to Lanzarote. Upon returning from their holiday, James was bought a replacement toy gun off eBay. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their decision, stating that no items resembling prohibited items are allowed through security. The airport offered to post the toy back to the family's home, but the family chose not to take up the offer. The hand luggage restrictions on all UK flights are set by the Department of Transport, and replica or model guns are included in the prohibited list.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed specific requirements for the 'successful candidate', including non-smoking, fitness, attractiveness, reliability, honesty, loyalty, domestic skills, and culinary skills. The man, identified as Rich, is 31 years old, athletic, heavily tattooed, and has brown hair and brown eyes. He does not drink, smoke, or do drugs, enjoys the outdoors, sports, fishing, camping, and owns property. He claims to make good money and is willing to spend on his partner. The advertisement also states that the successful applicant must enjoy being outdoors but also be a 'princess when need to be'. Former partners are not welcome to apply. The man promises 'lots of benefits' for the 'successful candidate'. Daily Mail Australia tried but failed to contact the man behind the advertisement.

Five former England managers have backed FA chairman Greg Dyke's proposals to increase the number of homegrown players in Premier League squads. The proposals include increasing the minimum number of homegrown players from eight to 12 and changing the rules so that 'homegrown' means having trained in England for three years before the age of 18 rather than before 21. The former managers, Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren, warn that English football will suffer if the proposals are blocked. They argue that the pool of English talent playing at the top level is shrinking, which is a disadvantage for any England manager. They cite the emergence of young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane as signs of encouragement but stress that these players are not being given enough opportunities.

The passage discusses the rapid progression of Demelza Poldark's pregnancy in the TV show "Poldark". In the latest episode, viewers see Demelza, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, go from barely showing to giving birth to a baby daughter within ten minutes of screen time. The pregnancy timeline is described as unrealistic, as the previous episode ended with the announcement of the pregnancy, and the next episode begins with Demelza being eight months pregnant. The birth occurs shortly after, with no indication of the passing of time. Fans have noticed this trend, as a similar situation occurred with another character, Elizabeth, whose pregnancy also progressed rapidly between episodes. The passage also mentions the popularity of Aidan Turner's character, Ross Poldark, as a heartthrob among viewers, despite his marriage to Demelza.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has asked his team to focus on their own performances and not be distracted by their relegation rivals. The team is three points from safety in the Premier League after two consecutive wins, including a 3-2 victory at West Bromwich Albion where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Pearson believes that if Leicester can maintain their form until the end of the season, they have a realistic chance of staying up. He is wary of the team becoming overly optimistic and wants them to concentrate on their own games, rather than the performances of other teams.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has completed the longest migration of a mammal ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles. Varvara left her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island, crossed the Pacific Ocean, and traveled down the West Coast of the United States to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale that swam 10,190 miles. Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, which led researchers to believe that she might actually be an eastern gray whale, not an endangered western gray whale as initially thought. This discovery could mean that the number of western gray whales is even lower than the estimated 150. The study's lead author, Bruce Mate, believes this long trip shows Varvara's impressive ability to navigate over long distances and suggests that some western gray whales might actually be eastern grays.

A landslide on Hokkaido Island, Japan, caused a section of seabed to rise overnight, creating a new stretch of coastline on Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu. The seabed rose as high as 50 feet above sea level in some places, measuring roughly 1,000 to 1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. The emergence of the landmass is believed to be due to melting ice and snow causing a section of land to drop, which in turn pivoted the underwater area into the air. Local residents were surprised by the new land, as there were no tremors or sounds to indicate the movement. Geologists believe the event was not related to the recent earthquake in Nepal. The new coastline has exposed marine organisms such as seaweed and sea urchins.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims that he will leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer. He expressed his love for the club and stated that he is happy with his teammates and life in Paris. Van der Wiel had a recent disagreement with his manager, Laurent Blanc, after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea. Despite this, he insists he is content and wants to sign a new contract with PSG. The club is rumored to be interested in signing Dani Alves from Barcelona, which could affect Van der Wiel's future with the team. He remains ready to play whenever called upon, regardless of the coach's decisions.

Carlos Tevez has reportedly told Juventus he wishes to leave this summer to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. His contract with Juventus does not expire until the end of next season, but Boca have confirmed they are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old. Boca president Daniel Angelici has stressed that Tevez must terminate his contract with Juventus first, which runs until 2016. Although Juventus are reluctant to lose their top scorer, they have accepted the player wants to leave and have started identifying potential replacements. Tevez has always said he intends to finish his career back at his first club Boca Juniors. His international manager Tata Martino claims any potential move would have no bearing on the player's Argentina future, stating that Boca Juniors are as great a team as Juventus.

Pep Guardiola, Bayern Munich's manager, had a hole in his trousers during their Champions League match against Porto. The hole was in the left trouser leg of his grey trousers, revealing his underwear. Guardiola joked about needing to buy new trousers for the next match. Bayern Munich won 6-1, overturning a two-goal deficit from the first leg in Portugal. Goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. The victory secured Bayern Munich a place in the Champions League semi-finals.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. Ten people, including four children, were involved in the accident. Two patients, a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain, were first airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane. Later, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also flown out. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. A man suffered hand lacerations, and two females were uninjured. The highway was closed, and diversions were set up south of Fernvale. Emergency crews found one person trapped in their vehicle and used hydraulic cutting gear to free them. The Rescue 500 helicopter airlifted patients to hospital. The highway closure was expected to last for a few hours.

Mesut Ozil, an Arsenal midfielder, received an Apple Watch and shared his excitement on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from the TV show Knight Rider. The watch ranges in price from £299 to £13,500. Ozil is expected to play in the upcoming Premier League match between Arsenal and Chelsea on Sunday at 4pm. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six league games remaining. Jack Wilshere, who has been out injured for five months, returned to the bench for Arsenal's FA Cup semi-final win over Reading. Arsenal legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere is the future of the club but questions his ability to stay fit due to his injury record.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby at Old Trafford. He has sent off three players from Manchester United and Manchester City this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany during an international match. Despite accusations of favoritism towards United, Clattenburg has only shown two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players. The derby has added importance as United lead City by a point in the race for second place. Clattenburg is considered one of the Premier League's leading referees. The match will have Simon Beck and Jake Collin as assistant referees, and Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming embattled MP Billy Gordon would quit after being accused of domestic violence and admitting to his criminal past. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, said he sympathized with Gordon's position and has personally faced racist attitudes from major parties. Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party but announced he would remain in parliament as an independent, causing chaos for the government. Katter's statement, which used the term 'little black puppet on a string,' has sparked criticism on social media. Katter defended his statement, saying he used the term because he is 'dark' and can identify with the attitudes faced by Gordon. He used federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of independents becoming puppets for the government, but vowed Gordon would not make that mistake.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but uses dancing to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. She has faced bullying and judgment because of her condition but aims to show that she is just like everyone else, doing things a little differently but not deserving of different treatment. Dayna created a video of herself dancing to counteract negative perceptions and stereotypes. She previously made another dancing video to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off." Dayna wants people to look past her disability and see her as an individual. She drives, attends college, and participates in typical 19-year-old activities. Dayna has also started motivational speaking at local schools in the Chicago area.

Orlando City, an MLS team, is interested in signing Javier Hernandez from Manchester United. Hernandez, a Mexican international, would be a big draw for the Florida team due to their large Latin-American fanbase. The club is coached by Adrian Heath, a former striker for Everton and Manchester City. Hernandez has struggled during his loan spell at Real Madrid, but there are eight European clubs interested in him, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is willing to sell him for around £8million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer. Pereira was on the bench against Aston Villa on Saturday.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a car at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles and set it on fire around 12:15am on Saturday. The driver of the car, who got into an argument with the suspects while pumping gas, said they tried to carjack him. The suspects covered his white Dodge Charger in gasoline and lit it ablaze while there were two passengers inside. No one was injured, but the car was completely ruined. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

A chiropractor in Iowa named Charles Manuel has surrendered his license to practice chiropractic. He admitted to accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Manuel signed an agreement admitting his misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing the charges against him. Despite his actions, Manuel received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires that Manuel prove any circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state. He also recommended that patients stop taking medication he prescribed to them. A woman at his former practice said he hadn't worked there for some time. Manuel's practice was listed with a residential address in Lamoni, Iowa.

A Russian fighter jet intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The U.S. plane, an RC-135U, was flying in international airspace when it was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker. The U.S. crew described the Russian pilot's actions as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed. The Pentagon plans to file a complaint through diplomatic channels with Russia. This is not the first time such an incident has occurred; a similar event happened a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk. Russian and U.S. aircraft often encounter each other in Northern Europe and the area between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City. The theft occurred on March 27, just days before President Obama visited Utah. The rifle was in a hard rifle case, secured with padlocks and chains, but the thief broke the car's window and used a rope to pull the case out. The thief likely used another vehicle's momentum to break the case's handle free from the lock. The FBI agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing and tools were also stolen. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The hotel does not have surveillance cameras. The Secret Service was notified about the theft but could not comment on whether it affected security measures for the president's visit. The police do not know if the thief specifically targeted the agent's car. The rifle has not been recovered.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Canberra. Professor Paul Mullen, a forensic psychiatrist, examined Costa after the attack and believes that Costa's state of mind was declining due to dementia and alcohol abuse. Mullen stated that Costa's mood fluctuated "moment to moment" based on the 000 calls he made during the incident. The presence of a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet where Costa was found was cited as evidence of his confused mental state. Mullen believes that Costa's brain was compromised by dementia and alcohol, leading to a confused state where he may not have understood the consequences of his actions. The prosecutor, Shane Drumgold, suggested that Costa feigned his failing memory during the interview with Mullen, but Mullen denied these claims. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as a not guilty verdict could be returned if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty kick instead of regular penalty taker Leighton Baines. Barkley missed the 10th minute penalty against Burnley, which was saved by goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Martinez stated that Barkley showed responsibility and that multiple players are capable of taking penalties. If Romelu Lukaku had been on the pitch, he would have taken the penalty. Martinez also mentioned that there was no dispute between Barkley and Baines, unlike a previous incident with Kevin Mirallas. Despite the miss, Everton won the match 1-0 with a goal from Mirallas.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The cruise line, Holland America Line, stated that the deaths appeared to be a murder-suicide. The cabin was secured, and the FBI was notified. The ship had left Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise. The cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers after knocking on the cabin door. The FBI is investigating the incident, and the cruise line is cooperating with the authorities.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland forward and assistant coach, has made a winning start as coach of Curacao in World Cup qualifying. Curacao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament after drawing 2-2 in a second-leg match at Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team won 2-1 on Saturday in Willemstad. The first-round encounter was headed to extra time until Charlton Vicento scored in the 87th minute, five minutes after coming on as a substitute. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup losing semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and last year as assistant to coach Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, an experienced midfielder who has won numerous trophies with clubs like Inter Milan and Real Madrid, believes that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would be as significant as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester being seven points from safety with only eight games left, Cambiasso is determined to help the team stay up. He considers the task of keeping Leicester in the Premier League as important as winning a cup or league title with another team. The Argentinian midfielder is optimistic about their chances, stating that they still have a quarter of the season left to turn things around. He signed for Leicester in the summer and has quickly become a key player, expressing his happiness with the club and his family's adjustment to life in the East Midlands. Cambiasso is open to staying beyond his current one-year deal, provided they can secure enough points to stay in the Premier League.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma, who has two children under five by two different fathers, has handed both infants over to her 52-year-old mother Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie is threatening to ban Gemma from seeing the children because she refuses to stop drinking and partying, and Debbie suspects Gemma of stealing. Debbie has been caring for the children after social services threatened to take them away. Gemma is unemployed and admits to stealing money and items from her mother in the past, but denies stealing an iPad. Debbie says Gemma has been off the rails since the age of 13, and she has been left to bring up both children alone. Gemma's children call Debbie "mum" and not "grandma." Debbie is at the end of her tether and is considering banning Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because she can't trust her not to steal their possessions. Debbie loves the children and feels awful about the situation, stating that Gemma doesn't put the children first and needs to grow up, stop drinking, and stop taking drugs and partying.

Chelsea defender John Terry fouled Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao with a strong challenge from behind during the build-up to Eden Hazard's goal. The challenge led to a loose ball which was collected by Cesc Fabregas and eventually resulted in Hazard scoring. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed during half-time analysis that play should have been stopped for Terry's foul. They believed that the elbow from Terry was a foul and that Falcao should have been awarded a free kick.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway on Thursday morning. Everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated. The fire was captured on video by Michael Barnett, who uploaded it to CNN iReport. The bus caught fire after a rear tire blew out, and it burst into flames after everyone had gotten off. The fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except for Hillary Scott's Bible. The band's two other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not traveling on the bus. Lady Antebellum is set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman, a physicist from Dundee University, is developing a space laser system that could potentially be used to power homes in the future. The system involves satellites orbiting the Earth, covered in mirrors to harvest sunlight and convert it into laser light using semiconductors. The energy created by the satellites would be shot back down to Earth and could be used to boost the energy received by solar panels. This technology could make solar power viable in places like Scotland and could be used to restore power quickly to disaster-stricken areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and Dr Quarterman plans to move the trials to Portugal. The lasers used in this system would not be powerful enough to cause harm, such as blinding a pigeon or destroying a planet, and are different from the laser system proposed by Tokyo researchers to clear space junk from Earth's orbit. Dr Quarterman acknowledges the potential for concern about who controls the satellites, but the lasers are not designed to be used as weapons.

A predatory convicted paedophile named Stephen Munden, 54, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit in Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who has a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, was last seen leaving a hospital at 6.15pm on Tuesday. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. Munden suffers from learning difficulties and has a history of possessing indecent images of children. He was sentenced last August for sexual offences and was subject to a hospital order. Officers have launched a manhunt to find Munden, who is about 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, and has dark hair. He may have shaved off his beard before leaving the hospital. The police are urging anyone who has seen Munden or knows his whereabouts to come forward as a matter of urgency.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back more than $2.6 million in gifts after Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling sued her. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting extremely wealthy older men and using the couple's money for gifts, including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with Donald Sterling giving her gifts and that she never took advantage of him. Shelly Sterling was thrilled with the court decision, and her lawyer said it sets a precedent that the injured spouse can recover damages from the recipient of these ill-begotten gifts. Donald Sterling's downfall came after an audio recording surfaced of him chastising Stiviano for posting pictures with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson. The NBA banned Sterling from the league and fined him $2.5 million.

Thierry Henry believes Arsenal need to purchase four top players in the summer transfer window to have a chance of winning the Barclays Premier League title. He suggests Arsenal need a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top quality striker. Henry also questions whether Arsenal can win the league with Olivier Giroud as their first choice striker. Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly, served as New York State Attorney General, was a U.S. senator from New York, and became vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was created to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program. It had 8 unmanned test flights before the first 19 manned launches. The Soyuz spacecraft was designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau, now known as RKK Energia, in the 1960s. It was developed to replace the Voskhod spacecraft and was initially intended for the Soviet manned lunar programs. The Soyuz spacecraft is still in use today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine released their fourth studio album, Renegades, on December 5, 2000. In the same year, the band faced internal tensions leading to lead vocalist Zack de la Rocha's departure and the band's breakup. De la Rocha pursued a low-key solo career, while the remaining members formed the rock supergroup Audioslave with Chris Cornell, former frontman of Soundgarden. Audioslave released three albums before disbanding in 2007. Rage Against the Machine reunited in 2007 and performed together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in April 2007.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a market index of 30 companies on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one of these companies and is part of the BSE SENSEX index. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the world's 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous Asian country with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. Vietnam is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, and has maritime borders with Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the highest economic growth rates in the world. In 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam is one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states, officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film. It was written and directed by John Gatins, who was making his directorial debut with this film.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who committed two acts of violence against the British in India. His execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement. He became a popular folk hero after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film Dangal, directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I, born James Stuart, was King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625. He ruled Scotland and England in a personal union, with each country maintaining its own parliament, judiciary, and laws. James VI and I advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland, but faced many difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand actress born on December 26, 1970. She was part of the original cast of the soap opera Shortland Street. She is known for her roles as Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, and Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. She also starred in the 2009 film Separation City and the Australian series Rake. Recently, she played Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth for four years, leaving the show in 2016.
Rob Sheridan is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer born on October 11, 1979. He is best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in several films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop is an album that received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful. It debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 in the United States, selling 258,000 copies in its first week. This made it Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the US. The album sold 757,000 copies overall and was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium. This album is also the last to feature Frusciante as he confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher was a Prime Minister who implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She was a controversial figure but is often praised as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, even though debates about her policies continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author born on February 5, 1964. He has a musical career and has also established himself as a writer. McKagan has written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who performs acting roles and also narrates commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative center. Valencia is Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain, and its capital is Valencia, which is the third largest city and metropolitan area in Spain.
Buffy Summers was first portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in a television series.
Make It or Break It ended after its third season. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a field that combines knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to enable computers to recognize and convert spoken language into text. Applications of speech recognition include voice user interfaces, call routing, appliance control, data entry, document preparation, and speech-to-text processing. The field has seen significant advances, as evidenced by the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, and IflyTek. These companies have reported that their speech recognition systems are based on deep learning technology.

Richard Alf, born January 26, 1952, and passed away on January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970, originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention. Alf served as its chairman and was part of a group that included Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. The convention was later renamed the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.
