McIlroy and Dubuisson are tied for the lead at 15 and 16 under par respectively, with McIlroy bidding to win his first title since May. McIlroy carded a 67 for the third straight day, including an eagle on the 12th hole. He is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leads Danny Willett by a significant margin in the points race. Chris Wood and Richard Bland are further back in the standings. McIlroy feels he can shoot a low round and is playing within himself, despite a few mistakes during his round.

Sheikh Ali Salman, the leader of al-Wefaq, stated that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government must offer concrete solutions. He wants someone who can speak for the royal family, and sees Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist. Hardliners, including the Prime Minister, oppose concessions fearing they will encourage more demands from the opposition. Sheikh Salman believes dialogue is necessary and welcomes it. He acknowledges that young protesters have lost faith in the opposition parties but insists that working with reformists within the royal family is the way forward. He notes that an agreement with the crown prince was reached before GCC troops were brought in to crush dissent in 2011. He is hopeful about the new US Secretary of State John Kerry's approach to human rights and democratic practices in Bahrain. Sheikh Salman is critical of the UK's approach, urging public pressure for reform instead of private conversations. He insists al-Wefaq will continue to call for peaceful demonstrations despite the ban on public gatherings. He also calls for the release of opposition leaders and human rights activists imprisoned on allegedly tortured evidence. He believes their participation in the dialogue is crucial for its success.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after a several months' long illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later. Hogwood was a leading figure in the early-music movement and founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973. He worked with many leading orchestras and made over 200 CDs, including a famous recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various positions and titles, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was known for his generosity and influence in historically informed music. The AAM's music director Richard Egarr and soprano Dame Emma Kirkby praised Hogwood for his contributions to music and his personality.

In the year to the end of March, 57 victims of homicide were recorded in Scotland, down five from the previous year. This is the lowest number of recorded homicide cases for a single 12-month period since 1976 and half the figure of nine years ago. Only one case of homicide recorded in 2015-16 was unresolved as of 31 March 2016. A sharp instrument, particularly a knife, remained the most common method of killing in Scotland, accounting for 51% of homicides (29 cases). Nearly all of these cases (26 out of 29) involved a knife. The majority of the accused had an unknown status for alcohol and drugs, but 31% (20 people) were identified by the police as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson commented on the continued falls in homicide cases and the long-term decline in violent crime, emphasizing the need for continued efforts through education and enforcement. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker expressed caution about the statistics, noting that last year's "record low" figures were later revised upwards to show an increase, and highlighted the rise in sexual and violent crimes.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, which was the first Premier League loss for the Black Cats this season. Dan Gosling scored for Bournemouth, but they couldn't find an equalizer after going down to a 2-1 deficit. Eddie Howe, the Bournemouth manager, said that the team's lack of scoring isn't due to a lack of confidence, as they had scored six goals against Hull City in a previous match. He also noted that despite creating chances, they hadn't scored in the last two games. Bournemouth had numerous chances to win the game, but were unable to capitalize, even after Sunderland was reduced to 10 men following Steven Pienaar's dismissal. Howe emphasized that the team needs to move on from this loss and focus on future games.

The Australian Prime Minister, Tony Abbott, has reiterated his stance that the only way to prevent people dying at sea is to "stop the boats". Australia's policy of detaining migrants and sending them to offshore processing camps has been described by the New York Times as "brutal" and "inhumane". The newspaper criticized the policy as "dubious in legality" and at odds with Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. Mr Abbott defended his policy, saying it has stopped illegal boats and prevented deaths. He also sparked controversy by comparing the Islamic State group to the Nazis, saying IS was worse because they boast about their evil acts. Australian Jewish groups criticized the comparison, saying there was a fundamental difference between the two. Mr Abbott later clarified that he was not ranking evils, but stood by his comments.

The US has suspended talks with Russia over Syria, blaming Moscow and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians in Aleppo. The US warned it would halt the talks unless Russia stopped bombing Aleppo. Russia regrets the US move, accusing it of shifting the blame for the collapse of last month's truce. Aleppo, Syria's largest city, has come under heavy aerial bombardment since the ceasefire ended two weeks ago. The main trauma hospital in the rebel-held eastern part of the city was hit in an air strike for the third time in a week. Hundreds of people, including children, have died since government forces launched an offensive to take full control of Aleppo. Some 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo. The US said Russia failed to live up to its commitments and was either unwilling or unable to ensure Syrian regime adherence to the arrangements. The US also accused Russia and Syrian troops of targeting critical infrastructure such as hospitals and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians. Russia denies involvement in the deadly aid convoy strike and says the incident was caused by fire on the ground, not an air strike. In response, Russia said the US failed to fulfil the key condition of the agreement to improve the humanitarian condition around Aleppo and was trying to shift responsibility onto others. The two sides will keep talking about counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.

The passage discusses a report by think tank Policy Exchange that suggests selling high value social homes when they become vacant could raise £4.5bn a year. This money could be used to build 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes, creating the largest social house building programme since the 1970s. The report argues that social housing would still exist in expensive areas, but there would be less of it. The government's Downing Street backs the report, stating that councils should use their social housing stock efficiently and selling high-value housing to invest in more social housing is something they should consider. The Labour party, however, criticizes the proposal, saying it would drive out hard-working families on low wages from whole neighbourhoods and break up mixed communities. Shadow housing minister Jack Dromey suggests using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes instead. The report states that expensive social housing accounts for 21.8% of the total social housing stock in the UK, and about 3.5% of the total stock becomes vacant each year. The government could sell a total of 28,500 properties each year, raising £4.5bn after paying off the debt. Critics argue that such a move would push the least well-off out of expensive streets, creating segregated communities. Housing Minister Grant Shapps defends the government's position, stating that they have introduced reforms to get Britain building and reduce social housing waiting lists.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, where there is a measles outbreak. The examination could not confirm if measles was the main cause of his death. An inquest will be opened and adjourned to allow further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have been hospitalized. Mr Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash after being discharged. He visited an out-of-hours GP with a rash from head to foot, but not on his arms, and was found dead the next day. Public Health Wales confirmed a measles diagnosis but further tests are needed to determine the cause of death. The family is unsure how he contracted measles as no close family member has it, including his vaccinated daughter.

Vincent Hudson, aged 54, from Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under 16. The alleged attack was reported to have occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

The match between Gateshead and Guiseley ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored after a pass from James Hurst. Gateshead's Liam Hogan made a crucial block on Jordan Preston's shot. Guiseley's keeper Jonny Maxted saved a shot from Wesley York just before halftime. In the second half, Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute when York scored after a slip by Guiseley's Derek Asamoah. There were several substitutions in the second half, including Michael Rankine, Adam Boyes, Luke Hannant, and Derek Asamoah coming on. The match report was provided by the Press Association.

Bristol Sport Ltd, which owns Bristol City Football Club, plans to replace two stands to increase the stadium's capacity. This plan is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed due to a town green application. The redevelopment was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Steve Lansdown, the majority shareholder, confirmed that work will begin if there is no judicial review by March. The club will start the redevelopment in May if they get through the six-week judicial review period without any issues.

Cuadrilla, the company conducting shale gas drilling tests in Lancashire, has suspended its operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor. This is the second such tremor in two months, with the British Geological Survey (BGS) stating that the April quake, also near Poulton-le-Fylde, shared a similar location and mechanism with the recent one. The BGS monitors fracking as a precaution, noting that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes. Cuadrilla will analyze data from the BGS before deciding whether to resume drilling. The process of fracking involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas using either hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions. Environmental concerns include shale gas contaminating drinking water, as seen in the US, but the Commons energy select committee has called for support of the process in the UK, arguing that environmental problems can be overcome with tight regulation and good industry practice.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud. He was accused of using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes to collect money, giving the impression he was fundraising for the charity. However, he was cleared of two other counts of fraud. Carpenter, who has played in the city centre for over 30 years, claimed he was simply busking and had permission to display the banner as a tribute to the victims. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, Kenneth Derbyshire, confirmed he had given Carpenter permission to design and display the banner but had made it clear it was not to be used for fundraising. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0. Grant Ward scored the first goal with a scuffed shot, and Luke Varney scored the second after a clearance error by QPR keeper Alex Smithies. Tom Lawrence completed the scoring with a calm finish. Ipswich had several other chances to score, with Christophe Berra and Cole Skuse both missing opportunities. QPR rarely threatened, and Sandro's late header hit the post. The win lifted Ipswich to 14th in the Championship, while QPR dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy was pleased with the performance, while QPR manager Ian Holloway was disappointed with his team's lack of mental toughness.

Wells, 23, had a good T20 Blast season, scoring 373 runs at 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. He believes the club is improving and the coaches are creating an environment of elite performance, which motivates the players.

The Reds, who are fifth in National Two South, won 29-12 against Chinnor, with their front row and front five making a significant number of tackles. Coach Churcher believes this strong defensive effort was key to their success. He also stated that the team still has room for improvement and must build on their recent performance to avoid it being a waste of time. The Reds have seven games left against teams below them in the table, as well as a game against league leaders Old Elthamians.

The police arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town. Nazrul, a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. This arrest is the sixth in the case, with five others already arrested and two suspects still untraced. The incident led to widespread outrage in India and street protests in various cities. Police acted on a tip off that Nazu was returning to Kolkata from Bangladesh. Milon Sarkar, described as the leader of the gang, was arrested in May, but his role in the case is not yet clear. During the attack, the convent school was robbed and ransacked, and the nun was raped in the convent itself.

The interactive video may not work on older browsers and provides an overview of why we change what we buy. Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, discusses factors like the arrival of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports that have influenced the items on sale and consumer preferences in the UK. The video also explores how ownership and ranking of major UK brands are changing. For non-interactive content, additional information is available on the ownership of Chinese brands, tips on freezing food, and an annual survey ranking the top 20 consumer brands in the UK.

Two incidents have occurred where individuals were tricked into giving money to scammers. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was deceived by someone claiming to be from BT. In the second incident, a woman in Stranraer lost money to a caller who said he was from BT technical support. The scammer gained remote access to her computer and took the money. Both incidents happened within a week of each other, with the first on 15 September and the second a week later. The scammer claimed there were problems with the victim's internet. The police advise people to be cautious when answering cold calls from individuals seeking remote access to their computers to fix alleged faults. They stress that people should never give out banking details or account numbers over the phone, as legitimate banks and reputable businesses do not ask for this information.

Duffy, aged 37, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone Rovers, a third-placed Championship team, after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse and in the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Mark Campbell, the chairman of Featherstone, praised Duffy's coaching abilities and his work at Swinton despite difficult circumstances. Duffy has been replaced by Stuart Littler as assistant coach at Swinton. Duffy played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during his 16-year playing career.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. The rider had head injuries and was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand. She was treated and then flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

The UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU) decided to allocate a radio frequency for global flight tracking at a conference in Geneva. This decision was made in response to the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014, which highlighted the weaknesses of the current tracking system that relies on ground-based radars and leaves 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The new system will enable satellites to receive transmissions from aircraft, known as automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B), which are currently only sent to other aircraft and ground stations. This will allow real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world. The ITU's decision will help meet the International Civil Aviation Organisation's (ICAO) deadline of November 2016 for adopting new tracking guidelines, which include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found at age 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. The FBI received a tip after Julian had trouble applying for college. The agency worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery. Bobby Hernandez, 53, has been arrested and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. He is charged with kidnapping and tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Authorities suspected Bobby Hernandez was the culprit around the time of the boy's disappearance in 2002 when he said he was taking Julian to pre-school but then fled.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street after a blaze on 2 March. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, according to the fire service. The Environment Agency revoked the environmental permit for the site, which is run by Asset and Land Group. The firm has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, proposed two bills linked to the situation in Ukraine. The first bill would allow Russia to annex parts of a neighboring state if a referendum or plea from the territory's leaders is made, bypassing the need for a treaty with the state. This is in response to the crisis in Crimea, where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong, and many people already hold Russian passports. The second bill would speed up the process for Ukrainians to obtain Russian passports, removing the need for a state tax, previous residence in Russia, sufficient funds, and renouncing Ukrainian citizenship. The justification for the bill is to support Russian-speaking Ukrainians facing a "brown threat," a reference to World War II fascists. The fast-track passport process was announced in Sevastopol by A Just Russia leader Sergei Mironov. Russian MPs, including celebrities like Irina Rodnina, Valentina Tereshkova, and Nikolai Valuev, have also gone to Crimea.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, including 182 grands prix wins and multiple world championships, is currently struggling to achieve their past glory. The team's decline began in 2013, attributed to poor chassis design despite having the best engine. Currently, the team's performance issues stem from the Honda power-unit, despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and an unnamed driver, in their lineup. McLaren's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, with periods of success followed by downturns. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998, and they faced scandals in 2007 and 2009. Ron Dennis, the team's long-time leader, has returned to try to restore McLaren's success. The team believes they are on the path to recovery, with a strong car and hopes for a better Honda engine next year. However, their current goal is to secure a respectable grid position and points, a far cry from their dominant past. The team's future success is crucial for Alonso's career and the reputation of the McLaren name.

Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, was found injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January. He was shot in the head and chest and later died in hospital. Three men aged 29 and 32 have been arrested and are being questioned. Baker had left Phoenix Gym at the market shortly before the shooting and was getting into his car when it happened. Detectives believe the suspects had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that left the scene at speed. They are also looking for people seen on CCTV near the meat market who have not yet come forward.

The passage discusses five ways to enjoy Christmas online. First, Everyday Church Online offers virtual services with a chat room, attracting people from 61 countries. Second, Guardians of Ancora is a free fantasy game for children that incorporates Bible stories. Third, there are charming nativity videos, like The Digital Story of Nativity, which creatively tells the Christmas story through social media. Fourth, the Churches Advertising Network created a modern nativity video, though it was rejected by cinemas for being too religious. Lastly, Next Manga has created the Manga Messiah, a nativity story in Manga form, available in 33 languages and distributed to refugees. Social media is also used by churches to connect with their communities. The passage suggests Jesus would be on Twitter, given his communication skills.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land for a motorsport circuit. Supporters, including Blaenau Gwent council, have offered around 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. Experts have conflicting views on whether the circuit would harm habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales stated it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value, but they are not opposing the development overall. An ecology report by the developers claims there would be a "net gain" in biodiversity due to plans to enhance other habitats nearby. However, the Gwent Wildlife Trust argued against this claim. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, and Welsh government ministers will have the final say on whether the plans can proceed.

The passage reports that Chechen Muslim clerics were offended by a newspaper's report about the persecution of gay men in Chechnya. The clerics' resolution was interpreted by Novaya Gazeta as a call for reprisals against journalists. The newspaper insists it is doing its professional duty and urges the Russian authorities to prevent any incitement of hatred against journalists. The report on 1 April said more than 100 people were detained and at least three killed in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report and said detainees were tortured. Chechnya's authoritarian leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations. The Chechens' spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, said "there will be retribution" for the alleged slander. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor Dmitry Muratov said the paper would continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The passage also mentions previous murders of journalists who investigated crimes in Chechnya, but the full details of those cases remain unclear. The LGBT Network is helping people flee Chechnya and accuses the Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses. If Russia fails to prosecute anyone, the Network says it will file a case at the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing are involved in a housing scheme for single homeless men in London. Investing Solutions, a letting agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, work together to find housing for these men. The charity refers clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. The agency makes money by charging housing benefit for each person housed in a property, rather than the property itself, leading to higher benefit payouts than the rent paid to the property's landlord. Both organizations are based in the same building, a storage unit in south London. The relationship between the charity and the letting agency has been criticized by a homeless group as "a new low". Records show that Investing Solutions was set up in 2002 by Samir Patel, who later set up Fresh Start Housing in 2010. The charity's stated goal is to help ex-offenders and reduce poverty, sickness, and distress. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making the venture profitable. In one example, the company was claiming £2,114 per month in housing benefit for two tenants, while the property owner received £1,150 per month. The agency focuses on housing single homeless men over the age of 35, despite legislation allowing for private accommodation for this age group. Tenants have reported unsuitable living conditions, including lack of heating, hot water, rats, and damp. One tenant, Nigel McCann, described having to remove 28 bags of rubbish from a house to make it habitable. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions more than £2.1m over the past two years. The council has a team to ensure the private rented sector is safe, secure, and affordable. Matt Downie, of homeless charity Crisis, criticized the relationship between the charity and the letting agency. Samir Patel defended Fresh Start Housing as an independent charity with its own board of trustees and stated that the majority of rents are passed to private landlords. Fresh Start Housing has housed 788 homeless people since its founding and 222 in the last 12 months. The Department for Communities and Local Government stated that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money through dedicated investigations and inspections.

Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon scored 13 points for Great Britain in a game against the Netherlands. GB led for most of the first three quarters but were overtaken in the last 10 minutes. The Netherlands won the game 77-73. GB now begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary in midweek. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the importance of completing every play and maintaining intensity on both ends of the floor. He was pleased with Ben Gordon's performance, who had missed out on a place for the London 2012 Olympics but joined the team for this game.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) received a waiver from Conor McGregor, hours before the deadline, to use lighter 8oz gloves for his fight against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, will debate the matter on August 16th. The rules state that 10oz gloves are used from 135lbs upwards, but bouts between 135lbs and 147lbs can use 8oz gloves if waivers are signed and the NAC feels the move is justified. The NAC's executive director Bob Bennett stated that even if both fighters agree, the health and safety of the fighters is the top priority. Conor McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, welcomed the idea of using lighter gloves. The NAC studied McGregor's background and decided there were several reasons to approve the fight, including his performance against Nate Diaz. McGregor has been training with a boxing referee, Joe Cortez, to familiarize himself with boxing rules.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith worked for the Dundee-based Sunday Post, which is closing its London office on Friday. Fleet Street was once the heart of British journalism, with nearly every national newspaper having offices within a half-mile radius. The first British daily newspaper was published in Fleet Street in 1702. The area was famous for its many bars and pubs, and was known as the "Street of Shame." The departure of the last two journalists from Fleet Street marks the end of an era. The decline of Fleet Street began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his newspapers to Wapping, leading to a year-long dispute with unions. The move to computerised printing technology and other parts of London contributed to the decline. Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith reflect on the history and atmosphere of Fleet Street, with Sherriff recalling his first day in a smoke-filled newsroom and Smith sharing a story about a tour guide who mistakenly announced the end of journalism in Fleet Street. Robin Esser, a former editor, highlights the importance of Fleet Street as a source of information before the rise of television and social media. Liz Hodgkinson, who worked in Fleet Street in the 70s and 80s, describes the heavy drinking culture and the challenges faced by women in the industry. The last two journalists leaving Fleet Street mark the end of an era, with the area now transformed into a hub for other businesses.

The Harry Potter author, J.K. Rowling, has commented on the abusive messages she has received on Twitter. She stated that these comments remind her of the number of decent people in the world. Rowling had previously expressed that her "personal line" had been crossed by some of these abusive comments. She believes in standing up to bullies. Last year, Rowling faced criticism for donating Â£1m to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum. In 2008, she donated the same amount to the Labour party. Recently, she was called "a traitor" for her political views and blocked abusive Twitter users who she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Rowling emphasized that she felt no responsibility to protect the image of any political party by hushing up such behavior. She also mentioned that she had interacted positively with other SNP supporters, finding common political ground. In response to a suggestion that her books should be burned, Rowling joked about bringing marshmallows. The SNP won 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland in the recent election, making it the third largest party in the UK.

The study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off children. Living in poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The research, part of the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime, tracked 4,300 young people since 1998. It found that a history of trouble with the police was the strongest predictor of whether a young person was not in education, employment, or training by the age of 18. Poorer young people were five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts. The study also showed that household poverty increased the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors were considered. Boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, but girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from affluent households to be involved in violent crime. The findings suggest a destructive cycle where poverty increases the risk of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system can inadvertently reproduce conditions that foster violence. The study also found that the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefited areas with the most chronic rates of crime, with half of the communities with the highest crime rates found in the top 20% of areas with the highest levels of chronic health problems and a third in the top 20% of areas with the highest levels of unemployment. The Scottish government has stated that Scotland is becoming a safer place to live, with recorded crime at a 41-year low, and they are tackling poverty and inequalities through various initiatives.

Karl Haugh was stabbed in a laneway in Kilkee's Marian estate early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh, 25, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and remanded in custody until 14 August. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged that Mr Walsh was one of three people who entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr Haugh, and a fight ensued involving weapons, during which Mr Haugh was stabbed in the back. Gardaí recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, and Mr Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. The court heard there was tension in the area due to the killing.

The Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted a false statement about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The tweet suggested that Mr Elliott had harassed and shot people during his service. The High Court was informed that the tweet was deleted within an hour of being posted. Mr Elliott has a clear Ministry of Defence (MoD) record. He was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Mr Flanagan has been ordered to apologize and state that his tweet was untrue and without foundation. The court has reserved judgement on compensation. Mr Flanagan's insurance firm has refused to cover him for this case, and he is challenging this decision in a separate court action. Tom Elliott expressed disappointment at the length of time it took to resolve the issue but was pleased with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters due to high demand. The company, established in 1874 and bought by Benny Hartop last year, has seen a boost in sales of its Hawick Knitwear-branded range since its January launch. In addition to the new range, the firm has experienced growth in its business of supplying private labels. Hawick Knitwear sells in various European countries, including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Production has increased from 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters per week to meet demand. Managing director Benny Hartop attributes this success to the dedicated staff and expects it to continue.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, who was driving a VW Golf, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. He admits hitting Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse for his actions, stating he had "turned her world upside down." The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose" aimed at preparing for the threat posed by Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat, U33, acting as an enemy submarine. The exercise highlights a gap in Britain's defences, particularly the lack of long-range maritime patrol aircraft, which used to be provided by the Nimrod. The absence of these aircraft means Britain has to rely on allies for surveillance when Russian submarines are reported near UK waters. The exercise is a response to increased Russian submarine activity in the region and serves as a reminder of the importance of anti-submarine warfare capabilities. The passage also mentions the introduction of underwater drones and the technological advancements of Russian submarines, which are considered the "quietest and most challenging adversary in the world." The exercise underscores the need for NATO members to strengthen their defences and for Britain to address its maritime patrol aircraft gap in the upcoming defence and security review.

The passage describes the dire situation in South Sudan, where violence has led to a mass exodus of people fleeing to neighboring Uganda. Since July, 340,000 people have fled South Sudan into Uganda, surpassing the number of refugees from Syria this year. The UN is concerned that the situation may amount to genocide and ethnic cleansing. The violence has spread to previously peaceful areas, such as the southern Equatoria states, and is targeting civilians along ethnic lines. People are fleeing due to killings, rape, and the targeting of civilians, with stories from refugees describing brutal violence. The Dinka tribe is mentioned as targeting other ethnic groups, including the Equatorians and the Nuer. Refugees have walked for days to reach safety, with many experiencing or witnessing horrific acts of violence. Uganda has been accommodating refugees, providing them with land and aid to start new lives. However, the influx is becoming a challenge, with water supply being a major concern. The UNHCR calls for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence. The passage also highlights the resilience of the refugees, particularly the children, who are trying to rebuild their lives despite the trauma they have experienced.

McKenzie, aged 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle on November 12 at York Hall for the English super-middleweight championship. McKenzie began his professional boxing career in 2013 after retiring from football two years earlier. He has a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The money for Bridgwater Community Hospital is part of a £330m investment for new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and in need of replacement due to poor conditions. The total cost of the project is £33m, with the remaining balance to be paid by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is expected to improve patient well-being and healthcare delivery. Work is underway to replace three out of Somerset's 13 community hospitals, and the new Bridgwater hospital is planned to be completed by autumn 2014, pending planning permission.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, Sheffield. He was either in or near a black Mercedes car when the shooting occurred. The victim was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. The shooting happened close to the time of a family celebration, and relatives tried to help him after hearing the shot. There have been several shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, but this incident is unusual for the Upperthorpe area. Previous shootings have been in the north of the city.

The passage describes the activities of various hacker groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have hacked into Russian servers and shared the data with Ukraine's security service. They use DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and target separatist funding. They also hijack CCTV cameras and printers to monitor rebel movements and spread pro-Ukrainian messages. On the other side, Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, hacks Ukrainian government websites and claims to have retrieved confidential documents from US Vice President Joe Biden's team. They also disrupt electronic billboards and claim to have hacked electronic vote-counting systems. Another group, Anonymous International, leaks documents from the Kremlin and has published material related to Ukraine, including a letter from a Russian fighter suggesting lack of local support for separatists. The activities of these groups highlight the use of cyber warfare in the conflict, with both sides attempting to gain an advantage through hacking and information warfare.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, spoke of Scotland's diversity and strength, and expressed his belief that the country was not divided but had a consensus on greater responsibility for its governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. Salmond concluded his speech with a heartfelt goodbye, emphasizing the honor of serving in the parliament and wishing good luck to those standing in the forthcoming election. Presiding officer Marwick thanked Salmond for his service, while Mr McNeil, who is also stepping down, warned that Holyrood needs to learn from Westminster, particularly in terms of accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, another retiring MSP, joked about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira will gather experiences from pensioners and their loved ones about residential care to inform her review. The review aims to improve the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She will use the evidence to make recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The commissioner will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. She will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but is disappointed that no provider expert is on the main advisory panel. They believe this misses an opportunity for partnership and full engagement from the sector.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016. Despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m, the company saw growth in international sales, particularly in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, catering to farming and rural communities. The company acknowledges the challenging times in agriculture but remains confident in its ability to handle the potential impacts of Brexit.

The body of a man in his 70s was found at a house in Little Gaddesden, Hertfordshire. A man in his 80s was also taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as a murder and are looking for Ian John McLoughlin, aged 55, also known as Ian John Baker. He is described as white, about 6ft tall, with greying hair, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked shirt. Anyone with information should contact the police or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, the second in command at the IMF, stated that the global economy is weakening. The IMF anticipates downgrading its global growth forecast from 3.4% due to a weakening baseline. This comes after China reported weaker-than-expected trade figures, with exports plunging by a quarter from a year ago. The situation is delicate and has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that rely on China's growth. The IMF will release its updated economic predictions in April.

The council leader Dave Stewart announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July to acknowledge the problems with the new ferry. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has experienced several issues since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, running aground, and being suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Cars have also been damaged getting on and off the ferry. Local businesses have suffered due to the ferry's problems, and the council is considering compensation for them. The council's transport councillor Ian Ward stated that the ferry's issues are expected teething problems with a prototype and that the council has taken steps to resolve the problems, such as manufacturing ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage. Groundings have been attributed to seamanship issues, which have been resolved.

A crash involving several vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at about 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while officers investigated the scene.

Matching Models in London is an international temp agency that seeks "beautiful and talented people". They advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, including a "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup". The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) criticized the ad as "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women". The EHRC's chief executive, Rebecca Hilsenrath, stated they would ask Matching Models to clarify their hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners described the ads as outdated, reminiscent of the 1970s. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended their practices, stating that looks are important to their clients. Another job ad asked for a "sexy female driver" to drive a Porsche Cayenne for a high-earning businessman. Employment lawyer James Lynas called the ad "clearly unlawful" and stated that anyone could complain to the EHRC. The agency's website states that they understand the importance of having attractive employees, but the EHRC's Hilsenrath criticized this stance, emphasizing that first impressions should not be based on physical appearance. Under the 2010 Equality Act, it is illegal to discriminate based on various personal characteristics, including physical appearance. Matching Models has clients like MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods. Nathalie Jansen defended their practices, citing specific client requests, such as an older gentleman wanting a personal assistant to fit a specific outfit designed by Christian Dior, and an Indian businessman wanting blonde, blue-eyed, Greek women to work on his plane. The agency has hired 5,000 people worldwide, with some clients requesting specific physical attributes.

The shooting happened at a hostel connected to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged shooter, Mahesh, worked as an office assistant at the school. Gun crimes at schools and colleges in India are uncommon. Mahesh is accused of shooting and killing 18-year-old Gautami and severely injuring another student, Sirisha. He was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. India has strict gun control laws, but firearms are used in many feuds. In 2007, a schoolboy was killed by fellow students near Delhi.

The advocacy group GLAAD analyzed shows from June 2016 to May 2017 and found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to sixteen this year. However, GLAAD criticized the fact that more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith from Orange is the New Black and Wentworth, respectively. The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD's Where We Are on TV study based its findings on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already being shown or for which casting had been confirmed. GLAAD's president Sarah Kate Ellis said it was "heartening to see progress being made" but emphasized that numbers are "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided not to seek re-election. This decision comes before a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to face opposition. The BBC reported that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC, when Mr Mackintosh was the council leader, to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, has gone missing. The loan is now subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. Mr Mackintosh has denied any wrongdoing. He stated that it has been a huge honour to be the MP since 2015, but he now feels it is the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was fired after he shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in April 2017. The incident occurred when police responded to reports of underage drinking at a party in Balch Springs, a suburb of Dallas. Oliver fired his rifle into a car full of teenagers as they left the party, initially claiming the car was reversing aggressively towards him. However, video footage showed the car was driving away from him. Oliver was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for endangering the other four teenagers in the car, including two of Jordan Edwards' brothers. The district attorney stated that justice is proceeding effectively and thoroughly. If convicted, Oliver faces 5 to 99 years in prison. This would be the first conviction of a police officer for murder in Dallas County since 1973. The trial date has not been set, and Oliver is currently free on bail. The lawyer for the Edwards family remains cautious about the outcome, noting the rarity of such convictions in Texas.

Melania Trump and her son Barron will not move to the White House immediately after Donald Trump's inauguration. The transition team has stated that this decision is due to Barron's school schedule. This decision has sparked criticism on social media, with some users expressing disappointment that the First Family will not reside in the White House as a symbol of the country. However, there are historical precedents for this situation. For example, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. Additionally, other First Ladies have prioritized their children's schooling, such as Frances Folsom Cleveland and Dolley Madison. Melania Trump has indicated that Barron's schooling is her top priority, suggesting she may not take on a full-time role as First Lady. The role of the First Lady is ceremonial, involving hosting and supporting causes. In recent years, First Ladies have taken on more active public roles, such as Michelle Obama's Let Girls Learn initiative. Melania Trump has expressed interest in tackling cyberbullying. There is precedent for other family members taking on some of the First Lady's duties, such as Chelsea Clinton during her mother's political career. The White House can be a normal family home, with children doing homework and having sleepovers, despite the public nature of the role.

The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is investigating the initial police response to a call from a 72-year-old man who was later found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness. The investigation was instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS). A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the COPFS in due course. Police Scotland is fully engaging with the investigation and awaits its findings.

A yellow warning of wind was issued, with gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) expected locally, particularly to the west of the mountains. The easterly direction of the wind was noted as unusual and potentially increasing its impact. The warning affected Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea was likely. A tree fell due to the gusts overnight in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road. The road was expected to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up work.

The Giants opened the game with a short-handed goal by player-coach Derrick Walser, but the Panthers tied the game with a goal by Jeff Dimmen. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal to give the Giants a 2-1 lead, which was then equalized by Andy Bohmbach. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored to make it 4-2 for the Giants, but David Ling scored a goal for Nottingham. The Giants and Panthers will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the grid and faced multiple challenges during the Chinese Grand Prix, including a broken front wing on the first lap and five pit stops. He now trails championship leader Nico Rosberg by 36 points. Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first-lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to finish fifth. The race was marked by numerous incidents on the first lap, leading to the deployment of the safety car. Red Bull's Daniel Ricciardo led initially but suffered a puncture, allowing Rosberg to take control and win the race. Hamilton's damaged car affected his ability to recover positions, and Mercedes team boss Toto Wolff confirmed the car had lost significant aerodynamic performance due to the front wing damage. Hamilton remains confident about his championship chances, but no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to claim the World Championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit. He did this to advance discussion about a topic that is ignored in German football. His former team-mates and other prominent figures in German football praised his decision. They called it courageous and an important step. Leading figures in German football administration also supported Hitzlsperger. They saw his announcement as a huge and courageous step in the fight against homophobia. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football is a problem. The last German footballer to come out was Marcus Urban in 2007. Hitzlsperger's decision was praised by German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, who said it's good that he spoke about something important to him. Openly gay German politician Volker Beck hoped Hitzlsperger's announcement would encourage others to come out. Zwanziger, the former president of the German Football Association, is optimistic that Hitzlsperger's announcement will lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Sidwell, 34, has played 32 Championship matches for Brighton this season, helping them secure promotion to the Premier League. His current contract ends after this season, but he hopes to sign a new deal. He believes he has performed well enough to earn a place in the Premier League team next season. Sidwell has played for several Premier League clubs in the past and is confident he can contribute at that level again. Brighton are currently leading the Championship and are aiming to win the league title in the final two matches.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Jamille Matt scored from a Nathan Delfouneso assist. Colchester equalized from a Kurtis Guthrie goal from a corner after 17 minutes. Blackpool's Sam Slocombe made several key saves, including denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi. Guthrie had a chance to score from two yards but hit the bar. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a chance to win the game from a corner. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

Reid, a 29-year-old, played 37 games for Coventry City last season as they were relegated from League One. He has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid could make his debut for Colchester United in the EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester lost their first game of the season 3-1 against Accrington.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising funds to build a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum to honor police officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff. The initiative gained greater emphasis following the murder of PC Keith Palmer in an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March. The trust needs £1.5m for the construction, with the government contributing £1m. The memorial will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, each representing a fallen officer, and will be given to their families. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United won 1-0 at Sunderland and remain 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League. The team has 25 wins from 30 matches, a record Ferguson says tells you a lot about the club. The focus is on winning the next game, which is the derby against Manchester City with a 15-point headstart. United have eight matches left to better Chelsea's record 95-point haul from 2005. There were injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea suffered a knock. Changes will be made for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, with players like Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley returning but potentially needing rest. Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez are available for selection, and Rio Ferdinand was not taken to Sunderland. The team defended well in the second half against a determined Sunderland side.

Mr. Schmidt, Google's chairman, stated that Google paid the taxes that were legally required and that it was up to the government to change its tax system if it wanted companies to pay more taxes. Google paid Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. He emphasized that taxes are not optional and that Google would comply with any changes in the UK tax laws. The head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, Margaret Hodge, suggested a new committee should be established to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Mr. Schmidt has called for a debate on international tax reform and believes that companies should pay taxes in the country where they conduct economic activity and take risks, rather than where products are consumed. He also believes that politicians should set the rules and that companies should abide by the law as it stands.

The NHS is being urged to reduce its spending on agency staff by £1bn by the end of the financial year. Last year, the NHS spent £3.6bn on agency staff. A cap was introduced in October, which has so far saved £600m. The cap means hospitals should not pay more than 55% above normal shift rates for agency staff, including doctors and nurses, but excluding senior managers. The progress made so far is promising, but the NHS is still short of its target. The agency bill is falling, but it is unclear if spending on other parts of the pay bill has increased. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending later this year. They will also collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust. There have been instances of hospitals being quoted double the rates for doctors, which is against the cap. NHS Improvement's chief executive, Jim Mackey, emphasized that the NHS cannot afford to keep spending on expensive agency staff and that more needs to be done.

The Longford Town Centre was intended to be a commercial hub but now serves as a symbol of Ireland's economic downturn. Local businesses have suffered, with one men's clothing shop experiencing a 30% drop in sales and having to lay off staff. However, there are signs of improvement as the shop has diversified its offerings. Fianna FÃ¡il criticizes the government's handling of the midlands' economy, arguing that money spent on water meters should be used for broadband improvement. The Industrial Development Authority has not brought potential clients to Longford in four years, according to Fianna FÃ¡il. The government points to a planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon as a positive step, which could create 1,000 jobs. However, the project still needs planning permission. The local Fine Gael TD believes the midlands has great tourism potential. Traders like Matt O'Brien believe more could be done to boost local business, such as removing parking charges. While there are signs of economic recovery in the midlands, more efforts are needed to support local businesses.

The competition ends on 29 May. Eight teams are participating, playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Scores, fixtures, and results can be found on BBC Sport. The leading run-scorer is Warner with 294 runs, followed by Kohli with 267 and De Villiers with 249. Warner and De Villiers have hit the most sixes, with 12 each, and Kohli has hit 8. The highest score in an innings is 108 by De Kock, 90* by Warner, and 90* by Gambhir. Four current or former England players are involved: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The schedule includes dates and times for each match, starting on 25 April and ending on 29 May with the final.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported an increase of 200 million plastic carrier bags since 2013. Plastic bags are a major environmental issue because they are not easily recyclable and often end up in landfills or rivers. To address this problem, starting in October, people in England will have to pay 5p for each plastic bag in a bid to encourage reuse. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar charges are already in place, have seen a decrease in the number of bags used. The hope is that the new charge in England will reduce the number of bags thrown away, benefiting the environment.

A school roof was ripped off in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, Gwynedd, and hundreds of homes experienced power cuts due to high winds in Wales. A yellow 'be aware' warning for wind was in place until midnight on Friday. The winds caused train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and power cuts for hundreds of homes. The highest gusts of wind were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries cancelled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin due to adverse weather conditions. Arriva Trains Wales warned of possible delays on services between Llandudno Junction to Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to expected high winds. Restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge were lifted as winds eased into Friday evening. A festive event, Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip, was postponed to Tuesday, 27 December due to the blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend.

The actor Michael B. Jordan is "super excited" to work on the Black Panther film. He will be reuniting with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. He did not specify his role in the film. He is looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Nyong'o previously won an Oscar for 12 Years a Slave and played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The Black Panther film is set to be released in February 2018. Jordan previously starred in the Fantastic Four reboot, which was not successful.

The theatre, founded in 1875, will be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music after renovations. The BBC studios at the eastern end of the Palace will also be repaired and refurbished. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m and Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m towards the £26.6m project. The entire east wing will be refurbished, and the glazed east court will become a public space for exhibitions. The theatre has much of its original decor and stage machinery intact, having been unused for decades. The Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the final £1m by summer 2017. If successful, the theatre is expected to reopen in 2018, transforming Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, won 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the squad at two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, scoring his first and only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. He has decided to retire from international football, citing common sense as the reason for his decision, and wishes the team success in the future.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a fire that destroyed their house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador. Her son David, who was awake due to a FaceTime call with his father, alerted them to the fire. The fire started in the wood stove from rubbish that Marcy had burned, which she had done many times before. The fire alarm did not go off. The family lost their pets in the fire. The community has provided support with donations of clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Marcy credits David for saving their lives and is very proud of him.

The energy drinks company was considering a £200m offer for West Ham United, a Premier League club. David Sullivan and David Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for £105m and now own more than 85% of the club. Since moving to the London Stadium in August, West Ham have also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan stated that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intend for their ownership to pass on to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards were held in Los Angeles, with 22 Jump Street star Jillian Bell noting it was not the Oscars. The ceremony featured fan-voted awards like best kiss and best shirtless performance, which Zac Efron won. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking home best movie, best female performance for Shailene Woodley, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with Ansel Elgort. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, dedicating his award to Chris Kyle. Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne were also winners. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award, saying he does it all for his kids. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, with his Avengers co-stars joining him on stage. The show also featured previews of upcoming films like Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron.

The Dons loaned Smith, 21, to United in July and he has five goals this season. Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for Aberdeen. St Mirren's boss Jack Ross considers Smith's acquisition as brilliant. Smith is a good, mature boy and will provide another attacking option for St Mirren. St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council will fill in 145 potholes each day over the next four months. The weather is now warm enough for their Jetpatcher machines to work. Extra staff will also repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

The incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland, in December 2016. Steve Innes, a rigging supervisor from Sunderland, and fellow Wood Group contractors discovered they had been exposed to alpha radiation while working on the platform. They were working on shutdown work with pipe equipment and were not wearing the proper personal protective equipment (PPE) because they were told the area was clear. The workers were informed about the radiation exposure two thirds of the way through their trip. A health and safety manager told them a reading had been taken the night before, and all work was stopped. The workers were told the levels of radiation might not cause them long-term harm, but they are undergoing ongoing tests. EnQuest stated that the level of exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but they advised the HSE of the matter at the time. EnQuest has taken additional precautionary steps to ensure personnel avoid exposure to naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM). Wood Group, the employer of the affected workers, stated that the health and safety of their employees is their top priority and that they fully supported a joint investigation with EnQuest. The union Unite believes the workers have been treated poorly and calls for openness and transparency about serious safety incidents. The HSE stated that the incident was not reportable under the current RIDDOR system and no separate report was made to them, so no investigation was carried out.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari sculpture for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer's manager later admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze sculpture. The sculpture was thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The ACM decided to return the item after discussions with the Indian government body, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI requested the return of the sculpture in May. Although there is no conclusive proof of the sculpture's theft, the ACM took into account the dealer's manager's confession of dealing in looted Indian antiquities. The ACM bought 30 objects from the same dealer, but none of the others are thought to be stolen. The museum plans to take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck near Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt in cities like Milan and Florence, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy is prone to earthquakes, and in 2009, a quake in L'Aquila killed almost 300 people. The recent quake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) with its epicentre in Garfagnana, and several aftershocks were felt. Phone lines were down and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution to check for damage. In 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted for providing a falsely reassuring statement about the risk of the L'Aquila earthquake.
Austin Grant from Sheffield has grown a banana plant in South Yorkshire, despite initial doubts about the climate. The fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar delayed the release of the PC version of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March. The delay is to ensure the game is polished and tested thoroughly. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version will offer improved graphics, including 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. Minimum specifications for running GTA V on PC have been published. The game became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever when it was released on consoles in 2013, generating $1bn in three days.

The 76-year-old artist, Jack Simpson, won the John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19). He was previously shortlisted in 1991 and has been on the longlist three other times. Squint (19) is a painting of a leper squint, a hole in medieval churches for undesirables to view services. The painting is about 7ft in height and was chosen for the competition due to its manageable size and relevance to Simpson's current work. The prize money of Â£25,000 will be used for art materials such as stretches, canvas, and high-quality paints. The painting was described by judge Ansel Krut as "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem" that reveals its depth and sympathy over time. The John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, who won the junior title in 1961, is now the prize's patron.

The offices of two Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked by four masked assailants. The attacks happened almost simultaneously, early Thursday morning. No casualties were reported, but windows in both buildings were shattered by gunfire. Firefighters quickly extinguished the blaze at Yeni Safak. The two papers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Police have cordoned off the area around the Yeni Safak building and are hunting the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. Last September, pro-government protesters attacked the offices of the daily Hurriyet, accusing the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

The 24-year-old player was under contract with the Stags but will join Grimsby Town on January 1st on a free transfer. He scored three goals in 23 appearances while on loan at Crawley. This is Marcus Bignot's first signing for Grimsby Town.

The passage discusses Arsene Wenger's comments on Gareth Southgate's performance as England manager and his own future. Wenger, who has been linked with the England job, says he is focused on his current role at Arsenal. He praises Southgate's experience and competency, and believes the England manager has the opportunity to prove his quality. Wenger also addresses speculation about Hector Bellerin's future, stating that the defender will be offered a new contract by Arsenal. Additionally, Wenger mentions that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are jointly investigating the incident. Fruehauf is cooperating with the investigation.

The Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had criticized the low wages, claiming some workers were paid less than Â£4 an hour. The new charter will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck, will now ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements will come into force early next month, subject to finalizing financial and regulatory details. Serco Northlink has been operating the Northern Isles contract since 2012, which includes three ferries and two cargo boats heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie died on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother. Mitchell and his mother Samantha, 57, also pleaded guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. The court heard that Mitchell and Mr Dickie had a confrontation outside the holiday park bar after getting "tanked up" on alcohol. Mitchell initially claimed Mr Dickie had pushed his mother and she had pushed back, but later admitted trying to push the couple apart, calling it a "tragic accident". Both Mitchell and his mother will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter, died last week at the age of 66 after a short battle with cancer. He was known for writing several hits for Michael Jackson, including "Thriller," "Off The Wall," and "Rock With You," as well as songs for Heatwave like "Boogie Nights," "Always & Forever," and "Groove Line." Temperton's talent was influenced by his father, who would put a transistor radio in his crib, exposing him to music from an early age. He started his career after leaving a job at a frozen food factory in Grimsby and joining the disco group Heatwave. His work with Quincy Jones on Michael Jackson's albums helped make Thriller the best-selling album in the US. Temperton won a Grammy Award and was nominated for Oscars. He believed in writing songs that he loved first and foremost. His death has been mourned by many in the music industry, including Chaka Khan, Nile Rodgers, and Mark Ronson. His family has requested privacy during this time.

A team of researchers from Swansea University, Exeter University, Reading University, and Brazilian universities have discovered ancient earthworks in the western Brazilian Amazon. The earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, are large geometrical "geoglyphs" that were concealed by rainforest until deforestation revealed more than 450 of them. The function of these sites is not well understood, but they are unlikely to be villages due to the lack of artifacts and their non-defensive layout. Instead, they are thought to have been used sporadically for ritual gatherings, similar to Stonehenge or Maya pyramids.

Dr. Neil Loader analyzed soil samples from the geoglyphs and found that they were built among taller vegetation, suggesting they were not visible above the forest canopy. This raises questions about their purpose. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems before European arrival, but rather had been influenced by humans who concentrated on economically valuable trees like palms, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. There is evidence that the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a legacy of these ancient agroforestry practices.

Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in the first round of the Shanghai Masters. He won the Japan Open the previous day and is close to entering the top 10. Kyrgios admitted he was tired and bored during the match, attributing this to his recent success in Japan and the travel involved. He also mentioned the long ride to the courts as a contributing factor to his fatigue. Last year at the same tournament, Kyrgios was fined for a foul-mouthed outburst.

Scientists and charities are calling for the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine to be given to boys as well as girls. They argue that this will protect them from head and neck cancers, which are increasing in number. HPV is sexually transmitted and the vaccine is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect them against cervical cancer. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision. Dr Mererid Evans, a consultant oncologist, has noticed a change in the demographics of those affected by head and neck cancers, with younger, non-smoking men being diagnosed. Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care urges the Welsh government to take a progressive step and vaccinate boys now. The vaccination programme for girls was rolled out in 2008 and has achieved an 85% vaccination rate in Wales. The Welsh government states that they will consider any proposed changes to the HPV vaccination programme after receiving the committee's recommendations.
