Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil, passed away after battling gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, a rare form of blood cancer. He was known for his positive attitude and documented his journey on social media, garnering over 28,000 Likes on his Facebook page, Jak's Journey. Jak's story touched many hearts, and he met several Rangers FC players and received support from various sports teams and celebrities. Despite his illness, he briefly attended his school prom, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. Jak's family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy at the prom. After learning that his cancer had spread and treatment was no longer an option, Jak and his family urged people to donate to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. Jak's life and fight against cancer inspired many, and fundraising efforts continue in his memory.

Egypt won the match 1-0 against Uganda with the goal coming in the 89th minute from Abdallah El Said, who was assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had an earlier goal disallowed for offside. The win means Egypt will play Ghana on Wednesday for top spot in Group D, while Uganda are out of the tournament for the first time since 1978. Ghana had earlier secured their place in the quarter-finals with a 1-0 victory over Mali. The match was played on a deteriorating pitch in Port-Gentil, and Egypt's veteran goalkeeper Essam El Hadary made an impressive clearing header to deny Salah in the first half. Egypt failed to break down Uganda's defense for long periods, and the match was mostly lifeless until the late goal.

Lancashire County Council has chosen a site on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to have two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The preferred location has good highway access and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The council will now start the process of acquiring the land. Skelmersdale's original railway station closed in 1956, and it is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station. The decision follows a comparative study of the sites and was made because the chosen location is large enough for future expansion. Skelmersdale was designated a new town on 9 October 1961.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, later handed himself in to the authorities. The woman underwent an emergency operation and was flown to a specialist clinic. She had been dragged by the neck through several streets. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear. Police have secured the area and are calling for witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School, the University of Warwick, and the University of Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to get one. The research analyzed 4,600 workers and compared full-time males with full-time females and part-time males with part-time females to eliminate any impact from part-time workers earning less. Men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study found no support for the "reticent female" theory, where women avoid asking for more money. Factors such as the size of the employer, industry, whether the workers were parents, and their qualifications were taken into account. The research was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, which is thought to be the only country to systematically record whether employees asked for a pay rise. The study's authors, including Prof Andrew Oswald and Dr Amanda Goodall, were surprised by the findings and suggested that there could be an element of pure discrimination against women. They also noted that younger women are negotiating their pay and conditions more successfully than older females, indicating a potential change in negotiating behavior.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable location. The two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively. The council has used money for ground investigations but has had to discount all identified sites due to issues such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants. After the two cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932. The council has not given up and is still exploring options.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, will offer an augmented reality app experience for visitors. The app will allow users to view online information, videos, and band interviews by interacting with signs and posters at the festival site. The festival runs from 19 to 22 July and features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The augmented reality feature will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere. Festival director Caroline Maclennan stated that the app will be updated leading up to and during the event, providing instant access to information and interviews, as well as ticket purchasing options.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He narrowly beat Thistlecrack in the race. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that Many Clouds suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The horse had no significant underlying health issues, and such incidents are rare among all disciplines of sport horses. The BHA is determined to understand the causes of these symptoms and prevent them in the future. Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past but had never collapsed before. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described Many Clouds as the "horse of a lifetime".

A 34-year-old person named Davina, formerly known as David Ayrton, was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in 2004. The incident occurred in a Portsmouth garage. Davina has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer. The judge, Ian Pearson, remanded Davina into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester, due to concerns about her being a risk to herself and potentially failing to attend future court proceedings. The judge also noted that the case was unusual and not easy. Protocols have been put in place for Davina's detention at the prison. The victim, who had only consumed a small amount of alcohol, clearly remembered the attack and shouted at Davina to stop. Davina changed her name in 2012 and spoke about her sexuality during the trial, stating she had not made any physical changes or taken any medication. The incident was reported to a care home worker by Davina in 2014. Sentencing is scheduled for March 4.

The Serbs, represented by Novak Djokovic, lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss came after Djokovic was defeated in the singles by Juan Martin del Potro the previous day. Djokovic, the world number one, had a surprising loss at Wimbledon in July to Sam Querrey. Despite this, he won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The Carrbridge chainsaw carving event will have more than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants use chainsaws exclusively to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Pete Bowsher, last year's winner from Moffat, will return to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb has been out due to a serious foot injury since September. He is close to returning and aims to be fit for the Six Nations in February. He has renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union. Webb has chosen to stay with Ospreys, his home region, to be in the best position to play for Wales. He is looking forward to getting back to playing rugby. Wales' Six Nations campaign starts on 7 February against Ireland in Dublin. Webb has 16 caps for Wales.

The incident began on Tuesday morning when US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near Sumas, Washington. The agents interrupted an attempt to smuggle a load of MDMA, or ecstasy, from Canada to San Francisco. One of the men fired a weapon at the agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately taken into custody. A search for the fugitive ensued, involving both Canadian and US police, and the fugitive, Nathan Hall, was arrested early on Wednesday morning in British Columbia. The backpacks contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy, and one backpack had a California driver's license with Nathan Hall's picture but another person's name. Kali Henifin, a woman from Bellingham, Washington, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested. They were allegedly planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco, with Lambert expecting to be paid $11,000. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The wooded area near the border is a well-known smuggling route for drugs and firearms, and such prosecutions are common in the area.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported that it counselled over 4,500 children in the past year for online abuse, a significant increase from about 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity believes the actual number of children suffering online abuse is much higher. Children as young as seven have been tormented, abused, and scared to go to school due to online trolls. Childline's president Dame Esther Rantzen stated that these figures should serve as a wake-up call, emphasizing that bullying does not stop at school gates and can follow children home, causing misery and humiliation. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children, as bullying does not stop on its own. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem. One young person who contacted Childline shared their experience of being told to kill themselves by online peers, highlighting the emotional distress caused by cyberbullying.

The Israeli government postponed a vote on building new homes in settlements in East Jerusalem following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. This move comes ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The postponement is an attempt to avoid further straining relations with Washington. The decision to abstain from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements infuriated Prime Minister Netanyahu. The resolution, which passed on Friday, calls for an end to settlement construction and states that settlements are illegal under international law. Israel disputes this and is particularly angry about the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem, which it sees as part of its capital. In response to the resolution, Israel took several diplomatic actions, including summoning ambassadors and recalling its own ambassadors. The postponement of the vote is seen as a strategic move to avoid political conflict during Kerry's upcoming speech.

The Queen's 90th birthday is being celebrated with various events, including a visit to a Royal Mail delivery office in Windsor and the opening of a new bandstand. Prince William has praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. He also addressed criticism of his own royal duties, saying he takes them seriously but is finding his own way. A photograph of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George has been released for stamps marking the occasion. The Queen's actual birthday is on 21 April, but her official birthday is in June. The republican group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage of the Queen's birthday, saying it was not fair, balanced, or proportionate.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored for West Ham in the first half, giving them control of the match. Cheltenham Town had chances through Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but they were unable to score. West Ham made seven changes from their previous matches, while Cheltenham kept the same lineup as their recent league defeat. The two teams had previously met in the same stage of the competition four years ago, with West Ham winning 2-1. West Ham could have won by a larger margin, but Cheltenham's defense, particularly Kyle Storer's clearance and Jonathan Flatt's save, kept the scoreline down. The match ended with West Ham advancing and Cheltenham Town's League Two representation in the EFL Cup coming to an end.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old man from Leipzig, failed to see Mr. McNicholl on his motorcycle as he turned right in his VW Transporter, causing the fatal crash. At Llandudno Magistrates' Court, Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving. He was fined Â£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not see value in Werner being jailed, accepting it as a momentary lapse. Werner expressed remorse but could not explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, left the UK in January last year and joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State. He was known for his online presence, always masked, and shared videos and pictures of his life in Syria. Khawaja, who called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, was involved in propaganda efforts for his group, including appeals for donations and videos of daily life. His group, according to Shiraz Maher of the International Centre for the Study of Radicalisation, was adept at producing propaganda that appealed to young British Muslims. Khawaja's activities in Syria are not fully known, but he was involved in gruesome propaganda, including an image of him holding a severed head. MI5 was monitoring him, and he was arrested upon his return to the UK in June last year after faking his own death. He is facing a possible life sentence for his role in Syria and has admitted four offences, including preparing acts of terrorism. His cousin Tahir Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja was considered so dangerous that he was held in a special unit for high risk terrorism suspects at Belmarsh prison. An additional charge of soliciting to murder will lie on file.

Kayden Jackson, 22, has joined Barnsley from Wrexham. He scored four goals in 36 appearances last season. Barnsley have signed three players ahead of their League One play-off final. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham. Paul Heckingbottom, Barnsley's caretaker boss, believes Jackson will fit in well with their style of play due to his pace and ability to get past defenders.

The National Trust volunteers have been clearing away bottles that have been washing up on beaches in Cornwall, including Poldhu Cove on the Lizard. The bottles are believed to have come from a container that fell off a ship near Land's End in May, during stormy weather. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated there is no concrete evidence linking the bottles to a specific incident, despite a ship called the MV Blue Ocean losing a container of Vanish bottles in the area. The National Trust is concerned about the potential environmental impact on wildlife, as the bottles contain detergent. Other affected coves include Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The Cornwall Wildlife Trust is "highly concerned" about the impact on marine life. The public is advised to keep away from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them. Cornwall Council, along with partners, will be monitoring the beaches.

The incident happened on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00. Several people were injured, one seriously, and others received minor injuries in the crash. The road was closed and diversions were put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season for Bolton Wanderers, helping them finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite has signed a new contract with Bolton, following in the footsteps of David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, who also signed new contracts after their promotion to the Championship.

The passage discusses the strained relationship between the Liberal Democrats and Labour in the context of Brexit negotiations. The Liberal Democrats, led by Lord Oates, accused Labour of being willing to concede too much to the government, while Labour, led by Baroness Smith, accused the Lib Dems of giving people false hope. The two parties had previously worked together to defeat the government on issues related to the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, after MPs rejected these amendments, the cooperation ended. The Lib Dems insisted on the amendments, while Labour deferred to the Commons' decision. A Labour source in the Lords criticized the Lib Dems for grandstanding and creating false hope for worried citizens. The Lib Dems, in turn, accused Labour of supporting a hard Brexit by aligning with the Conservatives. Despite these tensions, the Lib Dems expressed a willingness to continue working with peers from other parties on shared issues. The Labour source predicted residual tensions and a lack of enthusiasm for future cooperation.

The passage discusses the low priority given to defence in the current election, despite the world becoming more dangerous and unstable. Defence spending has been cut significantly, with the UK's military now having fewer personnel and equipment than before. The UK's commitment to spending 2% of GDP on defence is likely to be missed, and all indications suggest defence spending will continue to decrease. The passage also mentions the UK's nuclear deterrent, with differing party policies on its renewal or replacement. The Royal Navy's new aircraft carriers are highlighted as a potential symbol of the UK's diminishing military capabilities, due to a lack of personnel and equipment to fully utilize them. The passage concludes by questioning the UK's ability to maintain its reputation for "punching above its weight" on the world stage, given the current and projected state of its defence forces.

Barcelona have paid an additional 13.55 million euros in tax after signing Neymar. The club insists it has not committed any offence and that the payment is to cover possible interpretations of the contracts. The total cost of Neymar to the club is now 106.8 million pounds. The initial fee was 48.6 million pounds, with his parents receiving 34 million pounds of that. Barcelona's former president Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid accusations of misappropriating money. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Barcelona denies any wrongdoing and believes the original tax payment was sufficient. There has been no confirmation yet whether the case will be dropped after the additional payment.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old from Nottingham, died when a van he was in was hit by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw's family believes there should be regular driving tests for older people, arguing that age affects reaction times. They say Luciw, a new father, had his life taken away and that he will miss his daughter's milestones. Luciw's brother Simon suggests a test with a driving instructor to assess driving ability. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licences every three years with a self-assessment form, but no medical or driving test is required. The DVLA states that older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents and that they remove driving entitlements if a driver does not meet medical standards. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely for as long as possible, as driving provides independence.

The summary of the passage is as follows: Many women have experienced debilitating side effects from transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, leading to concerns about their safety. Two patients on the original review group resigned in protest over a watered-down report. Alison Britton, an independent expert, will examine the process of the final report. The report concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely and recommended a range of treatments with informed choices for patients. Reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. The health secretary confirmed that the recommendations would be implemented, but an all-out ban was not possible as it was under the jurisdiction of the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the final report. Some women who suffered complications quit the review group, and a consultant also resigned over concerns about the final draft. More than 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants over the past 20 years, with some experiencing painful and debilitating complications. There are currently over 400 women taking legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir broke Scottish runner Eilish McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan expressed excitement about the record being broken by Muir but had initial concerns about whether the race met all the criteria for a record attempt, including drug testing. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time was expected to be ratified as an official record. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to run even faster and win world medals, noting that Muir's race was similar to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago. McColgan is pleased that her record was broken by a fellow Scot and thinks Muir just needs to work on her race tactics to start winning medals.

Jung won the event riding Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou due to an infection. Astier Nicolas from France took silver and Phillip Dutton from the USA won bronze. William Fox-Pitt from GB finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, competed 10 months after a serious fall that required an induced coma. He performed well in the final show-jumping phase but was hindered by penalties in the cross-country phase. Jonty Evans from Ireland finished ninth.

Andy Murray won a tense fourth set to beat Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 at Wimbledon. The match ended at 20:57 BST after Murray saved five set points in the fourth set. He will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray said the match was "up and down" and he was pleased to finish in four sets. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also reached the second week with a win over Maria Sakkari.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 for a sudden death. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000. The judge expressed concern that he could not impose a custodial sentence, noting O'Neill's "appalling record" and describing the case as one of the worst he had come across. The defense solicitor admitted that the bar's licensing laws were not strictly adhered to and that the premises had not been run in a proper manner.

The Ulster Unionists launched their manifesto with Mike Nesbitt stating "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." The party wants the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. However, attention shifted to the Ulster Unionists after Nesbitt's comments about potentially transferring votes to the SDLP. Nesbitt defended his remarks, saying he would not withdraw a word and that he preferred a partnership with the SDLP over Sinn FÃ©in. The Ulster Unionist manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', focuses on issues like healthcare, policing, infrastructure, LGBT rights, and Brexit. Nesbitt also emphasized the need to address issues of incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption at Stormont.

The Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed a motion will be put before the Northern Ireland Assembly for approval to grant pardons for now-abolished sexual offences. This move will align Northern Ireland with England and Wales, where similar plans for automatic pardons were announced last month. The proposed law, known as 'Turing's Law' after Alan Turing, will provide posthumous pardons for men convicted of such offences and also allow living men convicted of these offences to apply for a pardon. The motion in the assembly is expected to contain the same provisions for both posthumous and living gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion for these pardons. The aim is to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales and to correct past injustices. The motion will now be considered by the assembly.

Laura Muir set a new Scottish record in the 1500m, finishing second in a time of 4:19.12 at the Diamond League meeting in London. This time surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and moved Muir to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who finished fifth in last year's World Championships, now holds the Scottish records for both the 1500m and the mile. She expressed her satisfaction with her performance and her excitement about getting close to the winner, Faith Kipyegon. Muir's next race will be in Stockholm in a week's time, and she hopes to secure an Olympic spot for Great Britain at the British trials in Birmingham in June. Muir balances her training with her veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school. Yvonne Murray congratulated Muir via her husband Tom Mooney's Facebook post.
The passage provides a summary of pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as having the best water quality.

The Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that there was no personal motive for Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi to kill Alexander Litvinenko. He suggested that the Russian state was likely to have been the sponsor of the plot to kill Litvinenko, who was poisoned with polonium-210 in London in 2006. The use of polonium indicates some form of Russian state participation, according to Mr Horwell. He stressed that this does not necessarily implicate Russian President Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his personal attacks on Putin could have been seen as treacherous. The inquiry heard that Litvinenko was poisoned twice and that the suspects left a trail of polonium behind them. The extradition of the two suspects has failed, and they remain in Russia. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, is the new captain of the Australian cricket team in one-day and Twenty20 formats, replacing the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, is the new vice-captain. Smith has already captained the team in three Tests against India and has played 32 Tests for Australia, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Michael Clarke, 34, has retired after his side lost the Ashes to England. Smith led the side in Clarke's absence due to injury. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith and said he is the right man for the job. Warner has been given the vice-captaincy despite past disciplinary issues, but Marsh believes he will respond well to the added responsibility. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval.

Tim Farron, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, has stated that he is passionate about LGBT+ rights and defending equal marriage will be at the top of his agenda. He refused to answer directly whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead saying that everyone is a sinner. He voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties," but clarified that he supports equal access under law for all people, regardless of their sexuality. He also wants to extend the marital rights of transgender people, citing the need to remove the spousal veto, which currently prevents transgender individuals from having equal access to marriage.

Accord Healthcare will use the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015, for its pharmaceutical production. The move is expected to create jobs, many of which will be filled by ex-Sanofi staff. The investment is seen as having a positive impact on the area. The leader of Newcastle City Council, Councillor Nick Forbes, said the announcement is great news for Newcastle and the North East, as it strengthens the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is a global player in the pharmaceutical industry and the new jobs and investment will boost the local economy.

Three senior staff members are leaving Dundee City Council: Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland. Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Monaghan and Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, believes these departures show the council's difficulty in retaining senior staff and expects more departures in the future. The council's chief executive, Angela Scott, thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, crashed at this year's Isle of Man TT and the Honda Fireblade bike he was using has had mechanical issues. He initially said he was quitting road racing but later clarified that he has no plans to race on Hondas this year. Martin did not compete at the North West 200 after his teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice. He will also not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin found the TT experience unpleasant and felt like a test rider. After further testing at Cadwell, he concluded the bike would not be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix. The team decided to withdraw him from the event, though they did not inform him directly. He has no unfinished business and wants to race in classic and unusual events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The PDP lost the presidential poll last month for the first time, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated as president on 29 May. The PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, but lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge for President-elect Buhari in dealing with militant groups. The elections were generally peaceful, but there were reports of violence in some areas, particularly in Rivers and other southern states. The PDP will need to rebuild itself after its defeat, following widespread allegations of corruption during its rule and the defection of governors and MPs to the APC.

The environmental lobby group Mighty accuses Olam, an agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of ignoring unsustainable palm oil trading practices. Both companies deny the allegations. The haze problem in Singapore and Malaysia is often linked to slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia. Olam, which accounts for less than 1% of the global palm oil market, buys 99% of its palm oil from third party suppliers. Mighty's report claims Olam and Temasek could be encouraging unsustainable practices and creating a secretive market for rogue palm oil companies. Olam's CEO Sunny Verghese states they have a strict 'no burn-no peat-no deforestation' policy and will remove non-compliant suppliers. Mighty's allegations could link Singapore's state fund Temasek to the haze issue if proven. Temasek states they support no-burn policies and do not interfere in Olam's operations. The palm oil industry is often criticized for labor practices, deforestation, and burning. Olam defends its practices in Gabon, stating they are transparent and responsible. Olam and Temasek reject the allegations, while Mighty calls for governments to enforce environmental standards.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants, but only outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt for the upcoming game due to a knee injury, having only played from the bench in the last two games. David Nugent, a striker for Derby County, may return to play after missing the previous game due to a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield, a Derby County midfielder, scored a late equalizer against Huddersfield and is hoping for a starting position in the next match.

The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority has lifted the ban on YouTube, stating that it is no longer necessary because Google has launched a Pakistan-specific version. The government claims that Google has agreed to a process where offending material can be requested to be blocked by the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directly. However, Google has clarified that requests for removal of content will not be automatically granted and will be reviewed. The ban was originally imposed in 2012 by the Supreme Court after the controversial film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded. The film sparked widespread protests in the Muslim world, including Pakistan, where more than a dozen people died. Pakistan's blasphemy laws make it a crime punishable by death, although the sentence has never been carried out. Google also announced the launch of local versions of YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, who heads up FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as is Gianni Infantino, one of the five presidential candidates. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections due to sharing nationality with a candidate, Sepp Blatter. Musa Bility, the Liberian FA boss, says he will go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The 2015 elections saw Scala and Claudio Sulser step aside due to nationality concerns. However, Scala's spokesman says there is no conflict of interest this time as there is no incumbent president. Bility, who was denied eligibility to run in the elections, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali and urged other Africans to do the same. The election will take place on February 26, 2016, in Zurich, with five candidates vying for the presidency: Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, Tokyo Sexwale, and Gianni Infantino.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road. They were working in a paint-spraying area when the incident occurred at around 09:00 BST on Monday. The men's bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. The explosion is believed to have been caused by a flashover, which happens when toxic fumes build up and are ignited, creating a fireball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence to investigate the incident.

Tunisia and Morocco faced issues with the Confederation of African Football (Caf) but have since resolved their disputes. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints it lodged against Caf during the 2015 tournament. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) has since apologized and the issue has been resolved. Morocco was banned from participating in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw but the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban. The Moroccan Football Association (MFA) chief, Fouzi Lekjaa, expressed optimism about the future of African football and Morocco's role in it. The FTF vice-president, Maher Snoussi, stated that the dispute with Caf is over and Tunisia is looking forward to the 2017 Nations Cup. Tunisia is preparing for their thirteenth straight Nations Cup appearance, which would set a record. The draw for the 2017 Nations Cup placed Tunisia in Group A with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

The passage describes a mass fracas that occurred in the 95th minute of a football match between Manchester City and Chelsea at Etihad Stadium. Manchester City forward Sergio Aguero and midfielder Fernandinho were sent off during the incident. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, his second such ban this season. Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban for his part in the scuffle. Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge. Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's part in the incident.

England won the second Test against Pakistan by an innings and 137 runs at Old Trafford, leveling the series at 1-1. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. England's captain Alastair Cook praised Root for his performance, especially at the number three position. England's coach Trevor Bayliss credited Root's success to hard work and determination. The pitch at Old Trafford offered little assistance to the bowlers, but England's discipline and quality were praised by former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott. Pakistan's batting performance was criticized, with Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledging their lack of confidence and poor shot selection. The series continues with the third Test at Edgbaston starting on 3 August. Former England captain Michael Vaughan expects the series to be tight despite England's convincing win.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has named interim coach Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach Graham McBryde assumes head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde is honored to represent his country overseas and looks forward to the opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. Discussions are at an advanced stage with other individuals about the summer tour, and the full management team is expected to be confirmed next week. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips and chairman Gareth Davies believe the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit Welsh rugby in the long term. Davies states that the Lions' experiences invigorate and inspire individuals, providing a unique opportunity for mental stimulation and growth.

The summary of the passage is as follows: Charlie Austin scored a penalty for Southampton in the sixth minute, but Hull City equalized through Robert Snodgrass in the 61st minute and took the lead with a Michael Dawson goal in the 63rd minute. Hull City's strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane were injured in the first half, which led to Snodgrass coming on as a substitute. Snodgrass's introduction changed the game, as he scored and assisted the winning goal. Southampton pushed for an equalizer, but Hull City goalkeeper David Marshall made several saves and Sam Clucas cleared a ball off the line in the final minute of added time to secure a 2-1 victory for Hull. The win ended Hull's six-game losing streak and lifted the spirits of their fans, who had been frustrated by the team's poor form and the ongoing issues with the club's ownership. The match took place shortly after Southampton's Europa League victory over Inter Milan, and the international break followed this Premier League match.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash with a tractor on the B1191 in Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at about 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist was a local resident, but no further details have been released. The tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses to the collision. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power and said he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. His move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials. Macedonia has been in turmoil since the release of covert recordings in 2015, which allegedly show government officials involved in corruption and abuse of power. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing a steady stream of recordings, accusing the government of wiretapping and corruption. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said President Ivanov's actions were not in line with the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis was sparked by recordings that appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder. The government denies the accusations and has accused Mr Zaev of trying to destabilize the country.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea for the match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley was sacked. Swansea want to hire a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as their top choice. Curtis wants someone who can keep them in the Premier League, as the Championship is getting stronger and it's not easy to go straight back up. Swansea were promoted to the Premier League in 2011 and have had a reputation for playing exciting football. Curtis believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, with frequent changes in management and not adequately replacing players. He thinks the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds new players of the club's history and importance.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona gave Dagenham hope after Jay Simpson put Orient 2-0 up. Armand Gnanduillet's winner kept Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham reached League One in 2010 but have now returned to the National League under manager John Still, who took them to the Football League in 2007. Dagenham have the worst goal difference in League Two and have conceded 20 more goals this season than last. Striker Jamie Cureton has scored nine goals this season, compared to 20 in the 2014-15 campaign. Leyton Orient interim manager Andy Hessenthaler said the team owed it to the fans to win after losing two managers this season. Dagenham manager John Still said his team lacked organisation and discipline in the first half.

Steven Gerrard, a former Liverpool captain and player, is returning to Liverpool as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player. He has expressed his desire to become a manager in the future. Klopp had a good conversation with Gerrard and believes he has a bright future in coaching. Gerrard has a long career with Liverpool, winning multiple trophies, and he retired from playing in November 2015. He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching license. He turned down a potential job at MK Dons because it came too soon for him.

McManus scored the first goal for Morton in the 15th minute. Ross Forbes then doubled Morton's lead with a deflected strike. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa before halftime. McManus scored again and Denny Johnstone scored late in the game, securing a comfortable win for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three illegal schools in Birmingham, which have now closed. The owners are being investigated for running illegal schools, which can lead to a jail term of up to 51 weeks. There are concerns that these illegal schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, could be putting children at risk of abuse or radicalisation. Any place where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week must register as a school. Some places, such as part-time education centres or "flexi schools," operate within the law by providing support for home-educated children. However, there are concerns that some of these places are actually illegal schools. Ofsted and the government are working to address this issue, with a team of six inspectors investigating illegal schools. The government is also consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. The Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools. A prosecution can only be brought with the consent of the Education Secretary. The consultation on further regulation will run until mid-January. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, believes these cases are likely to be the "tip of the iceberg." He emphasizes that the new regulations will apply to all religious groups, not just Muslim communities.

Lilliard Gin is produced at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. This is part of a series of proposals to open the Scottish Borders' first whisky distillery since 1837. The gin is made on a small scale, with the still fitting into a cowshed. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes is excited about the potential for the region to become a distilling excellence area. The gin uses local botanicals from the Teviot valley to capture the local flavor and "terroir". John Henderson of Born in the Borders sees the gin as a good fit with the existing brewery on the site. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The name reflects the local landscape and the strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam died after Gary Green, who was more than two times the legal driving limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before driving the vehicle. Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation, not road traffic law, as the incident occurred on private land. He was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother Pam Whitlam expressed that her family had been "changed forever" and called for awareness about the dangers of driving under the influence, whether on public roads or private land. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) described Green's behavior as "reckless" and the incident as "extremely tragic".

Luis Suarez can now train and play in friendly matches after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) partially upheld his appeal against a four-month ban for biting an opponent. The Uruguay striker will join Barcelona's training session on Friday and will be presented to the media at the Camp Nou on Monday. However, he will still have to serve the remaining eight games of his record nine-match ban in competitive international games. His competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October. The ban was imposed by Fifa after Suarez bit Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during a World Cup match in June. The Cas ruling still prevents him from playing "organised" matches but allows him to take part in all "football-related activities". Suarez's legal team argued that Fifa's decision to suspend him from all football activity was too strong a punishment. The world governing body's decision was "generally confirmed" by Cas, but preventing Suarez from training was deemed "excessive". Suarez will now be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan and South Korea in September and Saudi Arabia the following month.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race where competitors carry each other over a 380-meter course, including hurdling over haystacks, climbing a slope, and dodging water pistols. They beat a Lithuanian couple, Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene. Rich and Anna prepared by running around an athletics track near their home for a week. They will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July. Competitors do not need to be married, and there were various combinations of participants, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman.

The DVLA will undergo changes in job roles when the paper tax disc system is scrapped in October 2014. Stephen Hammond, the minister, has assured that there will be no job losses, but rather redeployment to other areas of the business. The new system will allow for monthly direct debit payments and will likely reduce the number of refunds processed. The minister's response to Mike Hedges, Swansea East AM, has provided comfort to DVLA employees regarding their job security. The changes are part of a government initiative to replace the traditional tax disc with an electronic system.

The EU is objecting to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and non-governmental organisations (NGOs), as well as a higher education law. Hungary's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr. Szijjarto, stated that the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues" and that Hungary would not backtrack on any of the three issues. He also mentioned that Poland has pledged to veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. The EU rules require unanimous approval for such decisions. Hungary's right-wing government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is under pressure to withdraw the laws, including one that could force the closure of the prestigious Central European University (CEU). The CEU ranks among the top 200 universities in the world in eight disciplines and was founded by philanthropist George Soros. Additionally, draft legislation on NGOs is expected to go before parliament soon, which human rights groups say would stigmatize them as "foreign-backed" organisations. The EU's executive Commission has warned of action if there are no positive developments in the coming weeks.

The upcoming 2017 live-action version of Beauty and the Beast will feature Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Emma Thompson will play Mrs. Potts, a teapot character originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and will start filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away after battling cancer. He had been undergoing chemotherapy and expressed that he did not feel cheated by his diagnosis, stating he had been "very lucky" in life. The Sunday Times editor, Martin Ivens, described Gill as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill's final column, discussing his diagnosis, will be featured in the next edition of the Sunday Times. His death was sudden and shocked his colleagues. Gill was known for his unique writing style and controversial opinions, which sometimes led to public outrage. He had a long career in journalism, overcoming dyslexia to become a successful writer. Gill was married twice and had four children. His partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, was to be his third wife.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was performing in Ulan Bator when he was allegedly attacked. He was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but claims local reports are distorted. Sukhbaatar wore a robe with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol, not associated with Nazi ideology. His father stated that Sukhbaatar spent 10 days in a coma after the attack. The Russian official accused of the attack has not been identified. The embassy statement mentioned that reports about the date, number of participants, and circumstances were inaccurate. The swastika is not a hate symbol in Mongolia and has a long history there. The musician's lawyer said the suspect, a Russian diplomat, had not been arrested and should be investigated under Mongolian law. The police stated that the suspect was not detained because the injury was not serious, not due to diplomatic immunity. The incident is under investigation by the police.

The passage describes a protest by Plane Stupid at Heathrow Airport on Monday morning. The protesters, both men and women, were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area of the airport. They will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police will review security at the airport following the incident. The protest was in opposition to Heathrow's expansion plans.

Glamorgan's Nick Selman scored 101 runs off 144 balls, his second first-class century. Despite Selman's performance, Glamorgan's batting was disrupted by Gloucestershire's seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles. Gloucestershire also struggled as the bowlers dominated the day's play. Glamorgan managed to secure a bonus point thanks to contributions from Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten. The match ended with the scores evenly balanced. This was Michael Hogan's first match as Glamorgan captain, as Jacques Rudolph was absent due to a neck problem. Nick Selman expressed relief at ending a run of low scores with his century, but was disappointed to be out shortly after reaching the milestone. Gloucestershire's Matt Taylor was pleased with his bowling performance, noting that the pitch offered assistance to the bowlers. Both teams face challenges in the upcoming innings, with Gloucestershire needing to survive the evening gloom and Glamorgan looking to build on their first innings.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making online threats to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning a murder bid involving an ambush of police officers, triggered by a false report of a crime. Hughes, who was drunk at the time, said he would shoot officers on the Dee Estuary. He has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Judge Niclas Parry remanded Hughes in custody, and sentencing will take place next week. Hughes's legal team stated he did not intend to kill himself or carry out the threats against police officers. North Wales Police was concerned because Hughes was on bail for firearms offences, though he was later cleared of these charges. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to those in difficulty.

Surrey posted a score of 255-7 with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker. Tim Bresnan made 68 but Yorkshire were all out for 236. Yorkshire lost to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals and were hoping to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002. However, they were unable to chase down the target and lost the match.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler was 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack when the crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. The boat's pump was unable to cope with the water coming in. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump on board and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir will not be competing at the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. She will be focusing on her exams in May and completing her final year of studies. Muir is disappointed to miss the Commonwealths but emphasizes the importance of her degree. She is considering competing at the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the latter event. She believes she has at least two to three more Olympics in her future but is unsure of which events she will compete in.

Robbie Savage's column discusses Liverpool's current state and their upcoming match against Chelsea. He notes that Liverpool are far from their title challenge form of last season and that securing Champions League qualification should be seen as a success for manager Brendan Rodgers. Savage points out that Liverpool's struggles are partly due to the loss of goals from Luis Suarez and the injuries to Daniel Sturridge. He also addresses Steven Gerrard's situation, stating that Gerrard's legs may not be as strong as they once were but he still has much to offer the team. Gerrard is facing a difficult match against Chelsea, given the events of last season, but Savage believes Gerrard's determination will keep him going beyond this season.

The new Â£45m educational facility in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He is known for his first novel Remedy Is None and the Laidlaw trilogy, earning him the title of "Godfather of Tartan Noir." The council leader, Douglas Reid, is pleased to preserve McIlvanney's name in Kilmarnock, as the writer was passionate about education. McIlvanney died on 5 December.

The area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated due to a sea mine spotted on Monday. The mine is believed to be British and from the 1940s or 1950s. Three streets were evacuated, and residents within 500m of the device were advised to stay indoors and open windows. An exclusion zone was set up on the river and at sea, affecting ferry services. The operation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community. The mine was to be moved to a safer place before being dealt with. Inverclyde Council thanked residents for their patience during the evacuation.

The passage discusses the funding cuts and changes for various sports in the UK leading up to the Tokyo 2020 Olympics. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have missed out on funding. Cycling, which was successful in Rio 2016, has had its funding cut by more than £4m. Badminton England is "staggered" by the decision to remove its funding, despite earning a medal in Rio. UK Sport has set a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Team GB in Tokyo. The total investment is £345m, which is £2m less than the amount allocated for Rio. UK Sport's Rod Carr states that the government has confirmed its commitment to Tokyo 2020. Badminton is the only sport that earned a podium place in Rio to have its funding removed. Judo, which also earned a bronze medal, has had its funding increased slightly. UK Sport's CEO Liz Nicholl says the decision to cut funding was not taken lightly and prioritization was necessary to protect medal potential. Sports minister Tracey Crouch supports UK Sport's approach, citing its success in previous Games. Basketball, handball, and volleyball express disappointment, stating that UK Sport seems to have no interest in team sports and has not followed through on its commitment to fund their development. Funding for five Olympic and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed, with £9m still to be allocated. UK Sport has left the door open for sports like baseball to prove their medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth will be demolished to make way for a new six-storey, four star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage objected to the development due to its scale in a conservation area. However, the planning board voted in favor of the project, stating it would benefit tourism and provide better living conditions for older people. The East Cliff Project LLP will carry out the demolition of Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The new development will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. The council received support from 246 letters, but 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected to the demolition. English Heritage expressed concern that the development would cause "severe harm" to the area's historic character.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely in Brecon on 8 May. Vallely, who had been drinking for seven hours, boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. Vallely was found guilty of manslaughter and will be sentenced on 8 December. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Pte Boyd was making his way back to barracks when he was punched and beaten outside a bar. The community of Brecon was shocked by the attack. Pte Boyd's family described him as loving, caring, and full of life, and said Vallely created a void in their family. They also praised the community for their support.

Andrew Travers left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council by mutual agreement after an error on election day. All 155 polling stations in the borough initially turned away voters because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched into the error. John Hooton, the deputy chief executive, will take over temporarily. The council's review will conclude by the end of May and the findings will be presented publicly. The investigation will also look at the arrangements for the EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored the first goal with a free-kick. Sean Newton equalized with another free-kick for Wrexham. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead, heading a cross from Craig Baxter. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby was pleased with the win and praised his team's second half performance. Wrexham manager Gary Mills was disappointed with his team's second half performance and noted they missed chances to score.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of those over 60 in 96 countries. Norway is the best country for older people, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project aims to deliver global broadband connectivity using a network of at least 600 satellites, with the potential to expand to over 2,000. The project requires a new approach to satellite manufacturing, with Airbus aiming to produce three satellites per shift at less than a million dollars each. This involves a high volume, low cost assembly line similar to those used in car and plane manufacturing. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April 2019, with more than 800 satellites expected to be on station by the middle of the 2020s. OneWeb is a global company registered in the UK's Channel Islands, and it has secured $1.7bn in equity to fund the project. The UK Space Agency will play a role in regulating the project, particularly in terms of debris mitigation. OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting old satellites within two years to reduce the risk of space debris. Airbus and OneWeb hope their new manufacturing methods will set new standards in the satellite industry and potentially be used for other companies' satellites. However, not all satellite projects will require the high volume approach, and some will still need bespoke treatment.

The Scottish government, led by Mr Swinney, is facing "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure due to the UK government's recent spending review. The UK government claims that Scotland will have £390m more in spending available next year. Mr Swinney argues that the UK government's cuts since 2010, including the recent spending review, will reduce Scotland's discretionary budget by 12.5% in real terms by 2019-20. He states that £1bn of these cuts are still to come by the end of the decade. The Scottish government believes that the UK government could have reduced debt and deficit without such severe cuts. Mr Swinney insists that key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and police services will be protected, and that Scotland has achieved better outcomes in recent years. The UK government's Scotland Office responds by stating that Scotland will have more funding available next year and that the UK's economic stability is beneficial. They suggest that the Scottish government should focus on preparing for new powers rather than complaining. Labour's Jackie Baillie calls for a long-term budget and criticizes the SNP for not providing concrete plans to counter austerity.

The passage discusses the lack of truly accessible toilet facilities for people with severe disabilities, which can leave them feeling isolated and unable to enjoy everyday activities. It highlights the need for Changing Places toilets, which have extra features and more space to meet the needs of users who require a hoist and a bench for changing. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but they are not mandatory in building regulations. The passage mentions the psychological impact on families and the importance of making these facilities compulsory in larger buildings. It also mentions the efforts of campaigners, like Lorna Fillingham, who started a petition to make the guidelines compulsory. The passage provides examples of how the lack of suitable facilities affects families and the positive impact of having Changing Places toilets, such as the experience of Bethan Folen and her daughter Lowri. It also discusses the challenges businesses face in installing these facilities due to space and financial constraints. The passage ends with a positive example from Arsenal Football Club, which installed a Changing Places toilet and saw a positive reaction from fans and the public.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's. They allege that McDonald's forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's responded by stating that they share risks and rewards with their franchisees and have a successful business model that has been in place for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, including the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union in the UK, support the complaint. The European Commission will study the submission and has the power to launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed credible. The complaint claims that franchisees are locked into long contracts and are forced to lease premises at above market rates, which leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to those owned directly by McDonald's. In Europe, franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants. McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood by the A2. This is part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. Josh was initially scheduled for an appendix operation at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, but doctors discovered and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths instead. The news shocked his family, but they have received support from people all over the world. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, was amazed by the support. The hashtag went viral, and a mystery donor paid for a billboard to be erected at Holywood playing fields. Josh's classmates have also shown their support on Twitter using the hashtag. People from all over the world are now supporting Josh and his family as he recovers, thanks to the kindness of strangers in County Down.

The closure of Brecon Barracks has been condemned by Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies. He stated that the barracks have been in Brecon since 1805 and have been home to troops who fought the Zulus at Rorke's Drift. Davies criticized the decision, calling it "abhorrent" and expressed his intention to fight it. He also questioned the government's reasoning for closing a well-loved and historic barracks in a military town. The barracks have a long history of service, with soldiers fighting in every conflict since the early 19th century. Davies is concerned about the impact on the local economy, as the Brecon area has high unemployment levels, and the potential damage to the military tourism industry. The barracks employ about 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel, but it is not expected that jobs will be at risk. The nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines are not affected by the closure. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced a reorganisation in Wales, including the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan. Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire, previously announced to close in 2013, will now close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring the military estate but warned that base closures would affect the livelihoods of many people.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report that discusses the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The fishing industry, which voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU, hopes to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the Lords warn that the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall Brexit deal. The fishing industry contributes a small percentage to the UK's GDP and employs around 12,000 fishers, which may make it a low priority in the wider Brexit negotiations. The Lords emphasize that the industry should not be marginalized. The UK's fishing industry relies on market access to the EU, as it exports the majority of its fish to the EU and imports a significant portion of its fish from EU states. The report suggests that continued market access may come at the cost of allowing more EU access to UK waters. The Lords also recommend retaining certain elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), such as basing total allowable catches on scientific advice. The UK will continue to be under international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. There is concern that leaving the EU could lead to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry believe Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats. The government has stated that it aims to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade with the single market while reviewing fisheries management to ensure fair access to quota, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks about US surveillance programs. The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and numbers involved. According to leaked documents, the NSA has access to a vast amount of individual data from major tech companies through a program called Prism. These companies deny involvement, and the exact workings of Prism are unclear. The NSA director claims the surveillance has helped keep Americans safe but cannot provide details due to security concerns. Data protection laws vary by country and tend to regulate what companies can do with user data rather than government activity. The US Patriot Act gives US authorities access to European data stored in the US. The UK government has not confirmed or denied involvement with Prism. Privacy concerns persist, with Snowden stating he leaked the information due to privacy concerns. The EU is seeking more details from the US about Prism. Privacy International expressed concern over the reported existence of Prism.

OpenAI is a venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. It aims to conduct AI research without financial obligations to ensure a positive human impact. The backers believe that AI should benefit humanity as a whole and be distributed safely and evenly. Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned about potential threats AI could pose to humanity, but other experts consider these risks remote. OpenAI has pledged $1 billion, but only a small portion will be spent in the near future.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson was injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. He carried the Olympic torch in Doncaster on 26 June and has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. He has had to turn down many requests due to this limit. Despite his brain injury, which took his speech, he has regained the ability to speak unaided and has maintained his personality and sense of humor. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab and walks with crutches. He is also a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits, a military charity. His mother Diane said the support and friendship shown to Ben has been "phenomenal." Facebook suggests that if a person receives this many requests, they should consider creating a public page or using the subscribe feature so that people can see their public updates without becoming a friend. Ben Parkinson is one of 8,000 torchbearers who will carry the flame on its 8,000 mile, 70-day journey to the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in London on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the United States was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. This rate remained unchanged from the previous three years, despite real median household income dropping by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% in 2011, marking the first annual rise since 1993. Additionally, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010, at 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, moved to Lancashire from Somerset in 2013. He has signed a new contract with Lancashire, which will keep him at the club until 2019. Buttler is known for his skill in the shorter formats of the game, and he holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach of Lancashire, praised Buttler's talent and his impact on the team, especially in the T20 Blast final where his presence was a factor in their victory. Buttler's international experience is also seen as beneficial to the squad. He has been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians and will return to Lancashire to play in their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Those who have registered an interest are finalizing their bids with viewings set to take place in late February and March. A final decision is not expected until the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to determine the capacity of the UK's industry in the field. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, hopes at least one of the ships will be saved from the scrapyard and turned into a reef and diving attraction, which would generate income through tourism. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure best financial return for the taxpayer. The Type 22 frigate was originally designed as an anti-submarine ship but evolved into a powerful surface combatant with substantial weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for Â£3m.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions have been a source of instability and international isolation in Fiji. In 1987, a coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew the elected, Indian-dominated coalition, leading to a series of adverse events. These events included the introduction and withdrawal of a constitution that enshrined indigenous Fijian political supremacy. A further coup in 2000, led by businessman George Speight, saw the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and several MPs held hostage. These events caused significant harm to the economy, particularly the tourism industry, and Fiji's international reputation.

Racial and political tensions persisted, with rancor over the 2000 coup and disagreements over amnesty plans. These disputes culminated in a bloodless military takeover in 2006, Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years. In 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth due to its lack of progress towards democracy.

Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, the descendants of Indian laborers. Coups and agitation have prompted many Indo-Fijians to leave, making indigenous Fijians a small overall majority. There are also small minority communities, such as Chinese and Rotumans.

Fiji's economy relies on sugar and tourism, but it also has mining and services sectors. Despite this diversity, the country has persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a large recipient of aid.

In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand. In 2014, following the elections, Fiji was reinstated as a member of the Commonwealth.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way from Damascus to Latakia. Mr Mekdad blamed "terrorist groups" for the attacks and said that Syria is in a state of war, which should be taken into consideration by the US and others. He also criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry for condemning the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, claiming that Syria is defending its people against terrorist attacks and has never targeted civilians. The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and activist groups reported that rebels had mounted an assault and freed hundreds of detainees. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% having left the country so far.
