The US and Russia have expressed concerns over the delays, with a deadline set for the destruction of all weapons by the end of June. The OPCW has acknowledged that security concerns have slowed down the process, but Mr Mekdad insisted that Syria is committed to fulfilling its obligations on time.

The Lives Of Others by Indian author Neel Mukherjee is the favorite to win the Booker Prize. The prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London's Guildhall. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and an Australian. Howard Jacobson, who won in 2010, is nominated for his novel J. Mukherjee's book is set in 1960s Calcutta and focuses on a family amidst political activism. Ali Smith's How To Be Both tells two interlinking stories, with the reader deciding the order. Joshua Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour explores atheism through a New York dentist. Karen Joy Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves is the best-selling book on the list. Richard Flanagan's The Narrow Road to the Deep North is a love story set during World War Two. The announcement of the shortlist caused a sales spike for all the books. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling and includes Sarah Churchwell and Jonathan Bate. Last year's winner was Eleanor Catton for The Luminaries. Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. The ceremony will be covered by the BBC News Channel from 9:30 PM BST.

The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal in a case involving a celebrity referred to as PJS. The case concerns an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on naming PJS in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will decide if the appeal should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the end of the hearing. The celebrity, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is fighting against the publication of an account of alleged extra-marital activities in The Sun on Sunday. The man argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The Court of Appeal previously ruled in his favor, preventing him from being identified in publications in England and Wales. However, the judges also stated that the details of the allegations were now so widespread that confidentiality had probably been lost, making it a "hopeless task" to continue monitoring and removing stories in breach of the injunction. The Supreme Court's decision will determine the outcome of the case.

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was bought for Â£345.5m in August. The new owners plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White said the new owners want to invest and improve the area, as it is the gateway to the city. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, said they want to address parking and congestion issues and improve the quality of common areas. They aim to make Fosse Park as good as it can be.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast was due to be released in Malaysia on Thursday but has been delayed due to a "gay moment" in the film. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit concerning the scene. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia. The film received a P13 parental guidance classification. The decision to review the film has sparked controversy and criticism from netizens. The film's release date in Malaysia has yet to be announced.

Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people need to apply for a licence for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO). The licence can cost up to ??1,000, but failing to apply can result in a fine of up to ??20,000. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. HMO tenants often face fear of eviction and poorly maintained properties. The shortage of affordable homes forces people into unregulated rented homes. In Southampton, HMO licences are required in specific areas including Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not applying for their HMO licence.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are trying to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. Water charges are a major issue in negotiations. One proposal is to set up a commission to consider the future of Irish Water. Fianna Fáil wants to end water charges immediately, while Fine Gael believes they should continue. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7. No party was able to form a majority government, and TDs have not yet elected a Taoiseach.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry, was en route to Valencia when a fire broke out on one of the car decks. The passengers and crew were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. Three people were injured, with one in serious condition, and were airlifted to hospital by helicopter. The cause of the fire is unknown. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, assisted in the rescue. The rescued passengers and crew eventually boarded another ferry, the Puglia. They were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca. Psychologists were being sent to the port to provide counseling. The Balearic Islands port authority tweeted that the Sorrento may sink. The ferry, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time (11:50 GMT). Initially, the captain did not believe it necessary to abandon the ship, but the fire became too intense, leading to a full evacuation.

The Electoral Commission has highlighted concerns about duplicate voter registrations and the potential for people to vote twice in the general election. They noted that 38 MPs have reported cases of individuals claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offence. The Commission suggested that electoral registers should be better connected to identify duplicate entries. They also mentioned that 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 2017 general election, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. The surge in applications to register to vote was particularly noticeable in areas with large student populations. The Commission pointed out that the online registration service and electoral registers are not directly linked, leading to a significant number of duplicate applications. They proposed clearer information on registration sites and a verification function to address this issue. Despite the concerns, there is a lack of evidence to support claims of people voting twice, but the Commission takes the issue seriously and encourages anyone with information to contact the police. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote, emphasizing that a blanket ban on being registered at two addresses could exclude those who need to be registered in two places due to work or study. The Commission also called for people registered in two seats to choose in advance which one they will vote in at future general elections.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and star at the University of Nebraska, is believed to have committed suicide on Wednesday. He was 40 years old. Phillips played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, but his career was marred by legal troubles. After his NFL career, he continued to have problems with the law, including a conviction for assaulting a group of teenagers with his car and another conviction for assaulting a former girlfriend. Phillips was serving a prison sentence of more than 30 years when he was found dead. He had been placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge had found enough evidence to try Phillips for Soward's death. The cause of Phillips' suicide is unclear. Tom Osborne, Phillips' coach at Nebraska, commented on Phillips' intelligence and good qualities, but also noted his anger issues and inability to overcome his personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to the rank of lance corporal at a ceremony in Chester. This promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the Mercian Regiment, for good behavior. The ram, considered an official soldier, is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. Private Derby XXX joined the regiment in 2014 and has his own army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season at the Chatsworth Estate. He has participated in various events, including the Christmas lights switch-on in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling Europa League quarterfinal second leg match at Anfield. The game was marked by intense emotion, drama, excitement, and brilliant football. Liverpool's manager, Jurgen Klopp, inspired his team to come back from a 2-0 deficit in the first nine minutes of the game. Liverpool needed three goals to progress, and they achieved this with goals from Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Dejan Lovren in injury time. The victory was reminiscent of Liverpool's 2005 Champions League triumph, where they came back from a 3-0 deficit against AC Milan. Klopp's touchline demeanor and the atmosphere at Anfield played a significant role in the team's performance. The win moves Liverpool closer to securing a place in the Champions League and winning the Europa League. Klopp has instilled a new belief and identity in his team, and he has banned his players from touching the "This Is Anfield" sign until they win a trophy.

The UK government, represented by David Davis, has expressed a commitment to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland updated about Brexit negotiations. A meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London was held, and Davis stated that he wants to hold monthly meetings to share analysis and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views. He believes this will help in shaping the UK's negotiating strategy with Brussels.

On the other hand, Scotland's Brexit minister, Mike Russell, has called for greater transparency from the UK government regarding their strategic intentions. He pointed out that four months after the referendum, the UK government has still not made its intentions clear, particularly regarding whether they plan to remain inside the single market or the customs union. Russell emphasized that single market membership is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity.

The UK government is hoping that the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered will be overruled on appeal to the Supreme Court next month. Meanwhile, the Scottish government will oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe expected to apply to be heard in the case.

The passage discusses the health monitoring of a group of 13 cloned sheep, including four that are clones of Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. Veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr examines the sheep for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. The sheep are closely monitored to determine if cloned animals age normally and are healthy. The study aims to address concerns about whether cloned animals inherit age-related issues from the cells they were cloned from. The original Dolly died at 6.5 years old, and her early death raised questions about the health of cloned animals. The researchers are comparing the health of the cloned sheep to the general sheep population, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published next week. The cloned sheep, nearing their ninth and tenth birthdays, appear to be in good health.

Shutter Speed, a 4-7 favorite, won the Musidora Stakes at Newbury, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. Trainer John Gosden decided to let her race after walking the course. Shutter Speed will go to Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are contenders. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won the Duke of York Stakes, beating Magical Memory in second and Comica in third. Shutter Speed's win was the fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Dettori noted that the horse performed well despite the soft ground, and she is considered top drawer. Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will decide whether to run him in the Derby trial after walking the course. Shutter Speed will have a month to prepare for the Oaks in Chantilly, staged over her preferred distance of a mile and a quarter.

The currency weakened against the dollar and euro, then recovered slightly before falling again. The "volatility index" reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound's value had simply returned to March levels. The pound's value decreased against the dollar, euro, and Japanese yen. Investors' uncertainty has increased, and markets have been affected by global economic concerns. Polls show the referendum vote is too close to call, leading to market volatility. Hedge funds are betting on a further decline in sterling's value. The FTSE 100 index ended the day down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group experiencing the largest fall. A weaker pound is seen as beneficial for UK exporters. The Leave campaign also noted that the pound had been strengthening before the recent decline and that the FTSE 100 had remained stable since March.

Braintree Town, known as The Iron, are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. They lost to Barrow, who have an unbeaten league run of nine games. Despite the loss, manager Danny Cowley remains positive, stating that their journey has been remarkable but not easy. He emphasizes that they are a part-time team facing their toughest challenge to date, but they will embrace and enjoy it to see where it takes them.

The passage discusses a shift in responsibility for planning decisions from the Planning Service, an agency under Stormont's environment department, to local councils. This means elected politicians will make planning decisions, which is seen as a move towards a more democratic planning system. Michael Corr, creative director of PLACE, sees this as a positive opportunity for councils to develop their own community and development plans. However, there are concerns about the potential for discrimination and favoritism, as seen in the 1960s when local councils were accused of discriminatory housing allocation. Friends of the Earth warns that a strict code of conduct is necessary to ensure fairness and transparency in planning decisions. They also express concern about the relationship between developers and political parties, and argue for more transparency in political donations. Some politicians oppose this transparency due to concerns about personal security and the relevance of the current donation declaration limit. The final decision on when to implement more transparency in political donations rests with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

Teenie, a one-year-old cat, was shot three times, requiring the amputation of her left back leg. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured in NiddryView, Winchburgh. The Scottish SPCA is investigating the incident and has called for the licensing of air weapons. The Scottish government previously held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but a majority of responders opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA believes licensing would help prevent such incidents and ensure only those with a lawful reason can possess air guns.

Christian Benteke has joined Liverpool from Aston Villa for a fee believed to be around £32.5m. He has signed a long-term contract and is Liverpool's second most expensive signing. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk in 2012. Liverpool have made seven summer signings, including forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. The club struggled for goals last season, finishing sixth in the Premier League. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup with an injury but returned to score 15 goals for Villa last season. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Anfield. Liverpool's former striker John Aldridge is optimistic about Benteke's impact.

The study commissioned by education technology charity Tablets for Schools found that tablet devices are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. However, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using these devices. The study, headed by Barbie Clarke, found that 9% of schools have an individual tablet for every pupil, with the highest use in academy schools. Despite the lack of clear academic benefits, head teachers reported a positive impact, such as motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement when tablets are taken home. The number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. Dr Clarke says that while the specific impact of technology on attainment cannot be isolated, the role of technology in schools is going to grow. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read. The study also showed that about two-thirds of pupils take a computer device or smartphone to bed with them, primarily for social media and watching videos. Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School in Essex, advocates for tablet computers in schools, stating they create a sense of empowerment and trust among pupils. He believes that the use of technology in school reflects the reality of how pupils live at home and what they will find at work.

The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs that span over 100 years, capturing the life of children in Liverpool. The images, which range from the 1880s to the 1990s, provide a social history of life in Liverpool and how special occasions were marked. The oldest photograph is from 1887 and shows the Rollo children dressed for a fancy dress ball. Another image from around 1900 shows a young maid for a well-to-do family, highlighting the work children were expected to do. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who selected the 25 images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition aims to show both the good and bad experiences of childhood, and is on display at the Museum of Liverpool until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow to join Torquay United in the National League. He has played for Aldershot and Exeter, and could play against Barrow on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, is joining Torquay United after being recommended by Micky Adams. He has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His move is subject to international clearance. Torquay United manager Kevin Nicholson believes Anderson will be a leader and Keating is hungry to prove himself. Torquay United are currently struggling in the league, having won only one of their last six games.

The new law in Bolivia allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera says this reflects the country's needs. The law also increases the punishment for child homicide to 30 years in jail. More than 500,000 children already work in Bolivia, according to Unicef. The International Labour Organisation suggests a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, but they are studying the new Bolivian law to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labour. President Evo Morales ensured the law balanced reality and international treaties. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50 year-old actress and former talk show host, had a heart attack last week. She experienced sudden nausea and aches, which she looked up online and found to be symptoms of a heart attack in women. She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell did not call emergency services but urges others to do so. The type of heart attack she had is known as the "widow maker". She recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was cancelled due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Kenton, London, in the early hours of Sunday morning. The incident occurred after a group of youths tried to enter the party and a fight ensued. Che was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later in an alleyway. He was pronounced dead about an hour after being stabbed. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a hospital in stable condition. The party was described as a well-run event with adults present. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder and is being questioned. Two boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old boy is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. The police are seeking witnesses who were near the alleyway where Che was stabbed.

The passage describes a reorganisation of the way patients are diagnosed with cancer in Denmark, particularly for cases that are not immediately obvious. The changes were made in response to poor cancer survival statistics compared to other European countries. The problem was that waiting times for diagnosis were too long, especially for patients with vague or difficult to diagnose symptoms.

Denmark introduced a new model of care with three routes:
1. Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers, with strict time targets.
2. Diagnosis centres where patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose are given a range of tests and scans quickly.
3. "Yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms, offering simple tests or scans to quickly identify any serious issues.

The changes have not led to an overload of the system but have improved organisation and use of existing resources. The results have been positive, with better survival rates and Denmark catching up to other Scandinavian countries in cancer care. The passage suggests that Wales could learn from Denmark's approach to better organisation and collaboration between GPs and specialists.

Powys council has won a competitive bidding process to deliver a service that will replace the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in regulating estate agents in England and Wales. The council will receive £170,000 a year to carry out this work, which includes issuing warning and banning orders against dishonest agents. Complaints about estate agents will still be made to local authority trading standards departments, who will prosecute offenders if necessary. If parts of the Estate Agents Act are breached, these cases will be referred to Powys. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, hopes this role will demonstrate that Powys can take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The Nuffield Trust review found that nurses and pharmacists could take on more tasks with additional training. NHS Employers has approved this plan, as it could help fill gaps in the workforce, particularly in areas where there are shortages of doctors and GPs. The review highlighted examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. However, unions warn against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems, citing concerns about funding for training and the importance of maintaining quality care. The British Medical Association supports increased skills but emphasizes the need for proper training and experience for doctors. The Unison head of health also cautions against using this as a cheap fix for staff shortages without adequate funding for training. The report suggests that reshaping the workforce could improve patient care and provide staff with more rewarding roles, but it acknowledges that money will need to be set aside for this to happen effectively.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure, which was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations are under way into how the collision happened. First said that while parts of its services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman said they hoped to have a full service running in time for the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and understanding.

NRW estimated that the Swansea tidal lagoon would result in the deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout each year as they migrate to and from local rivers. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed these claims, stating that they lacked a clear scientific basis. NRW defended its figures, stating they were based on the best available evidence. TLP claimed NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating the figures. TLP's own computer modelling estimated a worst case scenario of the lagoon killing 2% of all species of fish. The Swansea tidal lagoon project is seen as a test bed for larger projects around the UK coast. The UK government is reviewing the viability of the scheme. Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths expressed support for the scheme but called for clarity from the UK government. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism, stating they had shared a vast amount of information and data with the developer.

The announcement of a new agri-food marketing body was made by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster. The agri-food industry in Northern Ireland is crucial, employing almost 100,000 people in various sectors such as farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The new marketing body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities. This body will work to coordinate government and private sector marketing efforts. Stormont's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the initiative, noting the importance of the agri-food sector in driving export-led economic growth. She acknowledged the need for better coordination of marketing activities and described the new body as a positive step, but also highlighted potential implications for other organizations. Discussions with the AFSB are planned to address these implications.

Members of the public are invited to plant thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon. The Woodland Trust is organizing this project, which is one of four new woods being created across the UK to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. The project aims to plant millions of native UK trees and uses the pledge: "We will stand for those who fell." In Brackfield Wood, the conservation charity plans to plant 40,000 trees in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The trust is inviting local people and visitors to get involved and make a mark on history by planting a tree. The director, Patrick Cregg, hopes many people will join and roll up their sleeves to plant a tree. By the end of the project, the aim is to have 40,000 native trees planted at Brackfield, with carpets of wildflowers including poppies. The charity is providing the saplings for the public to plant and advises volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear. Brackfield Wood is located about seven miles outside Derry city, just off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available. The trees will stand as a living, growing tribute to the people from Ireland who played a part in the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate. The book, Someone Else's Skin, is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. It tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime. The book was praised for its writing and plot. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Paretsky's work was described as a "game changer" for female writers in crime fiction. She also set up Sisters In Crime, an organisation to support female crime writers. The festival's programming chair, Ann Cleeves, said the shortlist was strong and praised the winning book's writing and plot.

Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. Steve Rhodes, the director of cricket, said Santner's injury was a big blow to the team's hopes of qualifying. Santner will rejoin Worcestershire after the ICC Trophy in June. He is looking forward to making an impact with both bat and ball. Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that the car had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. The coroner was satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that Barry Pring was unlawfully killed, based on circumstantial evidence. The case was difficult to investigate due to being abroad, and the coroner offered condolences to the family. Close friend Peter Clifford believed Barry was murdered. Ms Ziuzina, 19 years younger than her husband, tried to claim his assets shortly after his death. The family believes he was killed in a staged hit and run. The couple met online in 2006 and married in 2007. Ms Ziuzina was described as a lap dancer and stripper, not a teacher as she claimed. She sold her husband's assets and was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. Ukrainian police closed the case initially but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, though it is not actively pursued. Ms Ziuzina did not attend the inquest and stated she had nothing further to add. The coroner could not get her to attend the inquest.

Sophie Fearns's son Charlie, from Merseyside, needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital for more T-Cell Therapy, as the previous treatment failed. The treatment is not available in the UK. After a third relapse, there were no further treatment options in the UK. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, leaving his family "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed". The family received confirmation via email from the hospital. The treatment will start as soon as possible, and they expect to know the date next week.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification process for iCloud accounts to prevent unauthorized access. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering their username and password on a new device. This measure was implemented in response to the recent celebrity photo leaks, where third-party software was used to access iCloud accounts. The two-step verification is an opt-in feature, but experts suggest it should be the default setting. Users can regain access to their account using a 14-character recovery key if they lose their trusted device. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves stated that the details of a potential deal where Joey Wright could buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club are still being worked out. The Sun reported that Wright would also become a club director. Billericay Town are currently in eighth place in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from the play-off spots. Joey Wright, who finished as runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has played non-league football for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. Billericay Town signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

The Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, has asked Mike Ashley to give evidence about the treatment of workers at Sports Direct's warehouse in Derbyshire. This follows a BBC investigation into working practices at the company. Ashley has until 21 March to respond to the letter. He had invited the committee to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook, but the committee prefers to meet in public at Westminster. Ashley has not accepted any of the offered dates for a meeting. The committee has warned that if Ashley does not agree to attend, they may take the matter further, including seeking support from the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment, but the company has previously pledged to review worker rights with oversight by Mike Ashley, who also owns Newcastle United Football Club.

The report, "Putin. War," was never completed by the murdered opposition politician, but his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin, have since finished it. The report is based on facts that have appeared in media since Crimea's annexation in March 2014 and the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The report argues that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, despite Russia's denial of sending troops and equipment to help rebels. The report presents evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial to the rebels' victories, with soldiers admitting they were directed by Russian generals. The dossier estimates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles, and it includes details of military units and weaponry. The opposition plans to seek donations to extend the print run of the report, but they face challenges in publishing and distributing it due to fear among publishers and the public's potential disinterest. The report's authors accuse Putin of using the war to boost his popularity, which they admit has been successful. The report may not galvanize protests against Putin, as previous works by Nemtsov failed to do.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries, according to a post-mortem. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

The passage discusses the differing views between Carwyn Jones, the first minister, and the UK government, led by Prime Minister Theresa May, regarding the Article 50 letter. Carwyn Jones was not shown the letter before it was published, a fact he shares with most of Mrs May's cabinet. He expressed dissatisfaction with the process, stating that the devolved administrations, including Wales, have been treated with a lack of respect. The UK government, however, argues that it is acting in the interests of the whole UK, with the Prime Minister mentioning Wales in the letter to Donald Tusk. The letter states that there will be a significant increase in the decision-making power of each devolved administration, but it is unclear which specific powers will be devolved and whether the funding will follow these powers. The Welsh Secretary, Alun Cairns, believes that the UK government has been in communication about the contents of the letter for months. The passage also raises questions about the future of EU funding and powers in Wales post-Brexit, with concerns that there may not be adequate funding to accompany the devolved powers after 2020. The details about which powers will be devolved remain unclear, with a promise of more information in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill expected on Thursday.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in Newry on Friday night. PSNI officers were attacked while carrying out their duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay at the attacks on both the officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

The board of American Apparel filed a court document in San Francisco stating that they do not expect Dov Charney, the company's founder and former CEO, to return to the firm. Mr. Charney was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board's filing includes evidence of inappropriate emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts by Mr. Charney. The company claims that Mr. Charney's behavior violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. Mr. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, responded that many of the statements made by the company were false and accused the company of invading Mr. Charney's privacy. The board argues that Mr. Charney's actions would make it difficult for any company to hire him due to the risks involved. Earlier this month, American Apparel was granted a restraining order against Mr. Charney, preventing him from making negative statements about the company and attempting to remove board members.

The game between Great Britain and Greece will be streamed on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Greece won the previous encounter 92-64 in Patras, Greece, but three of their players will be missing for the rematch at the Copper Box in London. GB guard Teddy Okereafor is excited to play in his hometown and believes the match will be a good preparation for EuroBasket 2017. The game will be Britain's only home game before they compete at EuroBasket, which starts in September. After the Greece game, GB will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland for their last warm-up games. The game will be broadcast from 17:30-19:30 BST on the mentioned platforms.

The passage describes the introduction of the iPhone in 2007 and its impact on technology and society. The author, a journalist, recounts how he was able to get an exclusive look at the iPhone before its release after initially turning down an interview with Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller. He reflects on the initial skepticism towards the iPhone's significance, comparing it to the Model T Ford and questioning whether it would be as transformative. The author later acknowledges the iPhone's role in changing how people use technology, particularly in photography and other activities on the move. The passage also mentions that while there were other devices with similar features before the iPhone, it was Apple's user interface that made the technology more accessible and appealing to the masses. The author concludes by expressing gratitude for witnessing the beginning of the mobile connected era, noting that while other companies like Amazon and Google are now leading with AI innovations, the iPhone's launch was a pivotal moment in history.

The RSPCA confirmed that cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray have ingested antifreeze. In the most recent case, a seven-month-old cat named Meereen died on Monday. Three other cats have died in the last seven days, and another cat died two weeks ago. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, was devastated by the loss. The cat was found foaming at the mouth and trying to vomit. The RSPCA confirmed that Meereen had ingested antifreeze. The RSPCA inspector, Andy Bostock, is appealing for everyone in the area to store pesticides and chemicals safely. He is concerned about the poisonings, which may be accidental or deliberate, and it is the time of year when antifreeze is used in cars. People are advised to check for leaks and clean up any spills.

The passage discusses the lack of protests in Athens despite the Syriza government's agreement to implement austerity measures. It notes that Greece's resorts are busy, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. The passage suggests that tourists may be avoiding areas closer to the so-called Islamic State. It questions why Greeks are not protesting against announced austerity measures, such as VAT increases and pension cuts, and anticipates further measures like reductions in farm subsidies, privatisations, and increased competition.

The passage suggests that the Syriza government, led by Alexis Tsipras, has changed its stance on austerity due to Greece's near-death experience in July, which led to bank closures and economic collapse. Despite this, Tsipras remains popular. The passage highlights that Greece is suffering from both fiscal and monetary austerity, with banks unable to lend and businesses lacking confidence.

The passage concludes by stating that for the new bailout to be successful, creditors should ease Greece's debt burden by a significant amount. It suggests that avoiding triumphalism and showing debt forgiveness would be necessary for a genuine recovery in Greece.

Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders to portray Grant Mitchell, reuniting the character with his mother Peggy, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, before her character's death from cancer. Kemp, who last played the role in 2006, was approached to return for Windsor's final episodes. The storyline will bring the Mitchell family together, with Grant returning to Albert Square to be with his mother and brother Phil. The episodes featuring Peggy's death are set to air in the spring. Grant Mitchell is a significant character in EastEnders' history, known for his dramatic family storylines. His return is expected to be emotional and is anticipated to showcase strong performances from Kemp and McFadden.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was found guilty of murdering Alice Ruggles in October 2016. He had stalked her and became obsessed with her. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed of her death by two Northumbria Police officers. Upon hearing the news, they immediately suspected Dhillon. Sue Hills expressed guilt for not taking the situation more seriously when Alice had expressed concerns about Dhillon. Two days before her death, Sue reassured Alice that everything would be okay and that ignoring Dhillon would make him stop. However, her other daughter Emma warned her that Dhillon was dangerous, but Sue dismissed her concerns. After Alice's death, Sue felt responsible for not acting on Emma's warning. Alice's parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. They want Alice to be remembered for her vibrant personality and to help others avoid a similar fate. Dhillon was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison for the murder.

The Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project in Somerset, valued at £18bn, has received funding approval from French firm EDF, which is financing most of the project. However, the UK government has decided to conduct a further review before backing the project. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement and is seen as a significant investment for both French and British industries. The project has faced criticism over potential environmental damage, escalating costs, and concerns about foreign government involvement, as one third of the cost is being provided by Chinese investors. EDF's board approved the investment despite financial concerns, with the company raising €4bn (£3.4bn) to help pay for the project. The UK government's decision to review the project has been met with calls for a swift decision to avoid energy supply issues and to meet climate commitments. Environmentalists argue for more investment in renewable energy sources instead.

The newly-designed form for applying for a divorce in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom the spouse has committed adultery. Family lawyers are concerned that naming a third party increases conflict and complexity in divorce proceedings. The form's guidance states that it is "not normally necessary" to name the third party, but lawyers fear that the presence of the box will encourage people to fill it in. If the third party is named, they become part of the court case, receive copies of the paperwork, and have the opportunity to respond. This can delay proceedings and incur more costs. Adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces out of 100,000 in 2015, while "unreasonable behaviour" accounted for 46,815. The Ministry of Justice states that there is no obligation to name the third party, and this has always been the case. Judges take a dim view of petitioners who try to involve new partners in the proceedings.

The forestry industry in Wales is worth over £450m a year to the Welsh economy. Confor, which promotes the forestry industry, warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted to meet needs. The Welsh government encourages commercial forestry organisations to invest in woodland creation through its Glastir scheme. There is a conflict between environmental policy, which wants more native, broadleaf species of trees, and the forestry industry, which is concerned about the loss of conifer forests. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development. However, the industry faces challenges such as bureaucracy in creating new woodland areas and difficulty in meeting long-term targets for planting. The industry believes there is a huge market for timber, but current production is limited by the availability of timber.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street. Emergency crews responded to the incident at around 16:40 and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

The Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys. Able seaman Charles Lewis, 91, from Calmore, Hampshire, was "honoured and delighted" to receive the medal. The Foreign Office initially did not allow Russia to honour the veterans as it broke the rules on foreign medals. The Russian embassy said the convoys allowed Russian soldiers to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012 following a long campaign for the convoy veterans to be recognized. The Foreign Office allowed an "exception to the rules" last year and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests. Mr Lewis, like many of his colleagues, did not see himself as a hero, but as someone who was "simply doing his bit for the war effort." The Arctic Convoys consisted of vessels which travelled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II. They faced constant threats of attack by German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, and thousands of Allied seamen lost their lives.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their unpaid work, and too many offenders were let off if they did not attend. In one case, an offender had completed just 16 hours in 17 months. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing how often offenders are turned away from work when they have reported on time and creating objectives for unpaid work that match the circumstances of the offender. The Ministry of Justice said it was acting on the report's recommendations. The unpaid work, or "community payback," is given for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offences, or criminal damage, and can range from 40 to 300 hours. The government had ordered 10,000 orange bibs for offenders to wear during unpaid work, but the difficulty has always been in organizing the offenders, many of whom lead chaotic lives with drink or drug problems. The chief inspector of probation called for "urgent remedial action" as the report found that in most cases unpaid work was viewed simply as a punishment, which was a "wasted opportunity". The Ministry of Justice wants "much more effective rehabilitation" and is taking action to implement the report's recommendations.

The paper's front page headline called the comedian a "hypocrite" because he campaigns for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, yet he lives in a luxury home. This accusation is not new, as viewers of his vlogs are familiar with his spacious London home. When asked about his own accommodation, Brand called the reporter "a snide" and walked off. Brand has been accused of hypocrisy before and has explained that he is aware of his wealth and the need for personal change. He believes that systemic change is necessary to address inequality and that his wealth should be shared, but without systemic change, this would be a futile gesture. He argues that the accusations are a way to keep inequality off the agenda, and that his own hypocrisy is a problem that can be addressed incrementally.

The passage discusses Dr. J Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race. He was criticized by the scientific community but his work sped up the process. After the human genome was published, Dr. Venter focused on creating a synthetic life form, which he and his team at the J Craig Venter Institute achieved and published in Science. Born in 1946, Dr. Venter initially pursued surfing before being drafted into the Vietnam War, which inspired him to become a doctor and instilled a sense of urgency in his work. During his medical training, he excelled in research and developed a method to sequence genes more efficiently. This led to his departure from the NIH in 1992 to establish a private research institute. In 1998, he founded Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome in three years, competing with the public project. Both projects published their results in 2001. Dr. Venter's disregard for scientific conventions brought him criticism but also financial success, allowing him to pursue his interests without traditional funding. He later formed the J Craig Venter Institute and worked on creating synthetic life, which he announced as a breakthrough. He also collected marine life forms for genetic sequencing. Dr. Venter believes synthetic microbes could help wean society off oil and reverse environmental damage.

The survey found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents questioned said their children had asked for these new foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research was commissioned by England's School Food Trust after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought their children were too fussy to eat school meals. The survey, conducted among about 1,000 parents, found that school meals can encourage children to try new foods and increase the variety of foods in their diet. School meals in England now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines. About 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. In Scotland, about 46% of primary school children eat school lunches. The survey was conducted online between 26 February and 5th March among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4-17 years old.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish footballer, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. His transfer to Juventus included a buyback clause for Real Madrid, with a reported fee of up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata has scored three goals for Spain at Euro 2016. During his time at Juventus, he won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia trophies, scoring 27 goals in two years. He has played in back-to-back Champions League finals, first as a substitute in Real Madrid's 2014 win and then as a player for Juventus in their 2015 defeat by Barcelona. Morata came through the ranks at Real Madrid, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the club.

Wilson rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the club, having spent four seasons there before. He has been without a team since being released in May 2017. Wilson has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, has sold its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles based private equity company. The deal involves around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees transferring to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business Â£80m and will close the remaining 50 stores. The transaction will cost Tesco Â£150m, but part of this is a loan that may be repaid. If the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April 2013.

The passage discusses an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it. He considered representing France but decided against it. His goal is to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. For those interested in martial arts, there is a guide available.

The ice fields on Mont Blanc and the surrounding mountains in the European Alps covered about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s. By the late 2000s, this area had fallen to about 275 sq km, representing an average loss of some 26% over the last 40 years. The research was presented at the AGU Fall Meeting. The French Alps glaciers inventory assessed roughly 600 glaciers in various massifs, including the Mont Blanc Massif. The team used map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to verify the accuracy of automatic delineation methods. The only existing glacial inventory from the French Alps was published four decades ago, finding the overall area of ice to be about 375 sq km. Since then, the retreat has accelerated, with the area being reduced to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the southern sectors experiencing greater losses. The Belledonne Massif has seen almost complete disappearance of glaciers, while the Ecrins Massif has experienced more than three times stronger retreat than the Mont Blanc Massif. The northern Alps, including the biggest French glacier La Mer de Glace, have experienced less retreat due to lower elevation and different climatic conditions, such as more precipitation and cloud cover.

The Scots are in a strong position to qualify for the 2017 Women's European Championship after winning all five of their qualifiers so far. They host Iceland on Friday, with a win likely to secure their place in the finals. The team has narrowly missed out on qualifying for major competitions in the past, and a failure to qualify this time would be devastating for the players. Iceland are also unbeaten in the group, and the outcome of the two matches between the teams will likely decide who tops the group. The best six runners-up will also qualify automatically, so Scotland are in a strong position to reach the finals without a play-off. The match against Iceland is seen as a tough test, but the Scots are confident they can win. The Scottish team benefits from having players in top leagues around the world, including Germany, England, Sweden, and the United States. This experience helps improve the national team's performance.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England on Friday. The arrest followed a complaint from a woman in south London who alleged harassment over a two-year period. The harassment is said to have taken place online, specifically through tweets. Mr Campbell, who was released on bail, stated that the tweets were not threatening and accused the media of spreading innuendo. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the online harassment allegation. Mr Campbell has been bailed to a date in mid-September pending further inquiries. He clarified that the allegations relate solely to some tweets from his Twitter account, which are still publicly visible and not threatening in nature.

The People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) wants the Skegness Jolly Fisherman mascot to be replaced with a modern, animal-friendly version. Peta suggests a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, welcomes all suggestions but does not think there will be much support for replacing Jolly. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908 to encourage visitors to take the train to Skegness. The poster, featuring the slogan "Skegness is so bracing", has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. Peta's Dawn Carr argues that the Jolly Fisherman evokes images of cruelty to animals, but Mayor Macey insists Jolly is loved by all and does not represent animal cruelty. He says the council will consider Peta's suggestion, but if it isn't broken, they won't try to fix it.

Scotland defeated Georgia 43-16 in their international match. The Scots scored six tries, with Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (twice), and Hamish Watson all crossing the line. The Georgians scored two tries, both by Vasil Lobzhanidze. Scotland's dominance in possession and territory in the first half led to a 24-11 lead at halftime. Georgia's scrum caused problems for Scotland in the second half, resulting in a penalty try for the visitors. Despite this, Scotland managed to secure their victory with a strong finish.

Widnes Vikings secured a 38-30 victory over Castleford Tigers in the Super League. Widnes led 14-6 at halftime with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge. Paddy Flynn scored for Castleford in the first half and added another early in the second half. However, tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor extended Widnes' lead to 38-12. Despite three tries in four minutes from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick score, Widnes held on for the win. Widnes moved up to seventh place in the standings, while Castleford remain in sixth, one point above Widnes. The victory had looked assured for Widnes after Joe Mellor's try following a short kick-off, but Castleford's late tries made for a nervy finish. The match ended with Widnes securing the win despite Castleford's late fightback.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. His lawyer said he was excited and joyful about returning home. The Periodic Review Board determined his detention was no longer necessary. As part of his release, he will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. His release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo Bay to 148. The US opened the facility in 2002 following the 9/11 attacks and President Obama has promised to close it.

Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and up to 400 people took part in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph on Anzac Day. This day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung as the service ended. The first Anzac Day service in the capital was held in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service. Since then, these services have become an important moment for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians to honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowds, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the heroism of the Anzac troops. The ceremony at the Cenotaph included members of veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel, and their families, and featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war and the allied operation was an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has rejoined Well and could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has mainly been a substitute this term. Clarkson is fit and ready to play, having maintained his match fitness by playing for the U20s. He has played for several teams, including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, and has two international caps for Scotland with one goal. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of Alloa. Clarkson believes that winning games will boost their confidence and help them move up the table.

Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. There were concerns about the future of workers' pension schemes under new ownership, but Unite union reported productive talks with Boparan representatives. Guarantees were given that all current agreements, including pension schemes, would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and current members have an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan confirmed that the current pension arrangements would continue. The new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through investment, cost savings, and using spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The council leader Dave Stewart announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July to acknowledge the problems with the new ferry. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has experienced several issues since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, running aground, and being suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Cars have been damaged getting on and off the ferry. Local businesses have suffered due to the ferry's problems, and the council is considering compensation for them. The transport councillor Ian Ward stated that the ferry is a prototype and that teething problems are expected. The council has authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the issue of vehicles scraping the concrete. Groundings have been attributed to seamanship issues, which have been resolved.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report that looks at the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The report warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall Brexit deal. Fishing regions around the UK voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU during the referendum campaign, hoping to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the Lords say these communities are at risk of being marginalised in the wider Brexit negotiations due to the small contribution of the fishing industry to the UK's GDP and employment. The UK fishing industry produces only 0.5% of GDP and employs 12,000 fishers.

The report highlights that the UK's fishing industry needs continued market access to the EU, as the majority of UK fish are exported to the EU, while a significant proportion of fish consumed in Britain is imported, often from EU states. The Lords suggest that market access may come at the cost of allowing more EU access to UK waters. The report also recommends retaining elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), such as total allowable catches and quotas based on scientific advice, and continuing international cooperation with neighboring states.

The Lords are concerned that if Britain leaves the EU, the CFP framework will fall away, potentially leading to four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry believe Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats, expecting fairer shares in catching opportunities and better fisheries management outside the EU.

The government has stated that it aims to ensure maximum freedom for British companies to trade with and operate in the single market while reviewing fisheries management to ensure fair access to quota, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney was removed from the teaching profession's register after admitting to taking or permitting indecent images of children. He was sentenced in February 2014 and ordered to take part in a sex offenders program. The General Teaching Council Scotland hearing concluded that his conduct was incompatible with being a teacher and that he had failed to uphold professional standards. The panel found him unfit to teach and removed him from the professional register for two years due to the nature and duration of his offenses.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street after a blaze on 2 March. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, according to the fire service. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months and raised concerns to the EA in February. The EA decided to take enforcement action against the site operators and revoked the environmental permit, effective on 7 August. The cause of the fire remains undetermined. The company is required to remove all the waste.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way from Damascus to Latakia. Mr Mekdad blamed "terrorist groups" for the attacks and said that Syria is in a war, urging the US and others to take this into consideration. He also criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, insisting that Syria is defending its people against terrorist attacks and denying the use of barrel bombs on civilians. The Syrian government also denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while activist groups claimed otherwise. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% having left the country so far. The US and Russia have expressed concerns over the delays in the destruction process, which is being overseen by the OPCW. Mr Mekdad reiterated Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council, promising to implement all obligations on time.

England won the second Test against Pakistan by an innings and 137 runs at Old Trafford, leveling the series at 1-1. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. England's performance was praised by former England captain Michael Vaughan, who described it as "an absolute hammering" and "as good a four days of cricket that you could wish for from an England point of view." Root's promotion to number three in the batting order was seen as a success, with captain Alastair Cook commending his performance. Pakistan's batting was criticized for their lack of high scores and inability to capitalize on a pitch that offered little assistance to bowlers. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott attributed Pakistan's defeat to their "broken spirit." Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged the team's disappointment and expressed hope that they would recover their confidence for the third Test at Edgbaston.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence by listening to the experiences of pensioners and their friends and families. The evidence will be used to create recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The commissioner aims to highlight both good care and the impact of poor care on older people. She has traveled across Wales to meet older people in residential care and has observed both positive and negative aspects of their care.

Rochira will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment to determine if older people have a good quality of life. Her team will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The commissioner believes that giving a voice to older people and their families will help those accountable for social services understand the realities of living in residential care and take necessary actions to improve quality of life.

Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that no provider expert is included on the main advisory panel. He believes that the absence of a provider expert misses an opportunity for partnership working and full engagement of the sector in the review process.

Paul Sheerin, a former Aberdeen player and Arbroath manager, has been appointed as the new Aberdeen assistant manager. He replaces Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Sheerin, 39, has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013-14. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser said Sheerin was chosen after a comprehensive process. Sheerin won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s and guided Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea want to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as their first choice. Curtis believes the new manager must be able to keep Swansea in the Premier League, as relegation to the Championship would be difficult to recover from. Swansea have not been the same since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, according to Curtis, who says the club has lost its way and not adequately replaced key players. Curtis reminds new players of the club's history and rise from near bankruptcy to the Premier League, hoping to instill a sense of importance in staying up.

The passage discusses Dr. J Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race. He was criticized by the scientific community but his work helped speed up the process. After the human genome project, Dr. Venter worked on creating a synthetic life form, which he named Synthia. He was born in 1946 and initially did not excel in school. During the Vietnam conflict, he was inspired to become a doctor and developed a sense of urgency. He later excelled in research and developed a method to sequence genes at unprecedented rates. His work was criticized by some, including James Watson, but he continued his research outside of public funding. In 2001, both Dr. Venter's private company and the public project published their results of the human genome. He later formed the J Craig Venter Institute to create a synthetic life form and has also collected marine life forms for genetic research. The synthetic life breakthrough was controversial, but Dr. Venter believes it could lead to an industrial revolution and help the environment.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short compared to those in other European countries, particularly Germany. The report highlights that only 200,000 out of 520,000 apprenticeships are rated at level three, equivalent to A-levels. It also notes that only one in five employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to over half in Germany. The report calls for an expansion of apprenticeships, with 300,000 new starts each year, the majority at level three or higher. The Department for Education states that apprenticeships are being reformed to improve standards. The Association of Colleges agrees with the need for high-quality apprenticeships but argues that some level two apprenticeships are respected by industry and should be preserved. The report also criticizes the complexity of England's vocational system, with 18,000 qualifications compared to Germany's 330. The Sutton Trust chairman, Sir Peter Lampl, states that the current system is not respected and does not provide clear vocational routes, which is crucial for social mobility.

The Briton, Sarah Storey, won the women's C5 time trial at the UCI Para-cycling Road World Championships in Nottwil, Switzerland. She finished more than two minutes ahead of the second place, Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, who is 37 years old, has 22 Paralympic medals, including 11 golds, and 21 world titles across swimming and cycling. She is aiming for more success at the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. Storey started her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, and switched to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United have been expelled from the Conference Premier due to their failure to pay football creditors. The club was given multiple extensions to meet the payment deadline, but ultimately did not comply. The club's financial troubles have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, with debts totaling approximately £225,000. The Conference had offered a final deadline of Thursday, 12 June, which Hereford did not meet. The club was taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar last week, but this did not resolve the financial issues. The last team to be expelled from the Conference was Chester City in 2010, who later reformed as Chester FC. Hereford's expulsion leaves a vacancy in the Conference Premier, which has been filled by Chester, who were relegated on the final day of the season. Players from the Hereford team that played on the final day of the season have since moved to other clubs, including Chester FC. The Bulls' fate has been met with disappointment from fans and players alike, who feel let down by the club's management.

James Milner has retired from international football. He won 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships but played just three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. He cited common sense as the reason for his decision to retire and wished the team success in the future.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after a several months' long illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later. Hogwood was a prominent figure in the early-music movement and founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973. He worked with many leading orchestras around the world and made over 200 CDs, including a famous recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various positions in the music industry. He was considered a generous and influential figure in the music world, and his work has had a lasting impact on many musicians.

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs has been unable to attend a special school due to lack of available places. His family removed him from mainstream schooling because he was not coping. They requested a place at a special school in June but are still waiting. In September, they were told all the special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full. The boy's mother said he misses being around people and feels isolated. An extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, and the family hopes he will start there in the next few weeks. The mother is worried this situation will happen to other families as the special needs school system is at capacity. The Education Authority cannot comment on individual cases but is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability close to where children reside, with changes planned for 2016.

Newport County have a lease to use Rodney Parade until 2023 and expect this contract to be honored. The Welsh Rugby Union is attempting a takeover of the Newport Gwent Dragons and sees Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. The takeover will be voted on by shareholders on Tuesday, 9 May. Newport County are currently in League Two and are two points clear of relegation with two games remaining. Relegation to the National League would be a significant blow to the club and its supporters. The Football League does not allow artificial surfaces, which the WRU has expressed interest in installing at Rodney Parade. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey has stated that both Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements.

The passage describes the life of a man who was kidnapped by rebels at the age of 15 during Sierra Leone's civil war. He was forced to use drugs and commit atrocities, including killing, under the influence of drugs. He managed to escape and met a preacher who encouraged him to continue his education and become a leader in rebuilding the nation. When the Ebola crisis hit Sierra Leone in 2014, he and his team started an Ebola treatment clinic, educated people about the virus, and provided support to affected communities. The clinic saved many lives, and he now believes in investing in young people to change the world. Sierra Leone was declared free of Ebola in 2016, with a total of 3,955 deaths in the country over 18 months.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of about 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs was at risk of being auctioned to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign hit its target in just a month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before it is loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. The successful outcome was achieved through complex negotiations. The museum inherited the pension bill after the firm collapsed in 2009, and a high court judge ruled in 2011 that the collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. The collection is important to Staffordshire and was at risk of being sold and scattered around the globe. The preservation of the collection is seen as crucial for understanding Britain's cultural development and national identity.
