Dan Groves stated that the details of a potential deal where Joey Wright could buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club are still being worked out. Wright, who finished second on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has a background in non-league football with clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay Town are currently in eighth place in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from the play-off spots. The club has recently been taken over by millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. Billericay Town also signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso's pinpoint chip was turned in by Jamille Matt from three yards. Colchester equalized from a corner in the 17th minute with Kurtis Guthrie scoring from close range after a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool's Sam Slocombe made a sensational save to deny Matthew Briggs and later another brilliant save from George Elokobi's close-range effort. Guthrie then hit the bar from two yards out just before halftime. In the second half, Tom Aldred missed a chance to give Blackpool the lead from eight yards out. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was shown a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The Fawley power station chimney will be transformed into a tourist attraction, becoming the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. This will be part of a Â£1bn development called Fawley Waterside, which will include a marina, housing, and restaurants. The power station closed in 2013 after more than 40 years in operation. The development will feature a petal-shaped glass structure and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The oil-fired power station was capable of powering one million homes and had an 198 metre-high chimney. The site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016. Aldred Drummond of the company said it would be "mad" to knock the chimney down, as it is their signature piece of infrastructure. The developers plan to apply for outline planning permission later this year, with building potentially starting in 2018.

Core pieces of information from the passage:
1. British cyclist Ryan Latham won a bronze medal in the men's omnium at the Hong Kong Track Cycling World Championships.
2. Elinor Barker won a silver medal in the women's scratch race earlier in the competition.
3. Latham finished behind Adrian Teklinski of Poland (gold) and Lucass Liss of Germany (silver).
4. In the men's team pursuit, Great Britain did not win a medal, losing to Italy for the bronze.
5. Joe Truman, the sole British rider in the men's keirin, did not advance to the final.
6. The women's team pursuit team, including Elinor Barker, finished fifth in the heats and did not compete for a medal.
7. The women's team pursuit squad is young, with an average age of 19, and has potential for improvement.
8. Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.
9. Marchant is scheduled to compete in the 500m time-trial and keirin events.
10. The athletes are preparing for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders to play Grant Mitchell, reuniting with his on-screen mother Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, before her character dies from cancer. Kemp last played the role in 2006. The storyline will be aired in the spring. Grant Mitchell is a significant character in the soap's history, known for his dramatic family storylines. His return is expected to feature some classic EastEnders episodes.

Sadio Mane scored twice as Liverpool beat Tottenham 2-0 at Anfield. Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino was critical of his team's performance, saying they lacked desire and were not ready to fight for the Premier League. He believes that if Chelsea extend their lead to 12 points, it will be a big problem for Tottenham. Tottenham have struggled on the road, winning just twice since September and losing to other top-six teams. Pochettino stated that if his team cannot cope with the pressure, it will be difficult to challenge for the Premier League. Former Tottenham and Liverpool midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Tottenham's defensive performance, saying they were all over the place and lacked pace away from home. He suggested they should have stuck with their previous formation against big sides. Tottenham need to improve quickly.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost the presidential poll last month for the first time, with Muhammadu Buhari of the APC set to be inaugurated as president on 29 May. The PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, but lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge for President-elect Buhari in dealing with militant groups. The elections were generally peaceful, but there were 66 violent incidents reported, mostly in southern states. The PDP will need to rebuild itself after its defeat, as voters sought change after 16 years of PDP rule.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival can use an app to access online information about signs and posters at the site. The app will provide videos and band interviews. The festival takes place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The festival director, Caroline Maclennan, said the augmented reality experience will add to the enjoyment of the festival and allow people around the world to interact with it. The app will be updated leading up to and during the festival, providing instant access to information and interviews, as well as ticket purchasing.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were also rated inadequate and warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools said parents tried to undermine her authority and descended on the school during an Ofsted inspection. The head teacher felt alone until the news of the Trojan Horse letter broke. The Department for Education has criticized the way Park View School was run and has decided to terminate its funding agreement. Similar letters were sent to Nansen Primary and Oldknow Academy, with Golden Hillock also receiving a letter with a list of demands to be completed by 4 July. The Ofsted report into Park View School said the academy's work to keep students safe, including from extremism, was inadequate. Parents at the schools have criticized the Ofsted reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, is accused of failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution alleges that her failure to do so was "criminal" and that Vinnie's death was preventable. Ms Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into having sex with a man he found on an adult website and filming the act. He sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg was convicted of causing the victim's sister and father to view sexual images and of threatening behavior. He was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to the severity of his crimes. Weatherhogg was assessed as a moderate risk of re-offending and was placed on the sex offenders register. The victim felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. The judge stated that the sentence must reflect society's abhorrence of such conduct. Weatherhogg's defense lawyer stated that being placed on remand was a "dramatic shock" for him.

Ireland made 165-5 in their innings, with Stuart Thompson hitting 56, Gary Wilson 41 not out, and William Porterfield 39. Afghanistan won the match with two overs to spare, with Samiullah Shenwari scoring 56 and Mohammad Shahzad 47. Ireland opener Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck early on. Ireland's total was not enough as Afghanistan reached their victory target with the help of an opening stand of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai. Ireland's captain William Porterfield felt they fell short of a potentially very big score and did not execute their bowling as well as they would have liked. Ireland lost paceman Boyd Rankin to a back problem for the T20s, but he is expected to return for the five ODIs starting on 15 March.

Barcelona have paid an additional 13.55 million euros in tax related to the signing of Neymar. The club insists it has not committed any offense and that the payment is to cover possible interpretations of the contracts. The total cost of Neymar to the club is now 106.8 million pounds. The initial fee was 48.6 million pounds, with his parents receiving 34 million pounds of that fee. Barcelona's former president Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid accusations of misappropriating money related to the transfer. A judge in Spain has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona maintains that the original tax payment was in line with their obligations.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Metropolitan Police officers went to Thailand last month to work with Thai police on the case. The UK detectives have now completed their work and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, have been arrested and charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery. They could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the police investigation, particularly regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. The UK police visit came after the Thai Prime Minister agreed to British assistance following a meeting with Prime Minister Cameron. Post-mortem examinations showed Mr Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Ms Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police say DNA found on Ms Witheridge matches samples taken from the suspects.

The Scots women's football team have won all five qualifiers for the 2019 World Cup and are set to play Iceland in a crucial match on Friday. A win would all but secure their place in the finals. Kim Little, the BBC Women's Footballer of the Year, plays for Seattle Reign in the United States. 24-year-old Bayern Munich forward Lana Evans, who has also played for Glasgow City and Turbine Potsdam, is one of 12 players in the squad who play outside Scotland. The team is in pole position to reach the finals without the need for a play-off. Iceland are also unbeaten and a win for Scotland would be a significant step towards their goal of reaching the finals. Evans is determined not to miss out again after previous play-off losses and believes that playing in top leagues like Germany's has improved the national team. The presence of players from different leagues and cultures adds to the national team's strength.

Apple has introduced a new security measure to protect iCloud accounts. The measure is called two-step verification and requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering their username and password on a new device. This process should prevent unauthorized access to iCloud accounts, even if a hacker has the user's password. However, the two-step verification is an opt-in feature, meaning users must choose to enable it. An expert suggests that Apple should make this feature the default option for all users. The recovery key, which users need if they lose their trusted device, is a concern as it may be lost or stolen. Despite these concerns, another expert believes that two-factor authentication should be the default for all companies, not just Apple. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The passage provides information about the campaign spending of the six highest-spending parties in the 2014 European election in the UK. UKIP, which won the election, spent £2,956,737, equating to 68p per vote. The Conservatives spent £2,980,815, or 79p per vote. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339, or 26p per vote. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575, or £1.45 per vote, and lost all but one of their MEPs. The Green Party spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. Including the SNP's £267,372, the six parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning. All but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow to join Torquay United in the National League. He has played for Aldershot and Exeter, and has experience in Italy. He could play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, is joining Torquay United after being recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. He has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His move is subject to international clearance. Torquay United manager Kevin Nicholson believes Anderson will be a leader and Keating is hungry to prove himself. Torquay United are currently struggling in the league, having won only one of their last six games and are four points above the relegation zone.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. The horse had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past but had never collapsed before. The British Horseracing Authority is determined to understand what causes these symptoms and prevent them. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime". The report concluded that his death was due to a haemorrhage, not linked to his previous condition of overheating.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament. Alex Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and praised the parliament's journey and growth. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling the pledges made during the referendum campaign. Salmond concluded his speech with gratitude for the honor of serving in the parliament and said, "It's goodbye from me... for now." Tricia Marwick thanked Salmond for his service, and earlier, she was moved to tears by Duncan McNeil's speech. McNeil warned that the parliament must improve its accountability and scrutiny, suggesting there were lessons to be learned from Westminster. Annabel Goldie, another retiring MSP, joked about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. These MSPs are among those stepping down ahead of the election on 5 May.

The upcoming 2017 live-action version of Beauty and the Beast will feature Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Emma Thompson will play Mrs. Potts, a teapot character originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. The film will start shooting in May at Shepperton Studios and is scheduled for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Bill Condon, who directed Dreamgirls and the last two Twilight films, will direct the movie.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will reveal its intentions at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. The meeting is about whether charges should be brought against 23 suspects related to the Hillsborough disaster. The disaster, in which 96 football fans were fatally injured in 1989, was the subject of new inquests last year that concluded the fans had been unlawfully killed. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died, hopes this is the end of the Hillsborough journey. Last January, files of evidence relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS. Of these, 15 relate to Operation Resolve, which investigates the causes of the disaster, and 8 relate to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police. The CPS will inform the families of their decisions at a private meeting in Warrington. Mrs Aspinall says it has been a long struggle for the families and they are waiting with anticipation. She believes it will be a long road but the families are determined to never give up, seeking accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has seen numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall. A former inmate said the jail was notorious for being flooded with contraband like mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice said staff work hard to stop contraband but more must be done. A woman living near the prison said she had seen packages thrown over the wall four times in two weeks. The Ministry of Justice spokeswoman said laws have been introduced to jail people for up to two years for smuggling packages over prison walls, and there is no evidence of drones being used at Chelmsford Prison.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, who was driving a VW Golf, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. He admits hitting Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed his remorse in court, stating he had "turned her world upside down" and that he thought of nothing else but her and her family since the incident. The trial is ongoing.

Eilish McColgan will not compete at the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. She will be focusing on her final year of university and her exams in May. McColgan is disappointed to miss the event but prioritizes her degree. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships and is pleased with her performance. She is considering competing at the World Indoor Championships in March. McColgan believes she has at least two to three more Olympics in her future but is unsure of the events. She is in "reasonable shape" and hopes to run in Birmingham for the World Indoor Championships.

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a site in Chapelizod in Dublin started early on Saturday morning. The area is three acres of Woodlands beside the R112 which runs down to the River Liffey. The search will involve excavations and is expected to take a number of weeks. Earlier this year, a team of six detectives began conducting a complete review of Mr Deely's disappearance. CCTV footage from the night he went missing was enhanced using specialist technology. It shows Mr Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked. He was returning to get an umbrella after the party. Detectives released the footage in April and appealed for the man to come forward. They believe he was the same man captured on CCTV following Mr Deely on Haddington Road. On Saturday, gardaí said the man seen in the CCTV has not yet been identified and they renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro defeated Stan Wawrinka in the second round of Wimbledon. Del Potro, ranked 165th, is making his first Grand Slam appearance since 2014 after recovering from wrist injuries. He won the match 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. Del Potro is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray and will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro expressed his joy and gratitude for the support he received from the crowd and his fellow players, saying he feels "alive" again after his injuries. Nick Kyrgios also advanced, overcoming Dustin Brown in a five-set match. He will next play Feliciano Lopez. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also won their matches.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf during the 2015 tournament. They avoided expulsion after apologizing to Caf. Morocco was only able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban on its participation. The Moroccan FA chief, Fouzi Lekjaa, expressed optimism about the future of both Africa and Morocco in football. Morocco was initially banned and fined $1m (£675,000) for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears, but the fine was reduced to $50,000 (£34,000) by Cas. Equatorial Guinea replaced Morocco as hosts and won the quarter-final match against Tunisia after a controversial penalty. Tunisia's Football Federation (FTF) wrote a letter to Caf, but they denied accusing Caf or the referee of corruption. The FTF vice-president, Maher Snoussi, stated that the issue has been resolved after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal. Tunisia and Morocco have been drawn into different groups for the 2017 Nations Cup in Gabon. Tunisia could set a record by reaching their thirteenth straight Nations Cup.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, including 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently struggling to achieve the same level of success. The team's decline began in 2013, attributed to chassis design issues, despite having the best engine at the time. The current struggles are primarily due to the underperforming Honda power-unit, despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and an unnamed teammate, in their cars. McLaren's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, with periods of success such as the 1988 season where they won 15 out of 16 races with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998, and they narrowly missed out on another in 2007 due to a scandal involving Ferrari technical information. The team's current aim is to return to winning ways, with Ron Dennis, the team's long-time leader, expressing confidence that McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony and win titles again. The team believes their car is among the best this year and that Honda will improve their engine performance next year. The team's success is crucial for the career of Fernando Alonso and the reputation of McLaren.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 for a sudden death. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months and fined Ms O'Neill £3,000 and Mr Thomas £1,000. The defense solicitor admitted that the licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to, and the judge expressed concern that he could not impose a custodial sentence due to the severity of the case and Ms O'Neill's "appalling record".

stephen curry broke his own nba record for most three-pointers in a season, hitting eight in a game against the portland trail blazers. curry scored 45 points and had nine assists as the golden state warriors won 116-105. klay thompson also contributed 26 points to the warriors' victory. lamarcus aldridge had 27 points and damian lillard had 20 points for the blazers. elsewhere, the chicago bulls defeated the miami heat 89-78. pau gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds for the bulls, who overcame a 19-point halftime deficit. aaron brooks and taj gibson each scored 14 points for chicago. the heat missed their first 12 shots after halftime and were outscored 57-27 after the break. hassan whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the heat, while dwyane wade scored just 9 points on 4 for 20 shooting.

A YouTube star named Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, visited Liverpool's training ground, Melwood. The players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were led to believe that he was a competition winner. However, after seeing his skills, they realized he was not a regular fan. Van Velzen impressed the Liverpool players with his dead-ball skills, scoring a free-kick into the top corner. He has become a YouTube sensation by uploading videos of his free-kick exploits. The experience was described as "amazing" by van Velzen, who enjoyed pretending to be less skilled initially. He also surprised Balotelli with a t-shirt featuring Balotelli's famous slogan.

Women with the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by more than 60% if they have their ovaries removed after being diagnosed with breast cancer. A study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that those who underwent oophorectomy after diagnosis had a 77.4% 20-year survival rate. The procedure was particularly beneficial for BRCA1 carriers, reducing breast cancer death risk by 62%. Oophorectomy was associated with a 73% reduction in death for BRCA1 carriers who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis. The protective effect of oophorectomy lasted for 15 years. The study suggests that oophorectomy should be part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early stage breast cancers, particularly those with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. More research is needed, especially on BRCA2 carriers. Angelina Jolie had both a double mastectomy and an oophorectomy due to her BRCA1 gene mutation and stated that these procedures did not affect her sense of femininity.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed when an Amtrak train hit them on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred around 10 am on Sunday, and the train, Amtrak's Carolinian, was heading from Charlotte to New York City. The train continued after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes, and none of the 166 passengers were injured, although one man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The Lowes may have been living in a homeless camp, according to a man who met them while collecting scrap metal. The train was delayed for almost three hours before continuing on its route to its next destination, Raleigh, which is about 25 miles northwest of Durham. The usual travel time from Charlotte to New York City is around 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old informant who worked for the DEA for 27 years, is facing deportation despite promises of US citizenship. Toro was a mid-level member of the Medellin cartel in the 1980s and fled Colombia after a confrontation with his boss. He began working for the DEA as an informant, providing information about his former bosses and associates. Toro was instrumental in the prosecution of several high-profile figures, including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. He was not paid for his work but was promised citizenship. However, after declining health forced him to retire, Toro is now living in the US illegally. The DEA has refused to help him with his citizenship after he went public with his plight. Toro fears for his life if he is deported to Colombia, stating, "if I am sent back to Colombia, I would be dead within the first four hours." Despite his service, Toro remains in limbo, unable to secure a green card or passport, and therefore unable to collect social security benefits.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal actions related to the '.sucks' domain name. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo, and Telus Mobility have been targeted by the '.sucks' domain, which Vox Populi charges $2,499 a year for. ICANN approved the '.sucks' domain but is now reconsidering after complaints from an advisory panel including Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay. Vox Populi CEO John Berard claims the domain is meant for companies to interact with critics, but the Intellectual Property Constituency calls it a 'shakedown scheme.' ICANN is seeking remedies within its contract with Vox Populi and has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. Taylor Swift has also spent money in the past to remove her name from 'adult' domains. Vox Populi plans to offer '.sucks' domains to the public for $10 a year starting in September.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a Sainsbury's bag in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The boy's body was exhumed last year for a case review, and DNA samples led police to his mother. The woman, who concealed her pregnancy and claimed the baby was stillborn, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide. The charge was dropped after she explained the circumstances. The baby was originally buried without a name, but a support group raised money for a headstone naming him Peter after the church. The case remained unsolved for 27 years until police used DNA to identify the mother. The woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied on the 26th anniversary of his discovery, and police have closed the case, stating they do not give up on unsolved cases.

A taxi driver named Michael Young has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger named Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of Young's moving car. The incident occurred in 2010 in Bath, Somerset, when Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to flee without paying the fare. Young decided to drive Hicks back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson, leading to Hicks jumping out of the moving vehicle. The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling Hicks to damages. The exact amount of compensation has not been decided yet, but it is expected to be around 50% of what the family requested, which is thought to be 'hundreds of thousands of pounds'. The compensation is intended to provide specialist rehabilitation and care for Hicks, who now requires round-the-clock care due to his injuries. The judge stated that Young's actions created a significant risk to life and limb, and a 50% reduction in damages was decided upon. The case may be subject to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the final amount Young must pay.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, which is less than 15 miles west of Wichita, but it moved to the northeast, missing the city. CNN's severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous. Reports of tornadoes also came from southwestern Kansas and potentially from Potosi, Missouri, where there was wind damage and flooding. The National Weather Service indicated a tornado may have touched down in Potosi. In addition to tornadoes, hail as large as baseballs was reported. More storms are expected in the midwest, Mississippi River valley, Tennessee River valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

luke rockhold is preparing to fight lyoto machida in new jersey. rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since losing to vitor belfort two years ago and has a title shot in his sights. he plans to be aggressive and dominate machida, comparing their roles to a bull and a matador. rockhold believes he has the speed and skill to exploit machida's weaknesses and win the fight. he respects machida's martial arts background but is confident in his own abilities. machida, on the other hand, is confident in his strategy and believes he can earn a title shot by defeating rockhold. both fighters are coming off victories and are well prepared for the upcoming bout.

The passage describes an incident where a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, landed at the Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida without deploying its landing gear. The plane skidded along the runway on its belly, with its propellers ricocheting off the ground and its wings bouncing from the impact. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, who has been flying for nearly 50 years, managed to take off again and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The video of the incident shows the plane touching down without its landing gear and the video maker noting the sound of the propellers hitting the runway. Despite the damage, the engines remained operational, and the pilot was able to regain control. The most common cause of such a gear-up landing is human error, but mechanical fault can also be a factor. The FAA is investigating the incident.

The passage discusses Yaya Toure's performance and his future at Manchester City. Manuel Pellegrini, the manager, admits disappointment in Toure's performance this season but vows to support him until the end of the season. Manchester City will consider offers for Toure in the summer. Toure, who earns £220,000 a week, has faced criticism for his performances. Pellegrini insists Toure does not need a break and is a very important player who will be backed. Captain Vincent Kompany is out injured, leaving City to face West Ham without him. Goalkeeper Joe Hart says the players are responsible for their poor performances and that Pellegrini has their backing. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warns Aaron Cresswell, who is attracting interest from Manchester City and Chelsea, not to make the same mistake as other English players who moved to City and did not play much. Allardyce cites Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair as examples.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. He was given a seven-year sentence in 1999 by an Italian court for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. In February 2014, he lost his battle against extradition and was told he must return to Italy to serve his sentence. However, it was discovered that his case expired last October, and his European Arrest Warrant is to be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still have to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore's solicitor is confident that the Italian government will withdraw their application for a European Arrest Warrant, and he will be discharged from proceedings. The Crown Prosecution Service admitted to a mistake in failing to serve appeal papers on time, which may have contributed to the outcome. The Italian Supreme Court will make the final decision on the case.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the seven-runner line-up for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. Mr Mole is trained by Paul Nicholls and is bracketed with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, to be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This will be AP McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will not be finalized until Friday morning. It was after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February that McCoy announced his intention to quit riding. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marica was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, recently saw crime scene photos of her daughter's body. Marica's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos. Ritter, who had not seen the photos for several decades, even after Barrett was convicted 33 years later, finally asked to see them last year. She viewed them on a laptop with the help of a lead investigator. Ritter described her daughter's condition in the photos and expressed a desire for revenge. Barrett, who was living in Memphis when arrested in 2006, was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career Grand Slam. He has one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, finishing joint eighth last year. McIlroy held a four-shot lead going into the final round in 2011 but collapsed to an 80, finishing 10 shots behind the winner. However, he bounced back to win his first major title two months later. McIlroy feels the 2011 Masters was the most important day of his career, as it taught him a lot about himself and his game. He hopes to use the golf course as a sanctuary from the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta. McIlroy is looking to claim his first green jacket and become the sixth player to win all four majors, after Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. He believes winning the Masters would make him a complete player, as it is a different test from other majors. McIlroy is aware that it may not be his time to win this year, but he is focused on playing his best and hopes his scores will add up to a win.

This week, several trending stories captured the public's attention. In New York, four rainbows appeared in the sky after heavy rainfall, and Amanda Curtis was fortunate enough to capture this rare sight. In China, the government is cracking down on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes, forcing families to find new ways to entertain mourners. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during an interview when asked about his private life. A new trend called the #kyliejennerchallenge involves using a jar to plump lips like Kylie Jenner's. Alice Barker, a 102-year-old woman, was able to relive her past thanks to filmmakers who helped her watch old footage of herself dancing. A promposal referencing bombs was not allowed by a school, and the promposer accused the school of racism. Ewan McGregor has been cast as Lumiere in the upcoming "Beauty and the Beast" movie, which has generated a lot of social media interest. Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the trailer for "Black Mass." A creative pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombed his son, showcasing originality. These stories all trended this week.

Hundreds of children were admitted to hospital last year after being born brain damaged due to alcohol exposure in the womb. According to the Health and Social Care Information Centre, 272 youngsters with foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England over the past 12 months. The actual number affected by their mother's drinking could be far greater, with the World Health Organization suggesting that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure. This equates to about 7,500 babies per year. Children born with foetal alcohol syndrome do not improve and face lifelong challenges. One example is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who needs help with daily tasks and will never live independently. The government advises pregnant women not to drink alcohol, but if they do, the maximum consumption is up to two units no more than twice a week. However, experts like Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome advocate for a complete ban on alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy.

An axe-wielding robber named Shaun Andrew Mckerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" due to his tendency to return home after committing crimes, attempted to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham. The robbery was foiled when the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled Mckerry to the floor, and his wife, Sam, hit Mckerry with a baseball bat. Mckerry was disarmed and arrested by the police. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in jail. Mckerry had a history of crime, starting shoplifting at age 12 and being arrested 80 times by age 15. He had convictions for various offenses and was known locally as a prolific criminal.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks. They must stay in Nova Scotia until they have been tried. Bail was set at over £2,000 for each of them, but they also agreed to surrender their passports and live at the nearby Stadacona naval base in Halifax. The accused are Joshua Finbow, 23, a submarine engineer, Craig Stoner, 24, Simon Radford, 31, and Darren Smalley, 35. They appeared in court and were given bail conditions that include not leaving the province of Nova Scotia and not applying for new passports. They must remain employed by the navy and cannot resign without the court's permission. The four men were playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team in a tournament at the Shearwater naval base just east of Halifax when the alleged sexual assault occurred on April 10. The victim, in her early 20s and from Halifax, had accompanied a friend who had been invited to the party by local Canadian servicemen. The four sailors are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is still at an early stage, and the results of forensic tests could result in additional charges. The Royal Navy will decide how to employ the sailors while their charges are working their way through the court.

A mother whose son, Rj Jackson, suffers from an incredibly rare disease called Netherton's syndrome, which makes his skin appear scalded, was reported to the police for child abuse. Netherton's syndrome is a congenital skin disease that causes the skin to appear red and scaly, and it affects only about 70 people worldwide. Rj's mother, Valerie Jackson, regularly applies creams to his skin to prevent it from drying out. While shopping, a member of the public mistook Rj's condition for signs of abuse and called the police, resulting in Valerie being surrounded by armed officers. The incident highlights the ignorance surrounding rare diseases and the challenges faced by families dealing with such conditions. Valerie has also faced taunts and accusations from other people, including being denied entry to a play center because of Rj's skin condition. Despite these challenges, Valerie sees her son as beautiful and hopes that as he grows, his condition will become better known and understood. There is no cure for Netherton's syndrome, but parents are advised to regularly cleanse and moisturize their child's skin, and to be vigilant about potential infections due to the inflamed skin.

The Protein World 'Are you beach body ready?' campaign has caused a backlash, with over 50,000 signatures on a petition to remove the adverts. The Transport for London (TFL) has decided to remove the posters as their advertising period has ended. The posters, featuring a bikini-clad model, have been defaced by bloggers and criticized for promoting an unhealthy body image. The Advertising Standards Authority has received over 200 complaints. TFL has stated that they will consider future similar adverts based on customer reactions. A protest against the campaign is planned for May 2 in Hyde Park. Protein World has defended their campaign, stating it is aimed at health-conscious individuals. The company has received threats and a bomb threat, which are being investigated by the police. The campaign has sparked a debate on social media, with some supporting the campaign and others criticizing it. The sales of protein powder are increasing in the UK, with projections to reach £358m by 2017. Notable figures like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick have weighed in on the controversy.

Rail firms are planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite the main party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western urgently review its decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his Witney constituency. Passengers travelling from Charlbury, the Oxfordshire station nearest to his constituency home, will see an off-peak return to London rise from £33.30 to £62.40, an 87% increase. Cameron has written to First Great Western to ask them to urgently review their decision. The fare increases are due to come into effect on May 17. Unregulated fares, which make up around half of rail companies' total revenue, can be increased by firms three times a year. First Great Western has defended the changes, stating they are to bring the north Cotswolds route in line with other services. Other sharp price hikes include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton rising from £30 to £37, and an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool increasing from £26.50 to £33. Virgin has said the majority of its price hikes affect 'Virgin trains-only fares', which are at least 20% cheaper than rival firms' tickets. Virgin's overall fare increase on the West Coast is 1.65%, below the industry average. The fare increases have surprised passengers, as both main parties have discussed price freezes.

former soldier john young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown through his front door in oldham, greater manchester. he and his wife elaine, 54, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when their home was targeted by vandals. the attack occurred three weeks after their marriage. when young opened the door to confront the offenders, he was struck in the face by a brick. he was taken to hospital and underwent emergency surgery, but doctors could not save his left eye. the couple are now moving to southport due to fear and the desire to leave the neighborhood where the incident occurred. police are investigating the attack, which they believe may have been carried out by yobs "messing around," with no known motive.

derbyshire wicketkeeper tom poynton has signed a one-year contract extension after returning from injury. he missed the 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident in which his father died. poynton, 25, made his comeback during derbyshire's pre-season tour of abu dhabi. graeme welch, elite performance director at derbyshire, praised poynton's character and expressed hope that the new contract will give him confidence to perform well this summer.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually. The cancer was found in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To help him feel stronger during his radiotherapy treatment, Harley decorated his protective mask like a Ninja Turtle. His story gained international attention, and Nickelodeon even sent him Ninja Turtle presents for Christmas. After battling the disease for a year, undergoing chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley has been declared cancer-free. His parents, Oliver and Stacey, are overjoyed and looking forward to a future where Harley can return to school full time. Neuroblastoma is a cancer of specialized nerve cells in the nervous system and other tissues, and it is the second most common solid tumor in childhood, making up 8% of children's cancers. The cause of neuroblastoma is unknown, and treatment varies depending on the child's age, the size and position of the tumor, and whether the disease has spread.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old footballer, impressed during Aston Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa's manager, believes Grealish should focus on his club career rather than his international future. Grealish is wanted by both the Republic of Ireland and England, and he must decide which country to represent. Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish's priority should be to continue performing well for Aston Villa, which will give him the opportunity to make an informed decision. Sherwood had a similar situation with Nabil Bentaleb, who chose to represent Algeria over France. Grealish's father agrees that his son should concentrate on his club football first, and the international decision will follow. Grealish has played for the Republic of Ireland's youth teams but is now considering England. Sherwood is impressed with Grealish's confidence and skill on the pitch, and he believes that with more opportunities, Grealish will continue to improve. The decision between Ireland and England is expected to be made by Grealish at the end of the season.

The passage discusses the high landing fees at airports for private jets, which can reach thousands of dollars per landing. It highlights that the three most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive at £ 4,559 ( $ 6,850). Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, and LaGuardia Airport in New York. Surprisingly, Bristol Airport in the UK and Salzburg Airport in Austria also feature in the top 10 list of expensive airports for private jet landings. The passage also mentions that the private jet industry is worth billions of dollars, with millions of flights recorded annually in the US and Europe. The busiest weekends for private jets are during major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. Landing fees vary greatly, with Salzburg Airport charging £ 2,530 for a 767-400 jet, and the cost of a round trip from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl estimated at around $ 38,000 on a medium jet.

The passage describes a video of a Labrador named Cooper eating an ice cream cone in one bite while his smaller companion, Daisy, takes ladylike licks. Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, took the dogs to McDonald's for the treat. Cooper is known for eating quickly, so Gallegos ensures Daisy gets her share first. The video has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she defends the practice, stating that Cooper is healthy and that her previous dog lived to 19 years old with a similar treat once a week. Another video shows Cooper and Daisy visiting Starbucks for a 'pup-uccino', which is a cup of whipped cream, with Cooper again consuming the treat quickly. Gallegos emphasizes that the pup-uccino does not contain coffee.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after a successful interim spell. He signed a three-year deal with the club. Locke joined Kilmarnock as assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer but took over the team when Johnston quit at the start of February. Since taking charge, Locke has lost just once in seven games. He will speak at a press conference on Friday morning.

Jessica Kemp, a mother from Eustis, Florida, has accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because of the essential oils he wears to help combat his illness. She claims that teachers at Seminole County Elementary warned they would remove Logan from class because the oils smell and are a distraction to other students. Jessica applies the oils to Logan's head and neck, believing they help him stay calm and focused. She says Logan has been using the oils all year, but a teacher's aide recently complained. The school board sent a letter stating the oils had created a problem for staff and students. Jessica questions why natural oils are not allowed when chemical alternatives are. Despite the threat of punishment, she will continue to fight the decision, insisting the oils have a positive impact on her son. However, the Lake County School District has stated they will not suspend Logan, considering it a health issue. The family uses Doterra oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, which the company describes as being "beautifully and powerfully fragrant."

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper complex, was destroyed by a fire on Wednesday at 3 pm. The fire spread through 90 condos and was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. The cause of the blaze is unknown, but it is being investigated. Twelve fire crews were deployed, but they could not enter any of the summer homes due to the intensity of the fire. The complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November. Janice Sklarek, an owner of one of the apartments, and Rob Taber, the building manager who lived in the complex, expressed their shock and loss. The fire was visible from three miles away and produced a lot of smoke. The Westhampton fire chief mentioned that the wind helped with visibility and that they are investigating a claim that the fire may have started near a car parked by the complex.

The Queen, aged 88, was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, through Windsor Great Park. She was not wearing a helmet, but instead a silk scarf, as she has never worn a helmet while riding, citing her hair as a reason. The Queen has been riding since she was four years old, starting with a Shetland pony named Peggy. Over the years, she has owned several horses, including Betsy and Surprise, and continues to breed Fell ponies and Highland ponies at Hampton Court and Balmoral. Despite a knee injury that has reduced her riding time, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and is often seen at her Windsor stables. Fell ponies, like Carltonlima Emma, are known for their hardiness and have been around since the Neolithic period. They were used by the Carvetii, Romans, Vikings, and Normans, and later became popular as riding ponies in the 20th century. The Queen's interest in horses and ponies has been a lifelong passion, and she has passed this love on to her grandchildren, notably Prince Edward's children, Lady Louise and James, Viscount Severn.

An argument over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors, Leon Yeaman and Phillip Pama, ended tragically. Leon Yeaman, 55, was killed by a single punch to the head from Phillip Pama, 28, during a row in front of their homes. Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse, was sleeping when Yeaman was making noise at around 9 pm on Thursday night. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at 'the world at large.' Pama confronted Yeaman, and during the confrontation, Pama grabbed Yeaman's hand and hit out 'blindly,' not seeing the punch connect but feeling it. Paramedics were unable to revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene. Neighbors described Yeaman as kind and generous, and a friend mentioned he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed loud music. Phillip Pama was granted conditional bail, with conditions including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and reporting to the local police station twice a week. The case is due to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher named Yulia Simonova was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-pupil, Damian Vanya. The teacher wanted to inflict pain on the boy by breaking his arms and legs, leaving his face untouched, and letting him bleed to death. She offered 100,000 rubles (about £1,400) for the hit. The police set up a sting operation, and an undercover officer posing as a hitman recorded the conversation. After handing over some expenses money, Simonova was arrested by armed police in her car. She now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. The pupil, who ended the relationship with Simonova when he started dating a classmate, expressed relief and hoped that she would be imprisoned for a long time.

Jose Mourinho, the manager of Chelsea football club, talks to God every day but never about football. He keeps his professional and family life separate. Mourinho, who has a strong faith, prays for personal matters and not for his team's success. He and his family have worked with the World Food Programme against hunger. Despite his arrogant image, Mourinho claims to be a good person, supporting friends and strangers alike. He has been fined for comments about a supposed campaign against his team. Mourinho's family life includes his wife Matilde Faria and two children, and he only attends church regularly when in Portugal. Chelsea are currently top of the league and playing QPR this weekend.

Bob Barker returned to host "The Price is Right" on April 1, 2015, for the first time in eight years. He hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," before Drew Carey, the current host, finished the show. Barker, who hosted the show for 35 years before retiring in 2007, appeared spry at 91 years old and seemed to handle the hosting duties without missing a beat.

An off-duty secret service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 am on Friday for allegedly attempting to break into a house and destroying property. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Metropolitan Police Department arrested him on the 3200 block of D Street SE. As a result of the arrest, the Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and put him on leave. He was a member of the Foreign Missions Branch, which works with the State Department on diplomatic activities. Baldwin was scheduled to be arraigned on Friday afternoon. This arrest comes after another high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave due to misconduct allegations being investigated by the police and the Homeland Security Department's inspector general. Baldwin's arrest and the earlier misconduct allegations are the latest incidents affecting the Secret Service's reputation, which is responsible for protecting the President and his family.

A freelance photographer named Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture images of a hungry lion from just a few feet away. He was at a safari park in his city when he spotted the male lion in the distance. Saeed got out of his car and crept up to within 10 feet of the lion, armed only with a camera. He managed to take a few photos before the clicking sound of his camera alerted the lion to his presence. The lion then aggressively jumped towards him, forcing Saeed to retreat quickly to the safety of his car. Saeed said he was thinking about capturing the lion's character and status, but now he reflects that it was a close encounter and he might not do it again.

The New York City Police Department has released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman who died in Brooklyn on March 22. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious and pronounced dead at the scene. She had no identification, but she had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg that appears to be the name "Monique" within a heart topped with a rose. The police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death. Anyone with information about the unidentified woman is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom, wood and steel home on the bed of an old 1986 Hino flatbed truck. They returned to New Zealand from the UK in 2009 and couldn't afford to buy property, so they decided to build their own home. The project took about a year and a half, and they now live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The home is powered by solar panels, and they have a wood-fired stove, gas for hot water, and water from a nearby spring. The total cost of the project was approximately $25,000, and they plan to build another similar home in the future. The couple and their cat enjoy living in a cozy, all-wood home surrounded by nature, with a babbling brook and majestic trees outside their door.

Children who share iPads in class do much better in early literacy tests than those who do not, according to researchers. Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University in the US found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in classes over an academic year significantly outscored their peers who had no iPads or who had their own devices. Shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher in a test than students who used the device on their own and non-iPad users. The findings suggest that it is the collaborative learning around the technology that made the difference, not just the collaboration in and of itself. Schools might reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective. These results come despite the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers expressing doubts about using technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on just its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed 'super pig', has been filmed taking unsteady steps and foraging for food with its snout to the ground. Despite the challenges, the piglet manages to balance and mix with its littermates, all of whom have four legs. The piglet belongs to farmer Ms Duan from Qionglai city in Sichuan province, China. Since its birth, villagers have visited to see the unique animal. This is not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction after learning to walk on its front paws. The video of the piglet has captured the hearts of thousands online.

Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was hit by the car of Francesco Dracone during the Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Dracone had come in on lap 25 for tires and fuel and spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, receiving stitches for a cut on his leg, and was released. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain. Dracone did not finish the race and wound up 23rd.

Horrific CCTV footage shows Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally attacking his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. He confessed to the crime, stating that he was jealous of men looking at her. Cicera belonged to a dance group called Jaula das Gostozuedas. The incident occurred four days after their marriage. A neighbor, Lelio Maya Puga, heard the argument and described the husband's accusations against his wife. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was apprehended by police after crashing it. Police found multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in his possession. Severiano faces life in jail for the brutal murder.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for her best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," has shared her personal struggle with mental illness. She revealed in a candid interview that anxiety led her to consider suicide, feeling that her life had no purpose. Wilson attributed her mental health issues to stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and a sense of isolation due to not having a family. She believes that depression and anxiety are closely linked and that acknowledging this connection is crucial to addressing the increasing rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. Wilson now accepts her anxiety but wishes she had a "guidebook to life" when she was younger. She considers anxiety to be the "new depression," citing statistics from Beyond Blue that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime. If anyone needs help, they can contact Beyond Blue or Lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant Oregon woman, was charged with second-degree assault after hitting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. The incident occurred when Curtin found the ex using heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge because Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. Curtin was seven months pregnant at the time and gave birth in January. The ex-girlfriend was reportedly jealous and bitter about the new relationship and had a history of harassing Curtin. Curtin and her boyfriend have since separated, and she is now living with her parents. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma the pit bull, who lives in California with two children, was filmed being fed treats. Her owner tried to trick her by including a broccoli spear among the treats. Gemma reacted with disgust, chomping on the vegetable before spitting it out on the floor. The passage hopes the children do not follow her lead and learn to love their greens. When not eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which were scrapped in 2011. After the awards were discontinued, the organizers allowed the registration on hsbc.com.hk to retire, which led the page to redirect to a porn site. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website after realizing the mistake and denied any association with the external site. In a statement dated April 20, HSBC apologized for any inconvenience caused and assured that its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus from Maryland called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home in Clinton on Sunday morning. Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call, providing instructions to the dispatcher and comforting his sister. Firefighters were able to rescue Marcus and Aaliya by entering the room and breaking a window. Marcus was handed out the window to another rescuer, and the firefighter gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries. The other family members escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar Hospital. The boy's calmness and instructions were crucial in the rescue effort, which was described as heroic by the assistant fire chief.

Blue fluorescent algae has been lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured images of the neon glow at one of Australia's popular beaches, describing the sight as a 'beautiful supernatural scene'. The glow is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, usually due to natural causes. Iain Suthers, an oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, explained that the algae gives off the luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar display was seen in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and there is no need to be concerned about the algae.

Breast cancer patients may be spared chemotherapy thanks to new tests that pinpoint genetic markers in the tumor and determine its aggressiveness. After surgery, the cancer cells are sent to a lab where they are screened, and women can be told within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the test can accurately tell if the risk is as low as five percent, which is as good as, if not better than, the odds for those who have chemotherapy. The majority of women who have breast cancer are routinely given chemotherapy following removal of the tumor to prevent recurrence, but the side effects can be difficult to live with. Experts have long believed that the risk of cancer recurrence for certain women is a lot less than for others, and that for some, chemotherapy may not be necessary. If the newest of the tests, called endopredict, shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. Most of the tests are available only privately and cost about £2,500, although breast specialists hope they may soon become properly available on the NHS. The test can help patients make an informed choice, whereas in the past, chemotherapy was given to almost everyone. Becca Cornford, a breast cancer patient, was relieved to find out that her chances of recurrence were just five percent after taking the endopredict test, and she opted not to have chemotherapy.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including at least one from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed 'HMS Lusty' by the crew. HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors removed in emergency 'medevacs' during the last nine years. Eighteen other ships, such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman confirmed a strict 'no touching' rule is in place at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. This comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. The data also shows that nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan due to pregnancy between 2006 and 2013, with 99 servicewomen evacuated during that period. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones. The women were flown back on flights usually reserved for injured troops, and the true figure could be higher if others traveled via routine flights. Troops are reminded to check for pregnancy before deployment but are not required to take pregnancy tests. The Ministry of Defence stated that the small number of personnel who discover they are pregnant on operations are returned at the first convenient opportunity.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence. This discovery occurred on the same day a court approved the restart of two nuclear reactors, sparking concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone was equipped with a camera and smoke flares, and the cesium was believed to have been placed in a plastic bottle. The amount of cesium was not immediately harmful to humans. The incident has raised concerns about future terrorism threats, especially in light of upcoming events like the Olympics and the G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but does not have similar restrictions for most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Abe was not in his office at the time, as he was attending a conference in Indonesia.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province in eastern China, takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this because his mother suffers from Alzheimer's disease and has a history of getting lost when left alone, including wandering into the mountains to collect firewood. After his father passed away earlier this year, Lu decided to take care of his mother himself since his wife works in a different city and his son is still in school. To ensure his mother's safety, he ties a sash around both of their waists while riding. The journey to work takes an hour, and he checks on his mother regularly during his shift, as his employers, a bank, have provided her with her own room. Lu feels a duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to caring for her children, and he says, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple." He adds that seeing his mother is the only way he can feel relaxed, as otherwise, he would be worried she had wandered away.

The study published in the American Journal of Public Health found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with women's drinking habits driving the increase. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men. Binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time. The study found that women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times the rate among men. The increases in excessive drinking are attributed to changing social norms, the influx of affluent young people in cities, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study also noted that alcohol advertising has increased and taxes on alcohol have not risen along with the consumer price index, making alcohol cheaper in real dollars. The CDC defines heavy drinking as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion.

Doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, according to UN officials. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to the risks of infections and even death. In England, over a quarter of women giving birth now have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The World Health Organization (WHO) suggests the rate should ideally be between 10% and 15%. Planned caesareans can cost the NHS more than natural births, and the WHO warns that the procedure can lead to significant complications, disability, or death. The WHO's statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow women to have caesareans even without medical justification. The WHO emphasizes that doctors are underestimating the risks associated with caesareans and that they are being performed too often.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after she allegedly broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard and lived there for at least a week. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The owner, Mark Conklin, found her sitting in his living room and called the police after she claimed to own the house and fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck. A construction worker reported seeing Filkins outside with items from the home, suggesting she was having a yard sale. Missing items include furniture, kitchenware, and a painting by the owner. The Edgartown Police Department is asking anyone who received items from the home to return them and has stated that those who purchased items are also victims and can seek restitution. The next court date for Filkins is May 14.

A lost iPhone was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border. The police officers found the phone unlocked and used it to post selfies and humorous messages on the owner's Facebook page in an attempt to track her down. The owner, Bella Crooke, lost her phone at a friend's birthday party and realized it was missing the next day. She called her phone and a security guard answered, saying he would leave it at the police station. By the time Bella arrived to collect her phone, the police's Facebook posts had already received a humorous response from her friends. The police even replied to text messages sent by Bella's friends. Bella reclaimed her phone without needing to give her name as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. She appreciated the police's good humor and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippo was thrown into the air and killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as the baby was dragged along the water's surface. The mother had been trying to protect her calf from younger hippos, thinking they would be too rough, but the deadly fight between the two adult males proved fatal. Stacey Farrell, a 30-year-old tour operator, witnessed the tragic event. The baby hippo had no chance against the two adults as they fought in the muddy waters. The calf died hours later from its injuries.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is being sold for £575,000, which is significantly less than the average price for the area. However, the property has only three years left on the lease. The cost of purchasing the apartment works out to £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, which is comparable to the rental rate for a similar flat in the area. The apartment, described as 'bright and well proportioned,' has 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and access to a communal garden. The property is in need of modernization. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge costs £1.5 million, and this flat is only offered with a 28-year lease. The current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, and any buyer would have to negotiate a lease extension with them, which could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease. The estate agents have noted that properties with such short leases rarely come on the market, and the phone has not stopped ringing with interest. However, a property consultant warned that extending the lease would come with a significant premium, and it is essential to check the lease length before purchasing. The apartment is located in Egerton Place, which was built around 1893 and has a history of high-status residents.

A computer outage at Starbucks affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada on Friday evening. The outage caused the registers to stop working, leading Starbucks to give away free drinks and baked goods. The company did not provide a detailed explanation for the outage, but stated it was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. The outage also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. Despite the inconvenience, many customers were pleased with the freebies and praised the company's response. The outage occurred the day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion. Starbucks announced that stores would open for business as usual on Saturday.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of west Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire.
