According to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, these locations are also used to radicalize Muslims. Those involved in such activities participate in seemingly ordinary community activities but have an ulterior motive. The officer, Detective Constable Gareth Jones, stated that terrorism issues are not confined to large cities. Islamic extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998, when it is claimed that hate preacher Abu Hamza sent a group of 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, an area used by the British military for training. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in North Wales. In 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested as part of an al-Qaeda inspired gang that plotted terror attacks. Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is believed to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, which was set up by Iraqi clerics. DC Jones emphasized the importance of community intelligence in combating terrorism, stating that it is vital for authorities to examine any intelligence that comes from the community. He confirmed that Ceredigion, Pembrokeshire, and Powys have been used for radicalization training, with individuals participating in ordinary activities but having ulterior motives.

A juvenile female Omura's whale was found on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, after Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The whale was initially difficult to identify, but DNA profiling confirmed it as an Omura's whale. The find is significant for whale scientists as little is known about the species, which was first described in 2003 and is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for scientific investigation and possibly public display in museums.

The passage discusses the controversial opinion of Cheryl Rios, a female businesswoman from Texas, who believes that women should not be president due to hormonal fluctuations that might make them irrational and more likely to start unnecessary wars. The passage contrasts this view with historical and scientific evidence that suggests men's hormones have also impaired their decision-making, and that women leaders are shown to take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts. It also mentions that Time magazine suggested Hillary Clinton, as a postmenopausal woman, is "biologically primed" to lead. The author argues that the real issue is not hormones but the bias against women in the workplace and society. The passage cites studies and examples to illustrate the bias women face, such as the underrepresentation of women on corporate boards and the different ways male and female professors are perceived. The author concludes that equality benefits everyone, including better financial performance for companies, happier and healthier children, stronger marriages, and better results for diverse teams. The passage ends by correcting an earlier statement about Canada's first female prime minister, Kim Campbell, who was elected in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is selling his enormous collection of antiques in a £100,000 auction after deciding to downsize his home. The star, known for appearing in "All Creatures Great and Small" and playing Winston Churchill several times, is auctioning off more than 200 items he has collected over his career. Mr. Hardy, 89, is a keen military historian who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and is now an expert on the medieval longbow. The auction, taking place on Saturday at Dominic Winter auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, a portrait of Mr. Hardy holding the bow, paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and a fine collection of crystal chandeliers. A total of 238 lots are being sold, including dozens of books dating back to the 17th century. Mr. Hardy expressed sadness about selling his collection but entrusted it to the auction house, hoping the new owners will enjoy the items as much as he has. He built up the haul of antiques thanks to his interest in classic literature and military history. Mr. Hardy was taught by Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Magdalen College, Oxford, and has published two books on the history of the longbow. He was also consulted as an expert during the raising of the Tudor shipwreck the Mary Rose. The actor found national fame playing vet Siegfried Farnon in "All Creatures Great and Small" and is well known for portraying Winston Churchill in several television performances. He also played Minister for Magic Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films. Despite a fall that forced him to retire from stage acting two years ago, Mr. Hardy intends to continue doing television work.

michael scott shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, sandra shemansky, in winter garden, florida. he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the day his mother was found dead. an investigation revealed foul play. shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness. he was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. his mother was helping him through a divorce. neighbors believe the divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge. shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. his estranged wife is preparing to protect herself. anyone with information on his whereabouts should contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council decided to bypass the usual bidding process, citing a "unique strategic opportunity to host the IAAF World Championships for the first time in the USA." Eugene previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The decision to award Eugene the 2021 event was made based on a recent presentation that convinced the governing body that the city has the necessary capabilities to stage a world championships. The IAAF president, Lamine Diack, stated that the decision was made in the interest of the global development of the sport, even though it departed from the usual procedure. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan was also awarded without a bidding process. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10,000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

An aspiring model named Leonie Granger, 25, from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger targeted Hassan after spotting him flashing a roll of £50 notes at a casino in London's West End. She used her good looks to befriend him, receiving gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. Granger, with her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29, plotted to rob Hassan. After a night out, she left his flat unlocked, allowing Jackson and Chandler to enter, tie up, and kick Hassan to death while searching for his hidden winnings. Hassan was found dead with multiple broken bones and drowned in his own blood. Granger was found guilty by a majority of 10 to 2 and was not convicted of murder. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." Granger was sentenced for manslaughter and for robbing Hassan and conspiring to falsely imprison him. The case revealed that Hassan was a "soft target" who kept his winnings at home and enjoyed the company of women, making him vulnerable. The defendants were also convicted of other crimes, including armed robberies at casinos. The family of Mehmet Hassan expressed their grief and love for him, stating that his death will haunt them forever.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season. He was one of the worst players on the pitch during Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland on Tuesday. Despite a brilliant start to the season at Stamford Bridge, his form has significantly dipped. Fabregas spoke of his happiness in London earlier this week, but his form has raised questions about his durability. He was given a four out of ten by a Spanish newspaper for his performance against Holland. Fabregas has been playing almost every minute of every match, which has led to fatigue. His role as a key man in Chelsea's title charge has declined of late. Jose Mourinho will be concerned about Fabregas's toil in the midfield during the full 90 minutes against Holland. Fabregas captained Spain but struggled to make an impact. After his £30 million transfer to Chelsea, his former club Barcelona released a statement pointing out his traditional post-Christmas slump. Despite glowing starts to each campaign, his contributions decreased as each season drew to a close. Fabregas had 15 Premier League assists by mid-January but has only one in five games since, and just four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. He was on track to break Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists in a season but now looks set to fall short. Chelsea have six opponents left who Fabregas has assisted goals against this season. Fabregas's personal accolade is important, but more key is the boost it could give to his club. Chelsea could need as many as six wins from their remaining nine games, and if Fabregas finds form again, the Premier League title could be wrapped up within weeks. Fabregas's assist for Diego Costa in Chelsea's last game against Hull City was his first in five games. Mourinho is looking to guide his team over the line in the Premier League title race, with Fabregas a key cog.

West Ham is negotiating a deal for Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United, Jamaica. Beckford impressed during a two-week trial with West Ham's academy. He has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the Caribbean's top prospects. West Ham is close to signing Beckford. Additionally, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making them the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League as they aim to fill the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of a suspected attacker. The attack took place on January 24, where Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. The incident occurred even though the hunt was chasing an artificial scent, not a fox. Lane was sent to the ground, kicked in the head, and suffered concussion and broken teeth. He has since experienced memory loss. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of saboteurs, were given to Wiltshire Police. However, the police have stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence, angering Lane and other hunt supporters. Lane feels let down by the police and believes they could have done more. The decision to drop the case has sparked criticism from hunt supporters and the countryside alliance, who are campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to make it easier to bring criminals to justice. Wiltshire Police stated that the case has been recorded as undetected but could be reopened if further evidence comes to light.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece of al Qaeda, was killed in January in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation. He was not specifically targeted, according to the White House. Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was born in 1978 and grew up in rural California. He converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998. Gadahn rose through the ranks of al Qaeda, becoming its chief official English-language propagandist. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. Gadahn appeared in numerous al Qaeda videos, criticizing U.S. presidents and urging Muslims to stage attacks. He was among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." Gadahn was married and had at least one child. Another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, was also killed in a separate operation. Warren Weinstein, a U.S. hostage, and Giovanni Lo Porto, an Italian hostage, died in the operation that killed Farouq.

A five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo has become a new basketball superstar in China after a viral video showcased his impressive basketball skills. Mai has been shooting hoops since he was two and a half years old. The video shows him scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, which has earned him many fans across China. This talent has led to comparisons with China's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming, who played for the Houston Rockets in the NBA. Netizens in China have been stunned by Mai's potential, with some questioning if the video is real and others expressing admiration for his skills.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 70s and 80s, attended a hacked off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25. The rally was to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, set up in the wake of the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against what it sees as the 'biased and unfair' Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The news of O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off is an embarrassment to the group. PIE, which O'Carroll was a part of, aimed to legalize sex with children and formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals'. The Hacked Off spokesman stated that the meeting was open to all members of the public.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday for a unique catwalk setting during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The empty pool hosted the Ten Pieces presentation, a label headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss. The lifestyle brand produces unisex collections of ten pieces designed to be worn in twenty different ways. The show featured a monochrome collection with models walking through the concrete pool and along the break wall, against a backdrop of the ocean. Guests enjoyed nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria, and the show took place on a warm 28 degrees Celsius day. The androgynous designs were suitable for both sexes and day to night wear. Beachgoers and passers-by stopped to watch the show, which was held at the public site.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent a day at a safari park in northern California with his family. He posed with and fed a white tiger, and also took pictures with giraffes and sea lions. Khan's wife and daughter accompanied him on this family outing. Earlier, Khan announced his next fight will be against Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent. He had been under pressure to fight Kell Brook, but chose Algieri instead.

The passage states that a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, will have his name removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His name was added to the wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, the national cemetery, but his family and others objected to his inclusion. Abu Khdeir was killed in July 2014 by three Israelis, according to prosecutors, and was beaten and burned alive. His father, Hussein Abu Khdeir, did not give permission for his son's name to be on the memorial and objected to it being listed among Israeli soldiers. Almagor, an organization that works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, also opposed his inclusion, stating that his death was a rogue attack and not an act of terrorism. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, has decided to remove his name from the memorial wall following his family's complaints. The teen's name has already been removed from the organization's website. The passage also mentions that a panel of judges began hearing evidence in January against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing.

The passage describes a young boy in California who chases his family cat around the garden in an attempt to use the cat's belly as a pillow. The cat, initially licking its fur, is then used as a pillow by the boy, but after a brief moment, the cat gets up and moves to another spot. The boy follows the cat and repeats the action. This sequence happens twice more before the cat, tired of being used as a pillow, goes indoors. A later video shows the boy and the cat reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer, testified in a police corruption trial in Philadelphia about his experiences with some of the officers on trial. He claimed that the officers stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. After his testimony, Kushner lost his job as a varsity coach at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy. He had passed a background check when hired in 2010, and the charges from 2007 were expunged as part of a probationary sentence. Kushner was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, and he also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. He expressed regret about his past and stated that he has moved past it. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, and the defense claims the government's case is based on unreliable witnesses.

An explosion at a chemical plant in China's Fujian province caused a fire and injured six people. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a chemical used in polyester production and considered carcinogenic. The explosion occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, but there were no reports of toxic chemical spills. Five of the six injured people were hurt by broken glass and were sent to the hospital. Over 600 firefighters were dispatched and the fire is now under control. Residents near the plant posted photos of the fire on social media, describing hearing a loud blast and feeling tremors. The plant had another explosion in 2013 with no casualties or toxic leaks reported. The construction of PX plants has led to protests in China due to pollution concerns. The Zhangzhou plant was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated due to public opposition in 2007.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player, is known for wearing his socks low during matches. This is due to a superstition he has held since he was young. He wears children's shinpads, which are not immediately noticeable. Referees have told him to pull his socks up, but he refuses to change his ways. He made his first Premier League start against QPR and was pleased with the opportunity, despite the match ending in a draw. He hopes to get more starts before the end of the season and appreciates the manager's faith in him.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Bobbi Kristina is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive. Cissy Houston expressed sadness at the possibility of her granddaughter living in this condition for a lifetime and is praying for a miracle. A source with knowledge of her condition confirmed that she does not respond to visitors or familiar voices and has a tracheostomy in her throat. Two days prior, Bobbi Kristina's father, Bobby Brown, stated that his daughter's condition had improved, saying she was awake and watching him. However, an attorney for the Brown family clarified that while Bobbi Kristina's condition has improved and she will have a long life, the quality of her life remains uncertain and will be determined over the years through a long rehabilitation process.

russia leads germany 2-0 in their fed cup tie after anastasia pavlyuchenkova beat sabine lisicki and svetlana kuznetsova defeated julia goerges. pavlyuchenkova saved a match point and won 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. both players had issues with their serve, with pavlyuchenkova having 13 double faults and lisicki making 63 unforced errors. russia needs one win out of the three matches on sunday to reach the fed cup final and win their first title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low, similar to the one that lashed the state's east coast for three days last week, could hit again, bringing heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) has already been inundated with requests for assistance from last week's storm, with over 4,000 jobs still to be completed out of 24,196 requests. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills expressed concern that more storms would hamper clean-up efforts, particularly in the hard-hit Hunter region. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott stated that while the new weather system is different and not expected to affect Sydney as severely as the previous one, it could still bring heavy rain to the northern parts of the state. The Bureau of Meteorology warned that the main impacts of intense rainfall and strong winds would be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, with heavy falls also likely for southeast Queensland. The SES urges residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "Livin' la Vida Loca" video, denied claims that she attempted suicide. She stated that she was hospitalized due to a domestic accident, where she fell and hurt herself due to low blood pressure. Italian media had reported that Moric tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment. Moric's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, initially suggested that she had attempted suicide, but Moric clarified that she was fine and only needed rest. She also mentioned that she was once married to famous paparazzi snapper Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs. Moric reassured her fans that she was recovering at home and that the media reports were incorrect.

The British public is hoping that Kate and William will choose a traditional name for their second child. A poll conducted by YouGov for the Sunday Times shows that 12% of people would like the baby to be named Diana, after William's mother, the late Princess of Wales. If the child is a girl, Alice and Charlotte are also popular choices, garnering 9% of the vote each. Alice was the name of the Queen's aunt, and Charlotte is seen as a nod to William's father, Charles. For a boy, James is the favorite with 13% of the vote, followed by Alexander. Many people are hoping for a girl, with 25% of the 2,200 people polled wanting a female baby, compared to only 3% hoping for a younger brother for Prince George. The poll also indicates that 68% of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded 64 others in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday. The attack occurred near a group of protesters in the city of Khost. The protesters were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. An Afghan lawmaker, Humayoon Humayoon, was among the wounded. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other group has claimed responsibility.

dani alves will leave barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. his representative confirmed that negotiations have ended. alves has been at barcelona for seven years, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles. the 31-year-old was offered a three-year contract extension, but it was dependent on him playing in 60% of matches. dinorah santana, his agent and ex-wife, stated that the offer did not make sense and criticized barcelona for not renewing his contract earlier.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently playing for Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. He believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a good fit for the Argentine club and that the fans would love to see them play at La Bombonera. Osvaldo thinks that Pirlo and Totti have a South American style of play that would suit Boca Juniors, and he is confident that the fans would go crazy for them.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, had a fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. The fall was spectacular, resulting in Ferguson performing a double somersault. Despite the fall, he only sustained a cut on his nose. The incident has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Ferguson was back at Paul Nicholls's yard the next morning, mucking out stables as usual. He watched the replay of his fall with other jockeys who expressed concern for his well-being. Ferguson considers himself lucky to have escaped with minor injuries and joked about considering a career in gymnastics after racing. He was undeterred by the fall and is ready to get back in the saddle.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, dressed up as Iron Man and posted a photo on Instagram to celebrate the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron. He joined the hype surrounding the movie's premiere at Westfield London shopping centre, which featured stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing for Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and the Highlanders in New Zealand. He first joined Wasps in 2002, winning his first England cap five years later. Since returning to Wasps, he has surpassed the 100 appearances mark and has 57 caps for England. Haskell has played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand after leaving Wasps in 2009.

The wide leg trouser is a trend at the forefront of SS15 fashion. It offers an alternative to the skinny jean, which has been popular for years. The wide leg trouser can be intimidating, especially for shorter people, but pairing it with high heels and a simple top can make it flattering. Denim is an easy way to achieve this look, as seen in Gucci's SS15 collection. The trend has appeared on several catwalks, including Gucci and Celine. Topshop has a version called the Miller jean, and Finery London offers a similar style at a lower price. The wide leg trouser is a versatile piece that can be dressed up or down and is suitable for all seasons.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a screening of "American Sniper" after more than 200 students objected to the film's depiction of the Iraq War. The students felt the movie reflected negatively on the Middle East and its people. However, a counter-petition led to the university reconsidering its decision. The university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and that it would be shown as planned. The university will also offer a screening of the family-friendly "Paddington" for those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper." The decision to show the movie was praised by Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh. The university values freedom of expression and respects students' right to make their own choices.

Two French tourists tried to set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia on April 3. They ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to make contact with the animal. The quokka survived but was singed. Detectives questioned the two men, aged 18 and 24, and seized video evidence. Both were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are the size of domestic cats and can be found on small islands off the Western Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, was shown videos of her performances for the first time. She danced in famous New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar, alongside stars like Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and some volunteers created a video of "soundies," early music videos, for her to watch at her nursing home. Alice was thrilled to see herself dancing again, calling it "fabulous."

The passage states that the tradition of washing one's own car on Sundays is declining in Britain. According to a survey by vehicle leasing firm OSV, a third of men and three-quarters of women never wash their own cars. The study found that only 12% of men who do wash their cars do it regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the size of 4x4 and off-road vehicles. The survey also revealed that Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to be washed by their owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least often washed by their owners. The OSV spokesman, Andrew Kirkley, noted that the tradition has faded due to time constraints, the size of modern cars, and the availability of cheap car washing services.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact since he joined Liverpool in 2008. Skrtel believes Gerrard is one of the best players in the world and is synonymous with Liverpool. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday. If Liverpool win, Gerrard will play in the FA Cup final on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel says Gerrard helped him settle at the club and gave him a hand every day. Skrtel believes Liverpool have potential replacements for Gerrard, but they will need help to fill his void. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool lineup for the match against Villa after serving three-match bans.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, hit an ace during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National. This event took place on the 130-yard fourth hole. Nicklaus was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. His ace was his first at Augusta, and it was one of five hole-in-ones that day, tying the record from 2002. Despite his ace, Camilo Villegas, who also had two aces, did not win the contest, losing to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus is known for being the youngest person to win a green jacket in 1963 and for winning six Masters titles, including his last in 1986. He is one of five men to achieve the career grand slam.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, which is less than 17 miles west of Wichita, but it missed the city. The storm moved to the northeast, posing potential risks to other communities. CNN's severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Reports of tornadoes also came from southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. Additionally, a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, causing wind damage and flooding. In Potosi, an Instagram user posted a photo of a fallen tree, and aerial footage showed damage to roofs and a street overtaken by water. Further south, unusual dark clouds were photographed in Leadington, and baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. More storms are expected in the midwest, Mississippi River valley, Tennessee River valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. The judge allowed Bates to go to the Bahamas for a family vacation, a decision that upset Harris's family, who felt it showed apathy towards the shooting and Harris's life. Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. Bates's lawyer, Clark Brewster, said they look forward to dealing with the facts in the courtroom. Allegations have been made that Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff, but the sheriff's office denies this. Two deputies involved in Harris's arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families. Bates's lawyer released training documents to prove Bates had proper law enforcement training.

Conor McGregor, who is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11, has unveiled a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach. He already has a tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart on his chest. McGregor posted the image of his new tattoo on Instagram with the caption, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." He believes he has more motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin in March, raising it in front of 5,000 supporters. The two fighters have a tense relationship, with McGregor having a chance to legitimately hold the belt before his supporters in just under three months.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, was cheered on by a crowd of about 50 as he skolled a schooner of beer at an Australian rules function. This act has drawn criticism from anti-drinking campaigners, who argue that it glorifies binge drinking and associates masculinity with drinking alcohol. Julie Roberts, a cultural studies professor at the University of Technology Sydney, stated that it is problematic for the prime minister to showcase his masculinity in this way, as it sets up a culture where drinking is about quantity and speed rather than socializing. She believes that Abbott, as a leader, should be advocating against binge drinking.

Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, saying there was nothing wrong with his actions and that his dedication to fitness sets a good example. However, critics argue that Abbott should be setting an example that one does not have to drink heavily to be a "true blue Aussie bloke."

Abbott's skolling was not the first such display by an Australian prime minister, with former Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke being a notable example. Despite this, Roberts believes that Abbott should have considered recent shifts in attitudes towards heavy drinking. The incident has sparked debate over the portrayal of drinking in Australian culture and the role of leaders in setting examples for responsible behavior.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in the number of hiv cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases. This increase has occurred among intravenous drug users primarily using the high-powered painkiller Opana. The state health department declared an epidemic last month and expects the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program on March 26, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected 1,400 used syringes. The future of the program beyond April 25 is uncertain, and the state is considering legislation to allow needle-exchange programs in other high-risk counties. However, there is debate among lawmakers and Governor Pence about whether needle exchanges promote drug use or effectively reduce harm. The federal government bans public funding for needle exchange programs, and the sustainability of the program is a concern.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test about the football club Arsenal. She scored 43.5 out of 50, which earned her boyfriend's approval and a promise not to dump her. The test included multiple choice questions, tables to complete, and an essay section. Saskia's boyfriend marked her answers with red pen and provided feedback. She struggled with naming the starting 11 players and their positions but impressed with creative answers, such as calling Alexis Sanchez "buff" and stating that "Thierry Henry is a legend." Her boyfriend graded her an 'A' and decided not to end their relationship. The post received mixed reactions, with some praising Saskia's knowledge and calling her "proper gf material," while others criticized the boyfriend for taking things too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old informant who worked for the DEA for 27 years, is facing deportation despite promises of US citizenship. Toro was a mid-level member of the Medellin cartel in the 1980s and fled Colombia after a confrontation with his boss. He began working for the DEA as an informant, providing information about his former bosses and associates. Toro was not paid for his work but was promised citizenship. After declining health forced him to retire, Toro is now living in the US illegally. The DEA has refused to help him with his citizenship after he went public with his plight. Toro fears for his life if he is deported to Colombia, as his work led to the prosecution of high-profile figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. DEA agent Mike McManus, who worked with Toro, gave him $5,000 for an operation after the DEA declined to help. Toro remains in limbo, trying to secure a green card or passport, and cannot collect social security benefits until he obtains one of these documents. His final temporary visa expired on January 1, and he is prepared to go into hiding if necessary. Toro states that he has atoned for his past mistakes and wants the citizenship that was promised to him.

A 14-year-old girl from a village in India's Uttar Pradesh was allegedly gang-raped by five men on Sunday. She went outside her house to relieve herself when the attack occurred. On Tuesday, she set herself on fire using kerosene, and she is now recovering in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. Her brother doused her with water to put out the flames. The accused men have been arrested. The incident comes at a time when India is sensitive to sexual assault issues, especially after the ban of the documentary "India's Daughter," which discusses the brutal gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh in 2012. The country has seen protests and incidents of vigilante justice in response to recent attacks. The passage also mentions two other incidents of mob violence in response to alleged rapes.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal says he is dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford but will have to do so without Robin van Persie. Van Persie said he was fit to feature in the game against City on Sunday after ankle trouble but Van Gaal has ruled him out. Van Gaal explained at his press conference on Friday that Van Persie is not yet fit enough to play. With City rocking after defeat at Crystal Palace on Monday, Van Gaal and his players have an opportunity to finish as high as second or third and avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture later in the summer. Van Gaal wants his side to take all three points against City. He said: "I dream of it. Every player should dream of the victory. Of course I want to win because it's a big step up the table also. If we win then third place is available." Van Gaal acknowledged that City will provide a stern challenge to his team and played down the idea he will be motivated by revenge, after losing the away fixture earlier in the campaign. He also ruled out a potential return for Luke Shaw, saying he does not yet consider him fit enough to feature. Van Gaal is looking forward to sampling the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford, as he takes on City with home advantage for the first time since arriving at the club.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match to protest against high ticket prices. The protest was organized by fan groups from both clubs, who are upset about the rising costs of attending matches. The cheapest tickets for the game were £64, which the fans consider "extortionate." Banners were displayed inside and outside the Emirates Stadium, with one reading: "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket." The fans argue that football has become too focused on money and that the match-going fans are being neglected. They hope that their protest will raise awareness of the struggles fans face in meeting the rising costs of following their clubs. The protest was a joint effort, with fans from both teams participating, and further protests are expected after the game.

A newborn baby named Star was diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. Her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, noticed her skin turning yellow, a symptom of jaundice that persisted and led to the diagnosis. Biliary atresia is a condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent, and if untreated, it can lead to liver failure and death. After an unsuccessful attempt to unclog her bile ducts, Star needed a liver transplant to survive. Neither of her parents was a suitable match, but her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, who is Jade's twin sister, was a perfect candidate. Shanell donated part of her liver to save Star's life. The operation took place in November, and both Star and Shanell have since made good recoveries. Star will need regular blood tests and liver function tests, as well as anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life. Shanell did not hesitate to donate part of her liver, and Star's mother is very grateful to her twin sister for saving her daughter's life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won by sinking balls into a car boot from close range, 5-3. In the second round, they won again by playing over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus, which replaced the tennis net. In the final round, players shot from long range into a convertible Audi. Remy and Willian won this round, but Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the cars. Despite the mishap, Willian was allowed to drive one of the Audi cars. Hazard and Ake won the overall challenge 6-1 after two rounds, but Remy and Willian won the final round.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Jason Timmons, 29, and Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated that he was not suicidal, contradicting his earlier statements to investigators that he was trying to kill himself. The crash occurred when Dellinger drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph, hitting the couple's SUV. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide for the deaths of the couple and assault for the death of their unborn baby. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger's attorneys claimed he was suffering from various health issues and medication effects at the time of the crash. The victims' families are devastated, and Dellinger's wife expressed her condolences in court. Dellinger also faces a wrongful death lawsuit. He held high-level positions at several companies before leaving in 2011 due to health reasons. The Dellinger family owns properties worth $3 million in Sunapee.

Lacey Spears, from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the murder of her son Garnett-Paul Spears. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his hope that she would die in prison and called her a "crazy woman" on Facebook. The judge stated that Spears suffers from a mental illness and called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors argued that Spears poisoned her son with salt because she had a bizarre need for attention. Spears' lawyer claimed she was innocent and blamed the hospital for negligence, planning to appeal the verdict. While awaiting sentencing, she was held at Westchester County Jail. The prosecutor said Spears used her son's illnesses to self-aggrandize herself, leading to his "tortured death."

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains of influenza: influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket. The vaccine's development was prompted by a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter, where the existing vaccine did not provide adequate protection against these strains. The new vaccine is expected to arrive a month later than usual. High-risk groups, such as the very young, the very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Experts emphasize the importance of everyone getting the vaccine, which also provides protection against influenza A strain H1N1. The modified vaccine is expected to be a good match for the strains currently circulating globally, aiming to prevent more deaths than were seen in the northern hemisphere. People are encouraged to book their flu shots now, despite the delay in vaccine stocks arriving. The vaccine to be used in the next northern winter will be the same as the one being used in Australia this winter.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are concerned about budget cuts and a negative critique in National Geographic magazine. The tomb, managed by the Illinois state historic preservation agency, faces a potential merger into another department due to Governor Bruce Rauner's proposed budget cuts. The tomb, originally designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has undergone recent renovations costing over $2.5 million. Despite these efforts, the National Geographic article described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." The tomb's interior, sheathed in black and tan marble and trimmed with bronze, has been criticized for its art deco style. The tomb's hours and staffing have been reduced due to budget cuts, and supporters worry about the impact of further reductions. The tomb, a circular structure topped with an obelisk, houses Lincoln's burial chamber with the inscription "now he belongs to the ages." Despite the critique, visitors like William Sparks find the site "absolutely gorgeous."

The passage discusses the return of nineties and noughties fashion trends, some of which are considered questionable. JNCO jeans, known for their huge leg openings, are mentioned as a trend that many people who wore them the first time around are horrified to see making a comeback. The passage then lists several other fashion trends from the past that are either making a comeback or have remained popular, including:

1. Bucket hats, which were popular in the nineties and early noughties, and are now being worn by celebrities like Rihanna.
2. Camouflage print, which was favored by Destiny's Child and is now seen on celebrities like Jourdan Dunn.
3. Taking trends to the extreme, as seen with designer prints and double denim, with Kylie Jenner as a modern example.
4. Ugg boots, which remain popular with celebrities despite their lack of glamour.
5. Daisy Dukes, or extremely short denim shorts, which were popularized by Jessica Simpson and are still worn by celebrities like Miley Cyrus.
6. Juicy Couture tracksuits, which were popular in the noughties and are still worn by celebrities like Nicki Minaj.
7. Colored sunglasses, which were popular in the nineties and are now worn by celebrities like Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner.
8. Corsets as outfits, which were popularized by Victoria Beckham and are now incorporated into dresses by celebrities like Selena Gomez.
9. Harem trousers, which are difficult to wear but were worn by Kim Kardashian in the past and are still worn by celebrities like Elle Macpherson.

The passage concludes by reflecting on these trends and suggesting that some of them should be left in the past.

This week, four rainbows appeared in the New York area sky, captured by Amanda Curtis. In rural China, the government is cracking down on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during an interview when asked about his private life. The Kardashian trend this week is lip plumping, using a jar to mimic Kylie Jenner's look, with the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge. A 102-year-old woman named Alice Barker was taken back in time with help from filmmakers. A prom-posal referencing bombs was not allowed by a school, with accusations of racism. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in the upcoming "Beauty and the Beast" movie. Johnny Depp is unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer. A pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombed his son.

Serena Williams achieved her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, which led to her receiving a giant cake as a celebration. The day after Andy Murray celebrated his 500th win with a cake, Williams also received a similar cake after her 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 win over Sabine Lisicki. Williams' hopes of playing her sister Venus were dashed as Venus lost to Carla Suarez Navarro. Serena will now face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens. The Miami Open has seen a theme of celebratory cakes for significant milestones.

Sabeen Mahmud, who ran a second floor cafe in Karachi, Pakistan, was shot dead by two gunmen after closing her cafe late Friday. She was known for her advocacy of free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship in a country where such views can be dangerous. Her cafe, known as T2F, was a place for discussions on various topics, including technology, human rights, and politics. She had recently hosted a discussion on the topic of disappearances in Baluchistan, a controversial issue in Pakistan. Despite receiving death threats in the past, she continued to speak out and provide a space for others to do the same. Her death has sparked grief and gratitude for her work, with many expressing their appreciation for the freedom of thought she encouraged. Sabeen Mahmud was a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan, and her death has left a void in the country's progressive community.

The passage discusses the plight of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Indian Kashmir, who have been living as second-class citizens for nearly 70 years. Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old WPR, fled violence during the partition of India and has been denied citizenship rights, including property ownership and voting in state elections. The WPRs, who are predominantly Hindu, live in abject poverty in slum conditions in Jammu, India's only Muslim-majority state. Successive governments have refrained from granting them full rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in the state. However, with the recent success of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in the state elections, there is hope that the WPRs' status may change. Activists like Labha Ram Gandhi are calling for the WPRs to be granted state-subject rights, which would improve their condition. Despite the hope, the community is prepared to protest if their demands are not met. The passage also mentions the broader context of the Kashmir conflict and the prosperity of the state compared to the poverty of the WPRs.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering whether to join Chelsea this summer. Chelsea has made an offer for Muto, reportedly around £4million, and would loan him to Vitesse Arnhem. Muto wants to play regularly and develop his potential. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane confirmed Chelsea's interest. Muto scored the winner against Shonan Bellmare and is weighing his options carefully. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic believes Muto has great potential and unique qualities that could make him a success at Chelsea. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto but declined to discuss him extensively, citing respect for FC Tokyo and the role of commercial interests in transfers. Muto seeks a club where he can play and develop, and Chelsea's interest is contingent on his potential and fit with the team.

Australia has dropped the policy of not selecting players who are playing overseas, which leaves England looking old-fashioned. England's coach, Stuart Lancaster, should be free to pick the best players regardless of where they play. The argument is supported by the examples of Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who are performing well for Toulon and are back in the Australian team's consideration. The World Cup should feature the world's best players, and rules that prevent this demean the competition. Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon have improved their performances after moving to France, and Jonny Wilkinson's move to France also improved his game. The England coach should focus on winning the World Cup, which means selecting the best possible team. The policy of not selecting overseas players is seen as misguided and potentially detrimental to England's chances. The example of Toulon, which has players like Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny playing for their respective national teams, is used to highlight the absurdity of England's policy. The conclusion is that England should follow Australia's lead and make all English players available for selection, regardless of where they play.

The passage describes a new device called Greenstone, developed by Open Garden, which acts as a booster for off-the-grid networks. Greenstone is designed to enhance the capabilities of the company's Firechat app, which allows users to chat without an internet connection or mobile signal. The app uses a feature called multipeer connectivity framework (MCF) introduced in Apple's iOS 7, and a similar feature on Android that works over Bluetooth. This creates a wireless mesh network where each phone acts as a node, passing data between them. Greenstone extends the range of these networks, which are currently limited to around 200 feet (61 meters). The device can be used in various situations where connectivity is unreliable, such as at music festivals, protests, or in hospitals. Greenstone is still under development and currently works with Firechat at a range of around 20 feet (6 meters). It has a one-year battery life and can store up to 1,000 recent messages. Open Garden is working with manufacturers to design and sell Greenstone.

A burlesque performer named Lillian Bustle from New Jersey gave a TED talk where she discussed her efforts to change the negative connotations associated with the word 'fat'. She uses the word as a self-descriptor, similar to how she describes herself as 'short' and 'wife'. Lillian Bustle believes that 'fat' should not be synonymous with 'ugly'. She points out that there is a 66% increase in size discrimination in the workplace over the past 30 years and that young girls often wish to be thinner. However, studies show that exposure to body diversity can lead to more acceptance and preference for different body types. Lillian performs burlesque to expose her audiences to a 'fat' body in a positive and glamorous way, hoping to change perceptions. She quotes another performer, Beelzebabe, who says that the body diversity in burlesque challenges societal norms of desirability. Lillian's first performance was empowering for her, and she encourages others to find a 'courage reference' to boost their self-esteem. The TED talk, given in 2014 and posted on YouTube three weeks ago, has received mostly positive feedback, with viewers thanking her and sharing personal stories about how her message has impacted them. Despite a few negative comments, Lillian feels that the body-positivity movement is gaining ground.

Theo Walcott has been frequently on the bench this season. He was photographed with six of his Arsenal teammates and a runway model for a Lanvin photoshoot. Lanvin is Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. The players, including Walcott, posed for an official portrait. Arsenal players will wear similar attire at the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott has been on the bench for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games. He came on for the last six minutes of the 0-0 draw with Chelsea. Walcott is hoping for a start in the upcoming game against Hull.

An auction will take place on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com, featuring an array of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker. The collection, estimated to be worth $746,100, includes items from films such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and others. Individual items are expected to fetch high prices, with some estimated at over $40,000. For instance, the alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black is valued at $40,000, the Two Face mask from Batman Forever at $1,500, the Grinch costume at $8,000, and the Mikey costume also at $30,000. The collection spans over 50 productions during Baker's 30-year career, including films like An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy, Mighty Joe Young, Michael Jackson's Moonwalker film, and the Thriller music video. Items from these films, including the iconic Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons, a Bat Gremlin from Gremlins 2, and various other props, are included in the auction. Brandon Alinger of Prop Store expressed excitement about the opportunity for collectors and fans to own pieces of film history. The auction will have no reserve, meaning all items will be sold to the highest bidder.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, died while skiing with his family in the French Alps. He became separated from his mother and sister, and his footprints led police to his body after he fell over a 164ft drop into dense woodland. His family described him as a "daring, outgoing, and determined" youngster whose "handsome smile lit up any room." They expressed their devastation and the void left in their hearts by his death. Carwyn was a competent skier and snowboarder who had been skiing since the age of three. The family had been enjoying a happy ski holiday in the resort of Flaine before the tragedy occurred. Carwyn's mother, Ceri, 44, desperately tried to find her son after he went missing. The family is well known in their community for their award-winning farm shop, and the community has rallied behind them in their time of grief.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after being bullied for her weight and feeling pressured to be thin. She survived on just one piece of fruit a day and hid food to avoid eating. Her weight loss led to her collapsing and being hospitalized, where she was put on a heart monitor. After a week in the hospital, Laura began receiving support from eating disorder organizations. She has since recovered and is now competing in Miss Teen GB, a contest that promotes positive body image and confidence. Laura's story highlights the pressures young girls face to be a size zero and the dangers of anorexia.

Raheem Sterling and other Liverpool players, including Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, unveiled the club's new home kit at Anfield. The kit, designed by New Balance, is part of a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal. Fans at the event expressed their desire for Sterling to stay at the club, with one fan shouting "make sure we see you in that next season." Sterling spoke positively about the fans and the club, while Sturridge emphasized the importance of winning the FA Cup. The new kit features an all-white branding and an all-new style of collar. Liverpool's focus is on the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley next weekend. The shirt also pays tribute to the Hillsborough disaster with a memorial flame and the number 96. Liverpool legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush attended the launch. Sterling recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract, sparking speculation about his future, but Liverpool are adamant he will stay.

The largest single high-definition map of dark matter has been produced by researchers at the University of Manchester. This map is the first in a series that will eventually allow a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device, and the 13ft (four meters) Victor M. Blanco Telescope located at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile. The map shows clumps of dark matter, with red indicating more dark matter and blue indicating less. The goal is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years. The map was released at the April meeting of the American Physical Society in Baltimore, Maryland. Dark matter, which makes up at least 80% of the matter in the known universe, cannot be directly observed but its gravitational effects on galaxies can be studied. The map covers 0.4% of the sky, with the moon shown for scale. The project, part of the Dark Energy Survey, aims to study how galaxies formed in the universe and to probe the nature of dark energy. The team at Manchester analyzed 130 million separate telescope images of galaxies to create the map, a process that requires significant computing power. The survey will continue until 2018, providing more insights into the distribution of dark matter and its role in the universe.

manchester united have made an official approach for psv eindhoven star memphis depay. the 21-year-old dutch winger has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and has attracted interest from other big european clubs, including paris saint-germain. depay worked under louis van gaal during the 2014 world cup, where he scored for the netherlands. tottenham had a £15million bid rejected for him last summer. psv technical director marcel brands confirmed that manchester united, paris saint-germain, and another big european club have made contact about depay. depay started his career at vv moordrecht and sparta rotterdam before joining psv at the age of 12. he made his first-team debut in 2011 and has since made over 100 appearances for the club. depay is known for his pace, close control, and ability to run at defenders. he has been compared to arjen robben and even a young cristiano ronaldo by some. he was part of the netherlands squad that finished third in the 2014 world cup.

Chelsea took a 3-1 lead back to West London after a strong performance against Manchester City's young side in the youth cup final. Tammy Abraham scored twice with fierce drives, and Dominic Solanke added a third late on. Chelsea's defense, featuring Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, was solid, while Ola Aina and Jay Dasilva were influential on the flanks. Manchester City's standout player was Brandon Barker, but they struggled to contain Chelsea's attack. Chelsea's midfield, with Charlie Colkett at the helm, controlled the game. Dominic Solanke's late goal sealed the win for Chelsea.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes that people are born with a sexual preference. He does not think that same-sex marriage should be a constitutional right, but rather a decision made by state legislatures. Rubio stated that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he disagreed with their decision. He emphasized that he is not against gay marriage, but believes that marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman. Rubio believes that the definition of marriage should be decided through political debate at the state level, not by the courts. As a Catholic, he also mentioned that he believes divorce is wrong, but he would not stop loving someone who was divorced.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are cycling around the world with no plans, agenda, or cause. They quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and started their journey last year. In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles and been through 16 countries. They live on less than three euros each per day, meticulously calculating their expenses. They keep costs down by camping (161 nights), using hosting websites like couchsurfing (66 nights) and warmshowers (44 nights), and sometimes relying on the kindness of strangers. Food is their main expense, costing them 2.74 euros each per day. Their diet consists of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits, and vegetables, and they occasionally pick up wild fruits or free food from kind strangers or dumpsters. They started in London, heading through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey. They cycled across the northern coast of Turkey and are now in Armenia, planning to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent. They expect to be on the road for the following years, living out their dream of discovering different parts of the planet at a pedal at a time.

A couple from Texas who got married in 2012 claims that their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, wrote racial slurs on the bottom of their photo booth snapshots. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue James Evans for the alleged racist incident. The couple was not aware of the offensive photos until months after the wedding when the bride's sister informed them. James Evans reportedly told the couple to "sue me" when confronted about the incident and did not apologize. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. They are seeking an apology at the very least and are not focused on monetary compensation. Mediation is scheduled for the next day, and if no agreement is reached, the case will go to trial in July. James Evans denies all allegations and claims there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion. He withdrew from Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley due to feeling unwell after the France game. He is aware of the risks of multiple concussions, citing the examples of George North and Johnny Sexton, who have had extended breaks due to concussions. Brown is not rushing his return to action and is following a step-by-step process to monitor his recovery. He credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, gained through online modules, for helping him make informed decisions about his health. He emphasizes the importance of honesty and caution when dealing with concussions. Brown is currently unsure when he will return to action but is determined not to rush his recovery.

Smartphone use and the emergence of the internet have been linked to a decline in the frequency of sex among couples in Britain. Research shows that the average British couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, suggests that the integration of public and private lives due to constant internet and email access has reduced the time couples spend together. He also points out that more people living alone could be a factor. However, the main explanation is that the boundaries between work and home life have become blurred, leading to less time for intimacy. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, adds that dealing with work emails late in the evening can make it difficult for couples to focus on each other at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, were once highly prized in China, with one fetching £1.2 million just a year ago. However, their popularity has plummeted due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption campaign, which has made gifting them to officials risky. Additionally, bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities, including Beijing, have contributed to their decline. Recently, 20 Tibetan mastiffs were found crammed into cages on their way to a slaughterhouse, where their meat is used for hotpots and their skin for leather belts. This shocking trade is partly due to unscrupulous breeders and thieves selling them to abattoirs. The breed's popularity peaked in 2005, and they were seen as status symbols. The decline is also attributed to urbanization, as the dogs are not well-suited to city living.

Every woman surveyed in Paris claimed to have been a victim of some kind of sexual harassment on the city's public transport. Half of them were assaulted before they were 18 years old. The poll led to calls for a campaign to stem sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains. The survey found that every female user of mass transit has been a victim of "gender harassment or sexual assault," even though some are "unaware" because they have been conditioned to accept low-level abuse. Harassment ranges from insults and intimidating behavior to sex attacks or rape. Six out of ten women are afraid of being attacked on public transport compared to three out of ten men. The problem often goes unreported and limits women's freedom, forcing them to alter their daily lives to avoid confrontation. The result is that women are excluded from the public arena. The poll led to calls for a campaign to address the issue. Women need to be educated that what they are going through is not normal, and the message must reach aggressors and witnesses.

A company called Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix. They asked people to pick their top ten 'everyday emergencies' and then asked groups to design products to alleviate these issues. The top emergency was not being able to sleep, which led to the creation of a product called Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications. Another product, Forget Me Lock, is a device that fastens on a key and changes color to indicate whether the door is locked or unlocked. The third product, Nipper, is a small phone charger that uses household batteries. People can vote for their favorite product by retweeting tweets with the #everydayfix hashtag. The winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. Other products that didn't make the final shortlist included a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists, a parking pin that alerts you when a parking space is free, and an app that lets you nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is facing a Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating more than £500,000 of public money to a charity she runs alongside the force's chief constable, Sue Sim. Baird donated the money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity supporting crime victims in the area, of which she is a director. Chief Constable Sue Sim also sits on the charity's top table. Keith Vaz, the Labour chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, criticized the move as inappropriate and a conflict of interest, likening the situation to a soap opera. The Home Secretary had previously implemented a rule allowing PCCs to commission services for victims of crime. Baird defended her decision, stating that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. The Ministry of Justice will investigate whether any conflict of interest rules were broken. Chief Constable Sue Sim, who faced misconduct proceedings over alleged workplace bullying, announced her retirement last week. Victims First Northumbria was established after the number of people contacting its predecessor, Victim Support, decreased.

Three people have been sent to prison and another two are awaiting sentencing for their roles in a horrific assault on a 53-year-old man. The victim, Greg Valecce, was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. The ringleader, Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles. The assault occurred in the basement of Campbell's mother's house in Mayfair, Philadelphia, in late March 2014. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, took turns punching and spitting on Valecce, filming the abuse. Valecce was tattooed with offensive images and words, including "RIP Pebbles" and swastikas. He suffered three busted ribs, two broken wrists, and fractured facial bones. Valecce escaped on April 1 and contacted police. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in state prison, Halin received the same sentence, and Ng was sentenced to 23 months in state prison. David Thomas, 28, is awaiting sentencing, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, is awaiting trial.

manchester united have made an official approach for psv eindhoven star memphis depay. the 21-year-old dutch winger has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and has attracted interest from other big european clubs, including paris saint-germain. depay worked under louis van gaal during the 2014 world cup, where he scored for the netherlands. tottenham had a £15million bid rejected for him last summer. psv technical director marcel brands confirmed that manchester united, paris saint-germain, and another big european club have made contact about depay, and that the asking price has increased since last summer. depay started his career at vv moordrecht and sparta rotterdam before joining psv at the age of 12. he made his first-team debut in 2011 and has since made over 100 appearances for the club. depay is known for his pace, close control, and ability to run at defenders. he has been compared to arjen robben and even a young cristiano ronaldo by some. he was part of the netherlands squad that finished third in the 2014 world cup.

Chelsea took a 3-1 lead back to West London after a strong performance in Manchester against Manchester City's young side. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half with fierce drives, and Dominic Solanke added a third late on. Chelsea's defense, featuring Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, was solid, while Ola Aina and Jay Dasilva were influential on the right and left, respectively. For Manchester City, Tosin Adarabioyo was a commanding presence at the heart of defense, and Brandon Barker was their standout player. However, City's efforts were not enough to overcome Chelsea's strong attack and midfield. Chelsea's Tammy Abraham scored two volleys, and Dominic Solanke sealed the win with a third goal. Chelsea's midfield, led by Charlie Colkett, controlled the game, and their overall performance was a testament to their strength in depth.

Marco Rubio believes people are born with a sexual preference but does not think same-sex marriage should be a constitutional right. He thinks the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio believes states should decide on gay marriage, not the courts. He would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he disagreed with their decision. As a presidential candidate, Rubio has received monetary commitments for his campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are cycling around the world with no plans, agenda, or cause. They quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and started their journey last year. In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles and been through 16 countries. They live on less than three euros each per day, meticulously calculating their expenses. They keep costs down by camping (161 nights), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and sometimes relying on the kindness of strangers. Food is their main expense, costing them 2.74 euros each per day. Their diet consists of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits, and vegetables, and they occasionally pick up wild fruits or free food from kind strangers or dumpsters. They started in London, heading through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey. They cycled across the northern coast of Turkey into Georgia and Armenia, planning to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent. They expect to be on the road for the following years, living out their dream of discovering different parts of the planet at a pedal at a time.

Mike Brown, the England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion. He withdrew from Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley due to feeling unwell after the France game. He is aware of the risks of rushing back to play, citing the examples of George North and Johnny Sexton who have had extended breaks due to concussions. Brown was knocked out in England's match against Italy in February and pulled out of the Ireland game due to symptoms. Increased awareness of concussion symptoms, from online modules provided by World Rugby, has helped him understand the importance of not playing when concussed. He emphasizes the seriousness of the issue and the need for honesty when dealing with concussions. Brown is currently unsure when he will return to action and is taking it stage by stage, assessing his condition after each step in the recovery process.

Smartphone use and the emergence of the internet have been linked to a decline in the frequency of sex among couples in Britain. Research shows that the average heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, suggests that the integration of public and private lives due to constant internet and email access has reduced the time couples spend together. He also points out that more people living alone could be a factor. However, the main explanation is that technology has made our lives busier and blurred the lines between work and home life, reducing the time available for intimate activities. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, adds that dealing with work emails late in the evening can make it difficult for couples to focus on each other at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, were once highly prized in China, with one fetching £1.2 million just a year ago. However, their popularity has plummeted, leading to some being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and skin. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption campaign, which has made gifting the dogs to officials risky, and to bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. Animal welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs on their way to a slaughterhouse, where they were to be used for hotpot meat and leather belts. The dogs were found in poor condition, with some already dead and others suffering from broken bones. The breed's popularity also suffered from unscrupulous breeding practices that led to a glut of poor-quality dogs. The rapid pace of urbanization has also made people realize that Tibetan mastiffs are not well-suited to city living. The breed's boom began in 2005, and they were seen as status symbols, but their fortunes have changed dramatically.

A company called Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix. They asked people to pick their top ten 'everyday emergencies' and then asked groups to design products to alleviate these emergencies. The top emergency was not being able to sleep, so a group called Instruments designed a product called 'Snooze', an alarm clock that connects with your phone and silences notifications to ensure a good night's sleep. To deal with forgetting to lock the door, Onn Studio created the 'Forget Me Lock', a device that fastens on the key and swivels green to show the door is open and red to signify it's locked. For running out of phone battery, Impulse designed 'Nipper', the world's smallest mobile phone charger, which uses any household battery as its energy source. People can vote for their favorite product by retweeting tweets about Snooze, Forget Me Lock, or Nipper with the #everydayfix hashtag. The product with the most retweets by April 40th will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed. Products that didn't make the cut included a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cycling, a parking pin that alerts you when a parking space is free, and an app that lets you nominate people to receive your messages when your phone dies.
